summary: Now an adult with three children, bank teller Michael Banks learns that his house will be repossessed in five days unless he can pay back a loan. His only hope is to find a missing certificate that shows proof of valuable shares that his father left him years earlier. Just as all seems lost, Michael and his sister receive the surprise of a lifetime when Mary Poppins -- the beloved nanny from their childhood -- arrives to save the day and take the Banks family on a magical, fun-filled adventure.

reviews.content: I thought Mary Poppins was angry. In the original movie Mary Poppin was stern, yes but kind. This new Mary Poppins scared me.

The songs are very poor and sung in an old-fashioned pitch that will annoy your dog.
'Tricks' are borrowed from the original, such as the magic bag, penguins and many other aspects. 
It's all a bit worthy, constipated, fragmented. It lacks originality and above all, fun.
I think the audience score is a lot more accurate than the critics.
Loved it!!!!  I think Emily Blunt is great.  The cartoon sequence is like the original Disney movies.

This film came out at just the perfect time. Beautifully blending Miranda's unprecedented songwriting and the original film's nostalgia, Rob Marshall has weaved together a colorful spectacle, a marvel of a film, that will not only engage the eye, but awaken hope in the heart. We need more movies like these. 

5/5
BORING! nothing like the original.

I think this movie was a wasted opportunity. The cast was pretty good, there was some good choreography… the music was terribly quiet. Usually on my tv, the dialogue is too quiet and the sound effects and music are too loud… but with this movie, the music is too quiet. 

Whoever they had playing Mary poppins did a decent portrayal… she really did capture the essence in a lot of ways; however with better direction maybe that could have been done a little more or a little better. 

They tried really hard to mirror a lot of things, which could be a good thing if the music popped more… but without the music, it's a little hollow.
An excellent continuation to the classic filled with emotion and smiles.

A very fun and entertaining sequel which holds up well compared to the original Emily Blunt does a great job playing Mary Poppins and brings a lot of charm to the role if you enjoyed the original then you'll definitely want to give this a watch

This is a jolly, fun, colourful and of course family friendly sequel to the original 1960s Mary Poppins film. It features (like the original film) a mix of animation and live action scenes and various irritatingly catchy tunes (you've been warned, parents). Its certainly an entertaining watch...not by any means a particularly stand-out, amazingly memorable film, this is a solid piece of good family entertainment, which I imagine pretty much all fans of the original film will enjoy, certainly in parts, if not in full. Of course its also very much sentimental and unsurprisingly cheesy (but of course!), with some pretty predictable plot aspects but I suppose that's pretty much to be expected. As Disney films like this go, its well worth a watch if your interested I reckon, so yes, I'd recommend it, although I wouldn't necessarily say its the best of recent Disney films, its by no means bad either. (also, finally, I couldn't quite figure out (certainly on first watching) what the symbolism was of the sailor and the boat.

Horrible. To live up to the original, a Mary poppins sequel must have a tremendous soundtrack. The music in this movie is forgettable at best, and annoying at worst. Emily blunts performance is redeeming but not enough to carry this movie this clumsy, disaster. I'd rather just watch the original masterpiece than be bored to tears with this garbage. Can we find something else for Lin Manuel Miranda to do please?
Good family movie, enjoyable

The visual effects in this film are downright weak. Not much extra is added to the original story, both in interpretation and story. Ultimately, the film falls through the holes with a masterful, charming performance by Emily Blunt and a Meryl Streep that is still worth its weight in gold.

Spit spot!  Mary Poppins is back, and she has just as much to impart on us this time as she did her previous visit.  Yes, times have changed since we saw her last, but life's quandaries are still solved the same way.  Mary makes sure we know that being positive will always give us the best outcome, that every task can have an element of fun if we choose to find/see it, and that one need never apologize for who they are.

Sequels of classic films rarely live up to anyone's expectations.  For this reason, I thought it best to avoid seeing Mary Poppins Returns when it debuted in 2018, lest it sully my appreciation for the original flick (Mary Poppins).  However, since I made it my 2022 goal to view every motion picture featuring Meryl Streep, I was forced to take this sequel in.  And now that I have… I'm very appreciative of the experience.  It was an enchanting escape.

Emily Blunt took on the unenviable task of stepping into an iconic role established in 1964 by the legendary Julie Andrews.  Blunt wisely chose to make the character her own, rather than attempting to act like Julie Andrews.  Her Poppins is a bit sterner but still imbued with a sense of whimsy and humor.  Lin-Manuel Miranda plays new character, Jack, who is a former protégé to chimneysweep, Bert, from the original film.  Jack is a lamplighter who is aware of who Mary Poppins is before she arrives.   

Mary Poppins returns to 1930's London to help Michael and Jane Banks.  Michael and Jane were the children she nannied in the original film.  Now they are grown and in peril of losing their family home in a foreclosure to the bank.  Michael is a widower with three precocious children of his own.   Actors Pixie Davies, Nathanael Saleh, and Joel Dawson play Annabel, John, and Georgie Banks, and all three are delightful from the get-go.  Pish posh!  Mary takes the new children on grand adventures, just as she did in the original film.  While the movie is just as clever as the original, it isn't quite as sharp.  There are no Super-cali-fragil-istik-expi-ali-docious or Spoon Full of Sugar ditties that you will be humming or whistling for days after.  One of the more memorable songs is when Mary's cousin Topsy (Meryl Streep) sings "Turning Turtle".  Streep, in usual form, makes the absolute most of her outrageous character and her eight minutes of screen time… in the most delightful way.  

If you are a fan of the original Mary Poppins and you have not seen this sequel, do yourself a favor and take some time to do so!  Sometimes some saccharine is simply grand for the soul.

B*ll*cks to anyone reviewing this who is unable to move on from the original. This is an extremely underrated movie, and rewatches merely affirm how well made it is. The casting, music, sets and outfits are fantastic. Emily Blunt at her very best 🌂👜✨
A beloved classic has a new take and I enjoyed this with my family.
While it doesn't hit the heights of the original, it still has excellent performances and keeps that family-friendly charm while also having some pretty good songs making this a fun watch.

This was really pretty bad. Take something that people once loved and try to recreate it without any understanding whatsoever of what made the original any good and you get something like this. It's like a cardboard cutout of a good movie, but worse because you've cut all the heads off too.
They couldn’t of made a better sequel. Period.
Visually amazing and furthermore that 2D animation is so nostalgic! My rating: 8/10
This Film In Short Terms Sucks

While the original was Wow Original!, this one is just a rehash to the point that even the story beats are all the same.  Blunt is acceptable as Poppins, which is high compliment when trying to carry the umbrella of Julie Andrews.  Honestly, if you saw Mary Poppins, you've already seen this one as well.

No sequel would ever be as good as the original Mary Poppins, but this is a perfect attempt. Fun, music and pure joy in each moment bound to have the children excited and adults reminiscing their childhood watching the original.

This works really well as film-maker classroom exercise in answering the question, how would you remake Mary Poppins? It's the right answer. A kinda sequel many years later, with a generation skipped, little to no exposition needed, just enough difference to the original that you don't directly compare and Disney resist the urge to go modern on 3D animation, opting instead for a retro feel of the original. That's about as well as you can do to be honest, from there you have to like Poppins and buy into the conceit, similarly explored in Paddington, that the travails of a lovely middle class West London family is the most important thing in the world. In Poppins, cue forlock tugging, leaping cocked-ees risking life and limb to scale Big Ben Tower when Poppins just floats up on a brolly. Sorry I'm late for dinner love, we all had to go find a share certificate that allows a shit artist who's never done a days hard work in his life to hang onto a £3m mansion, ‘cos he's polite and all and his sister maybe saucy.
Meh sequel, slower than the first and pretentious.

I thought it was a solid follow-up to the original without blowing me out of the water. Emily Blunt did a superb job stepping in the shoes of Julie Andrews and the supporting cast were generally very good, although I was on the fence about Lin-Manuel Miranda's turn as Jack in the quasi-Bert role played by Dick Van Dyck in the original. Overall though, (almost) as great to watch with the kids as the original was.

I consider myself to be an expert reviewer of the original 60s film having watched it for around 50 years every festive season. I couldn't bring myself to watch a remake until this year, 2021, having already watched the original earlier on in December. Have to say, pleasantly surprised. The new take on Bert was good. The kids were good. The maid was good as was the captain. But, Emily Blunt as Mary?  Trying too hard. Far too posh and stuffy. The musicality was ok, not a patch on the original though, same for the scenery. In fact despite the new techno age, I preferred the original scenery. All in all, a fair effort, but make sure she stays away for good this time!

I was ok until 49:25 (ISH) when Mary Poppins started doing a cabaret and did a pelvic thrust 'comin av a look' line .. 
The author rolled in her grave... That was diabolical... And a couple times before that I let slide because I though Emily blunt was ok but too giddy... That was the final straw... Also having a bad guy of Colin firth was not a Mary Poppins trope.... They butchered the character...

Nothing can beat the 1964 Mary Poppins no way no how.  We weren't asking for a sequel to be made but it happened.  Taking  place in early 1930s London Mary Poppins Returns continues the story with poor and unmemorable plot.  Michael Banks is going to loose his house and Mary Poppins comes back and teaches his kids to change their dad around with reverse psychology.  Adding to it a boring villain, Computer Generated Animation trying to pass its self off for hand drawn animation and Disney once again making A wolf a horrible character.(another way of pushing the wolf to extinction)  Mary Poppins Returns is a recycled and hastily done sequel that is that makes you appreciate the original one more and is yet again another reason why Disney has no respect for the original film and tarnishs the characters that where created.  If Walt Disney was still alive he would definitely be disappointed and destroyed that his studio pushed out into the world.

Being as the original is one of the all time classics and a favourite for me I was as a bit worried before watching this. But now I've watched it I enjoyed it as much as the original. Emily Blunt was a great choice to play Mary Poppins as she plays her version just as great as I remember Julie Andrews played her version on the first, second, third, fourth.......... nth viewing of that film over the years. No doubt over the years Mary Poppins Returns will have second, third, fourth......... nth viewings like the original.

The nostalgia I have for Mary Poppins could be me giving this a higher grade than necessary due to being biased.  I think Emily Blunt is a perfect casting here.  The special effects are great but the movie never quite took off.

"Mary Poppins Returns to once again help the Banks children". That line in the movie immediately told me that the writers of this film had no idea what the first movie was about. Since this film is written as a sequel, but is essentially a remake of the original it doesn't have the spirit it needed to call it a true Mary Poppins movie. Emily Blunt was enjoyable in the lead role, though she can't seem to keep her feet in the right formation, and I felt she smiled too much. Lin-Manuel Miranda was miscast in this film. His acting chops didn't seem to match what was expected of a film actor. The sets in this film didn't have the same London feel from the original, instead they looked like set pieces in a sound stage built for a small musical. The music in this movie is mostly forgettable with the exception of "A Cover is Not a Book" and "The Place Where Lost Things Go". The climax of this movie felt pointless after everything was done. The best thing in this film is the cameo from Dick Van Dyke, I was smiling every moment he was on screen. If you're curious check this film out.
A good, kind, children's film. Boring in places, but for family viewing the most.

Nothing says wholesome family fun like feminism coupled with less than memorable songs. Most of the scenes are pedantic attempts to adhere to some of the cornerstone's of the original. Clearly an attempted cash grab by those who now run the Disney corporation, Walt is rolling in his grave and if Travers was alive, she would be regretting ever touching pen to paper. It'll take more than a spoon full of sugar to get through this one. A full bottle of bourbon might be a better option. I'll give it a full star because they created a movie that somehow made it into our homes.
How dare Disney try to re-do Mary Poppins with a new gal, shame on you Disney to wantonly try to capitulate on a Classic Movie!

A poor copy of the original, what was charming is now cringey. Hated it the first time and gave it another go thinking maybe I'd been harsh. Nope, gets worse as it goes along and I fought to finish it.

Worst thing Meryl Streep has ever done by the way.
The movie is sweet and fun, really captures everything you want and expect from a Mary Poppins movie.
Another Disney cash-grab that plays very safe and doesn't leave you with a message at the end, trying to be just as good as the original movie, but forgetting to be original.

2nd Watch: FABULOUS. Early on, you can see Lin Manuel Miranda wanting to break through and belt out a GREAT MUSICAL NUMBER. And when he does (A Cover is Not a Book), he steals the film. 1st Watch: I saw the original during its first run.  I've seen it dozens of times. I didn't bother with this one in theatres, but did check it out from the library.  I LOVED IT.  Emily Blunt is very good, almost as perfect as Julie Andrews. BUT, Lin-Manuel Miranda is AMAZING and steals the entire movie from everyone else, even from Meryl Streep. I thought the themes here to be more of an adult nature and I guess that's why I loved this so much. I am buying a copy, this one is a classic! And this score is BRILLIANT!!!

The original is better in pretty much every way other than when it comes to the technical aspects but honestly, this is surprisingly a solid sequel. The songs, whilst not as good, are still really catchy and fun, the production design is excellent, Lin Manuel Miranda and Emily Blunt are incredibly charming in their roles and it has a lot of fun fantasy elements like swimming underwater in a bathtub, an upside down antique store and a music hall. It also has a lot of heart and emotion and a beautiful message about childhood and remembering it, which is really appropriate given how old this movie is. It just puts a huge smile on my face. The story itself does hit the same plot beats as the original sadly and as I said, none of the songs come up to the levels of the original but a good sequel.
This is a great movie! In fact I thought it as good if not better then the first Mary Poppins.
Not nearly as good as the original. Very slow.
So heartwarming....loved it and cried - and if I told you when, I’d spoil the surprise!
Mary Poppins Returns brings fresh nostalgia and style to its familiar story that more than holds up on its own.
as good as the original, WONDERFUL!
another show trying to recreate a show that was done by one of the greats!! you cant out do Julie Andrews and Dick VanDyk
A sequel made too late ruined by feminism and sexism towards men. Emily Blunt was brilliant as Mary Poppins though.
this is a solid sequel to the original film although not as good. the songs are catchy, Emily Blunt makes a good Mary Poppins.
It wasn't as good as the original, but it still has family fun.
This was a lot better than I thought. I enjoyed the colors and visual effects, but found it just a little too similar to the original.
The funniest Disney sequel ever!! Julie Andrews used to sing!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I didn't grow up with the first Mary Poppins, and sadly have never been a fan.  This movie really worked for me though!  The visual effects were very beautiful, the story was engaging, and the music was well done.

A rehash of the first movie. An easy cash grab that has no heart. I'll give some credit, i did like emily blunt's potrayal as mary poppins, the songs were nice, the cinematography looked good and dick van dykes cameo was nice. Besides that, an easy cash grab with no new elements. Mary poppins returns 54% D
super fun and charming
cant help but smile watching this
Definitely not my kind of movie. I was so compelled to go home afterward and watch the bloodiest violent mature action-packed movie I could find!
Very boring. VERY boring.
It's pretty good, but it doesn't beat the classic 1964 film.
poor remake. story, singing, dancing. completely horrible. what a bust. Walt would be turning in his grave. Can't beat Dick Van Duke dancing on the roof

Disney worked its magic here to create a worthy successor to 'Marry Poppins'. Great looking London in the 1800's (or is it early 1900's) lot's of fragments that reminds one of the original movie but are not just copies of that. I think they did a great a job in the nigh impossible task to create a sequel to that iconic movie.
The original Mary Poppins was just so practically perfect in every way. It's hard for this movie to even compare.
Huge disappointment. Doesn't come close to the original. Had so much potential.

Giving a star for nostalgia. And another star for effort. But the movie itself was way too long that it bores me out to death. The unnecessary lengthy dances and uncatchable song scenes makes it far less entertaining than it should be.

This is a good sequel that could never live up to the original.  The most interesting part to me is tortured relationship between the supernatural Poppins and her Jack, reincarnated by Lin Manuel Miranda.  Watching those two on screen is reason enough to see this.

Thank you Mary Poppins for warmly reminding us that anything is possible
Mrs. Shullivan and I treated ourselves to a special early Christmas present by attending the opening night of Mary Poppins Returns. Our anticipation for this night was more than just rewarded, we received a very pleasant reminder that although we are more than half a century old we are all still children at heart if we just allow our imaginations to wander as when we were children.

Emily Blunt was perfectly cast as Mary Poppins as was Lin-Manuel Miranda as Jack the Lantern lighter. The story line surrounds the now adult Michael Banks (Ben Whishaw) who lost his wife just a few years ago and is trying to raise his three (3) young children in the original Banks family home at 17 Cherry Tree Lane. Michael's sister Jane (Emily Mortimer) is single, never married, and has her own apartment while she fights for the rights of the low income workers.

Michael Banks three children are Anabel,John and the youngest Georgie. The three Banks children love their father and sooner than they should have to worry about losing their home through a bank foreclosure , Mary Poppins magically appears. Mrs. Shullivan and I, as well as the rest of the theaters audience let out a noticeable sigh of relief because we realized that the magic of a Walt Disney movie is now upon us, and we were not disappointed in our faith in Mary Poppins. Quite the contrary, the evening was perfect as the films songs were beautiful, the dance numbers choreographed and animated to as many animals as were on Noah's Ark, the cinematography magical and the story of Michael and Jane Banks and the children that warms one's heart.

We especially loved the Banks childrens first afternoon bath with Mary Poppins and their most colorful and animated underworld adventure with song and dreams of a magical world. Just believe and anything is possible!

A sequel to one of Disney’s most precious films is a hard task to accomplish. Emily Blunt in the title role delivers a good performance following the original Julie Andrew’s. The one thing this film lacks is that the music is really not that great. The original film had some of the greatest show tunes of all time, while this felt like a cheesy ride soundtrack in a theme park. My main concern is did this film need to be made? Probably not. It gives a glimmer of magic to new audiences but most scenes don’t serve a purpose to let Mary Poppins fly away with grace.
Waste of money and of your time. The songs are forced and bland. If they wanted to make another mary poppins film, they should've reboot the film, not a boring trying to be sequel.

I don't know why so many people are hating on this movie because this movie is phenomenal. Maybe it's because people don't like change or anything new. But this movie is a great fantastic phenomenal Disney musical adventure starring the wonderful Emily blunt, the Mr Alexander Hamilton himself Lin Manuel Miranda, meryl Streep, Colin Firth, Ben whishaw, and some random kids that could sing really high notes. I really enjoyed this movie from the songs to the musical score to the choreography to the set design to the animation to pretty much anything this movie has to offer. To me this is an amazing sequel to a classic movie and I hope they don't make another sequel like what Disney did with the Muppets but I hope they don't make another sequel but if they do it better be 50 years from now. I can't wait to see this movie again on Disney plus.
You can see they tried to get the spark the original had but it just isn't there. The magic has gone. The songs are long and boring.
Nostalgia is fine and all, but the film flubs its message by going on a tad too long in an ending that spoils the message of the original.

It's hard to believe that anyone else could measure up to Julie Andrews and Dick VanDyke, but Emily Blunt and Lin-Manuel Miranda were sure up to the challenge. I enjoyed the movie as much as a grandmother as I did the original as a child. The special appearance of Dick VanDyke was the cherry on top. Bravo!

It takes some serious courage to take on a sequel to one of the most loved family films of all time, especially after all these years and no presenting reason to do so. Unless of course the casting, the performances, the songs and the story are all confident and on point. Which, to my immense relief, they mostly are.

The songs mostly work - the only musical sequence that felt like a false-step to me was the one involving Meryl Streep's character, a side-line of the plot which felt unnecessary and a little indulgent. Otherwise, the performances are confident and pitch-perfect. Ben Wishaw, also given his excellent work in the Paddington films, is beginning to carve a niche for himself in these family films; there's something in his careful blend of fragility and hidden strength  - as well as exceptional comic timing - that is ideal for these films. Lin-Manuel Miranda burns up the screen every time he's on it with an effervescence that confirms him as a performer born for musicals. 

But it all hinges, naturally, on the title character. Given an almost impossible task, Emily Blunt is pretty much perfect, the right mix of continuity with the original performance and making the character uniquely her own. At no point did I find myself thinking that this isn't the Mary Poppins who was so ever-present in my childhood. 

The plot is also surprisingly clever, dealing with some important themes of adults repressing the magical innocence of child-like fun under the weight of life's responsibilities and losses. Like all the best family entertainment, this film isn't afraid to look pain and grief in the face. 

The measure of how successful this film is comes with the ending. I had thought the rush to the bank against the clock (neatly nodding at Hitchcock in part of the action) was the film's ending, but there were still a good number of minutes to go and I feared an over-extended goodbye that would leave me frustrated and bored. But what resulted was an honest, joyful sequence that stays the right side of over-sentimentality and allows an ending fitting to the film's bigger themes; it's moving and uplifting without being naive or saccharine, in such a way as to suggest that this Mary Poppins - as she always does - has arrived at just the right time. This film may actually be one we all need more than we realise.
Quite enjoyable, some songs are catchy. Emily Blunt did a very good job. Children will probably enjoy it more than grown-ups though. It's a nice movie for a sunday afternoon to watch with family.

Being neither a fan of the original, I honestly don't think that after that one and some of Nanny Mcphee movies we needed this one. There wasn't any mesmerizing song and the story lacks of pertinence. The plot was already told in different manners. Its moral lessons are the same as in many other movies. However I confess that Emily Blunt did a great work and that the visual effects are stunning.
Takes all the ideas from the classic original but forgets to add any magic

A sequel to "Mary Poppins" doesn't really feel necessary, but I still think this movie is pleasant enough to watch once. It's a movie that audiences of all ages can enjoy and follows familiar beats to the original. Replacing Julie Andrews is no easy task, but I thought Emily Blunt did a solid job and I liked her performance in the movie. The movie doesn't have a particularly memorable story or songs when compared to the first one. The catchiest songs in the original far overshadow any of the songs in this movie. I think the movie played it pretty safe, which is probably for the best, but at the same time, the movie doesn't add a lot to these characters. Overall, Blunt's performance is worth checking out, but the rest of the movie is just passable.
A cringe-worthy attempt to fleece money from fans of Poppins. Nothing new is added and so it only shrinks and detracts from what we love about the original.

Great watch, would watch again, and can recommend.

Having recently watched the original, and "Saving Mr. Banks", it is apparent that this movie does lose some of the charm from the original, but not enough that I think you would notice if you hadn't seen the original in a while.  This is the sort of difference that happens in sequels when the writers are trying to force a recreation rather than naturally extending a story.

Don't get me wrong, the premise, if a bit forced, is lovely and the story is decent enough, but it is the embodiment of Disney's Mary Poppins that Emily Blunt portrays that carries the movie.  I like all the cast in this, some more than others, but everyone did a great job on their deliveries, but the only roles that would have made a real difference would have been Mary Poppins, and possibly Jack, but maybe not.

I would like to see more Mary Poppins, but I'm not sure if one can keep the momentum for this sort of thing, what would a story (or two) look like from her perspective?

A lot of fun and a great follow up to the original. Emily Blunt was awesome as Mary Poppins and the supporting cast did a great job as well. Definitely one of the better sequels to classic or older movies that have come out in recent years.
Desperate attempt to recapture the magic of Mary Poppins

This movie bored movie out of pants! I disliked this whole movie. I really thought that this movie wasn't worth watching! When I saw the trailer for this movie, I was actually wanted, a bit, to watch this movie. But man was it bad! A terrible sequel for Mary Poppins! The fantasy action was lame and the songs had a mild catchy tune to it. Even the songs were were boring! I give this movie 4% of Rotten Tomatoes!

Even the great Emily Blunt can't save this stale retread of the perplexingly popular original. Terrible story worse music and cringeworthy time filling dance numbers. If you like the original this is just like it.

I can see why there are positive reviews. Although I appreciated the movie being faithful to the original, it seems a little...too faithful. It seemed like the new songs were just re-writes of the other songs (nearly all of them sounded like 'a spoonful of sugar'), and a lot of the scenes were like slightly rewritten twins of the scenes in the previous movie. I expected something new to come up, and was surprised the 'wolf' didn't lead to the villain secretly being a magic user or whatever. There were some choices that I thought 'why did they even do this if it didn't lead up to something big?' I'm sure people liked seeing similar stuff for the nostalgia, but I was kind of hoping for something fresh and new. No such luck. In the end it left me feeling neutral to the movie, besides a couple chuckles and a tear or two. It seemed like it had elements leading to a nice surprise, but it kept to the same formula as the first movie, and honestly I kind of wish it hadn't so much.
Dull with forgettable songs.
Some songs dragged on for too long but alright. Probably not the best Friday night or weekend film from Disney by far.
Lacks something. Does not have the strong melodies of the original. Feels a bit too much like a remake.
The sequel to the cult classic was okay but not creative.

Although perhaps more of a remake than a sequel (the musical sequences, the dance numbers, the animation style, the function itself of all of these in the story and even the structure of the story are all pretty much the same), I can't recall a follow-up that captures the magic, the charm and even the essence of its predecessor in a more practically perfect way. The only two new things this one did are tackling the theme of overcoming grief and giving us an actual villain. While I found the former addition to be absolutely brilliant and it even added a dramatic touch that could be felt from the very first minutes of the movie and the message behind it could be summed up in the lovely, touching song, The Place Where Lost Things Go, I do not think the inclusion of an actual, real villain to be a good decision at all. I believe it somehow took away from the moral value of the movie a little bit, and made it more "childish", so to speak. That said, Mary Poppins Returns is almost supercalifragilisticexpialidocious as the 1964's classic.

(8/10)
Went with a group with high expectations, really drawn out and all of us left the theater half way through. Boring and drawn out. Was extremely disappointed

"Mary Poppins Returns" actually does alright on its own. Independent of the 1964 masterpiece "Mary Poppins", this is a perfectly passable and somewhat enjoyable film. However, the main and glaring flaw of this production is that it simply does the same things that the 1964 original did, except not nearly as well. But it isn't entirely this film's fault – after all, it is impossible to live up to the masterpiece that is the 1964 original. Emily Blunt is no Julie Andrews, but she performs well as Mary Poppins. Lin-Manuel Miranda doesn't do quite as well as Blunt, and not nearly as well as Dick Van Dyke in the 1964 original, but he does okay. All the other performances are passable, but not nearly as memorable as those in the 1964 original. In my opinion, the songs in this film are actually pretty good, even though they're blatant imitations of the far-better, catchy, memorable, and brilliantly-written songs of the 1964 original. The script and the story are easily this film's weak points – they're either bad because they make no sense or bad because they're far too similar to the 1964 original. Most of all, it lacks most of the heart and soul that made the 1964 original the masterpiece it is. Yet it's still an okay film. All in all, while "Mary Poppins Returns" isn't practically perfect in every way, it is a passable film which has its moments. Not a must-see, but if you think you'd be interested, take a look at it.

In every sequel that is done, there should be an element of fun. And while Mary Poppins Returns is a visual delight, the story and the songs don't quite have the same magic as the original. In fact, the only parts that truly feel supercalifragilisticexpialidocious are when they reference the 1964 Disney classic. Nothing against Emily Blunt, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Ben Whishaw, Emily Mortimer and the rest of the cast, who all do a good job, but overall, this follow-up tale is simply unnecessary.
i love watching MARY POPPINS RETURN ITS SUPER AWESOME
Always tough to do a re-make or carry-on from a classic tale, but, I thought they did a great job with this one to make it entertaining and magical

Although not "practically perfect in every way", the director certainly pulls out all the stops to make this work. Mary Poppins Returns plays lovingly with nostalgia. The musical numbers will work for newcomers, while older audiences may find themselves craving to watch the original.

Canned.  Predictable.  Uneventful.  This movie is not worth your time.  Technically this is not a remake, but the story line basically follows the same formula as the original Mary Poppins.  It gets windy and Mary shows up, they do something crazy in the nursery, the family is in financial straits, Mary and the kids go visit someone and crazy stuff happens on the ceiling, a bunch of black-clad lamp-lighters (instead of chimney sweeps) have a crazy dance. Etc Etc Etc. The music was uninspired, none of the songs were unique or memorable.  Emily Blunt seems like she is trying to be like Julie Andrews, and fails at it badly.  Julie Andrews is prim and proper, Emily came off as smug and arrogant.  I would write more, but the bottom line is that you are better off watching the original Mary Poppins instead of watching yet another drab Disney money grab remake...

I suppose if you have an intense emotional attachment to the first Mary Poppins, no other treatment would measure up. But viewed on its own, Mary Poppins Returns is well worth the watch. The film is respectful of its forbear, with snatches of melodic lines from the original film embedded in its score, and many of the scenes loosely built around the original. I loved that the animation is in the old Disney style, rather than Pixar-ized (not that there's anything wrong with Pixar). At the same time, there are contemporary elements: Miranda's rap turn, and the decidedly funky dance moves in the leerie production number. All the performances were solid, with Whishaw, Miranda, Holdbrook-Smith and newcomer Joel Dawson as standouts. Blunt made Mary her own, bringing a hint of world-weary melancholy to the role. The well-realized characters, storytelling and obvious love of the material more than balanced the beautifully designed settings and CGI. My only caveat is with a plot point: why would Mary Poppins let the lamplighters make such a risky manoeuvre at the end when she has the magic to fix the problem right from the start? Other than that, a worthy and heart-warming effort all round.

Raises nostalgia, wonderfully animated part, made me smile and laugh. Horribly cut around including an actor for 2 minutes. Didn't like the deus ex Mary Poppins. It doesn't fit her. Besides that, a wonderful movie for children to look at with wonder, just like I did with the original.

Desperately trying to recapture the magic of the original, and failing, Mary Poppins Returns is a whimsical family film with no heart.  The fates once again call on Mary Poppins when Michael Banks, now a widower, is about to lose his house and his children are despite to help him save it.  Emily Blunt takes on the iconic role of Mary Poppins, but as good as she is she's no Julie Andrews and comes off as a little more stern and less kind.  And the musical numbers aren't nearly as catchy and fun as those from the original film.  A couple are alright, but most of them go on too long, are over produced, and try too hard to be charming and lighthearted.  The writing isn't that good either, as much of the film seems forced and contrived.  While it's entertaining and has a bit of the original's spirit, Mary Poppins Returns doesn't have its passion or its sincerity.

Confession - I have never watched the original 'Mary Poppins' in its entirety, but have seen several extended clips through my life time.  Enough to feel... it wasn't my sort of movie.  A bit too sweet, a little too silly and random.  So, when my girlfriend heartily pushed for us to watch this sequel, I agreed with a cautious concern.

I loved this film.  I thought it was fantastic, with an amazing cast and wonderful sets.  The music was sufficiently fun and playful (though a bit saucier than I expected in one clip when Mary and Jack are singing on stage), with a surprisingly collection of darker and serious themes than I believe the older film would have ever approached.  Emily Blunt steps in well for the incomparable Julie Andrews, and Lin-Manuel Miranda shines with his own impish warm heartedness.

I was so enamored with this film, I even confessed my trepidation for watching it after we finished simply so I could apologize to my girlfriend.  I liked it that much.

Tasked with the impossible, this movie does quite well. No one can recreate Julie Andrews' iconic performance, but Emily Blunt does a great job as the character. There's singing and dancing, as one might expect, and it follows the beats of the original movie in a way that is more comforting than distracting. Still, it finds plenty of new things to do. They go into a cartoon world again, but this time it's a ceramic bowl. There are villainous bankers again, but this time with more tie-ins with the children. They even manage to have tear-jerking song that far surpasses the heartfelt "Feed The Birds". If you like the original, definitely give this one a watch.

Closest Comparison: It's an updated Mary Poppins with a new coat of paint.

Cute but definitely not great. When making a remake of a beloved classic, you have to put extra effort into being original while also not being overly reliant on the original. Emily Blunt was a bit forced in her portrayal, using tag lines constantly and did not have the quiet grace associated with Mary Poppins. And while the song writing was good, it dropped the ball with song for lamp-lighters (im not bothering with looking the song name). Otherwise, most of the music was decent and the vocals overall were pretty good. The presence of a "bad guy" did not hit the mark when it comes to standing up next to the original, which did not have one.
My kids loved it and I loved it. Not one for musicals and this I loved the music and the dancing. Great movie.

Growing up watching the original Mary Poppins I had high hopes for this movie to be practically perfect in every way. Sadly those expectations fell short with complicated songs and dance routines that in my personal opinion did not do justice to the original's legacy.  I also was not a fan of the demeanor of this new Mary Poppins, Julie Andrews while being an amazing singer and wonderful actress brought a sense of light and hope to the original role this new character seemed rather demanding and almost mean at times.  Without the calm charismatic character of the original Mary poppins I found that the new role did not in any way do justice to the original and the role played originally by Julie Andrews could not hope to be replaced by this. That is whatever this role was supposed to be as the character seemed not only harsh and demanding but also lacked the fun, happy, and humorous part that Julie Andrews had provided.  Then throw in a couple lack luster non-catchy music numbers like "Turning Turtle" and "Trip A Little Light Fantastic" which seemed to really dumb down quite a bit from the original music numbers and could never hope to stack up with "supercalifragalisticexpialadocious" or "Chim-chimney" and you'll have the gist of this movie.  Don't get me wrong the actors did a great job with their roles and I personally love Collin Firth but this movie just didn't do justice to the legacy it was set to represent and frankly Mary Poppins flying in on a kite isn't quite the same for me as the traditional umbrella.  Not to mention that it cannot he escaped that the new Mary Poppins looks nothing like Julie Andrews.  The cameos from Angela Lansbury and Van Dyke were a nice addition to the film as well but A few nice moments cannot make up for all the other parts in which this film was severely lacking.  I could go on but I think my point is made.

Honestly that would be a under statement.  Mary Poppins was in fact one of my favorite movies growing up as a child. It was creative and imaginative. Through a childs point of view. You soon would believe the world was full of endless possibilities and wonderful things. If you choose to grasp it.

Dear god this was dreadfully awful. The story was absolutely dismal, the plot was like cold porridge, every scene was forced & nothing flowed naturally. The film did not carry on the same warmth as the original. Poppins played by Blunt, is depicted as more self absorbed & distant, she is portrayed as somebody with internal conflicts but never adds to the story what her internal issues are. Poppins takes a backseat to Jim & every other obnoxious character that pops in at each stage of the film, and the film does feel like just going thru the motions of each stage, until Poppins just up and leaves, forgotten, then we get slapped with the credits. Instead of calling this film “Poppins” they should have called it “Jim”, because that terrible character was pretty much thru out the entire movie that we were subjected to follow his stupid story & stuck with his awful singing, it was pure cringe. Lin-Manuel Miranda’s acting & attempt of being British was an epic failure. Just because he got notoriety for one play on broadway, doesn’t mean he’s talented in other genres. Miranda was overplayed & way out of his dept. He single handedly destroyed this film. Why was this film focused on JIM over everybody else?? This film was more of a fan made film tribute involving the location where Mary Poppins took place and an egotistical love letter by Miranda to himself. To top it off, The lyrical tunes were incredibly poorly written, the music was out of place, forgettable, forced, & just awful. Nobody is singing this garbage. This movie sucked. The characters sucked, the casting sucked, UGH, I’m annoyed I was duped into having been subjected to this garbage. Such a waste.

I liked this film, and I've recommended it.  I must point out, this is not a retread, but a continuation of the Mary Poppins (1965) film starring Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke, both of whom are still living.  It's hard to watch this film and not draw comparisons, but Emily Blunt made a very convincing Mary, both in singing ability and characterization.  Lin-Manuel's lamplighter is clearly a step up compared to Van Dyke's chimney-sweep. He has a much better British accent.  Meryl Streep has a completely silly musical scene with a Russian accent, with an apparent homage to the late Ed Wynn's "I Love To Laugh" Scene.  The lamplighters, on bicycle's do a musical dance number in homage to Van Dyke's "Step In Time" number.  There is a lot of "homage" going on here; it's as if the film is self aware of it's own history.  There is a song-and-dance number with Poppins and penguins (animated), to compare with the dance number Van Dyke did in 1965.  Finally, Van Dyke himself makes a cameo appearance, reprising the same bank elder from 54 years earlier.  Angela Lansbury has a cameo as a balloon lady in the park, which sets up the finale piece "Nowhere To Go But Up", which is basically a homage to "Let's Go Fly A Kite". On the whole, its a lot of fun, but there's a little bit too much "seriousness" with the plotline about the Bank's children losing the house to the very bank George Banks was an employee of, with Colin Firth as the "bad guy'.
It was dorky,, it was ok for little children. I watched it on Netflix and fast forwarded through every musical number.

Disney, Disney, Disney, why? While the movie nicely continues the stories of Jane and Michell, everything else about the movie is a recreation of Disney's original masterpiece. Uncle Albert's ceiling song is replaced by a creepy Meryl Streep and a song about being upside down. Dick Van Dyke's Bert is replaced by Miranda's Jack who does not sound like he really is from London. The story follows the exact same path of the original so much that it is basically a recreation of the original. The scene types are all the same and the song types are all the same. There is nothing new and fresh here and anyone considering watching it should just watch the original and thank God for Van Dyke's horribly funny Cockney accent.

Practically Timeless in Every Way:  There is neither the 4th wall breaking, meta-cultural references (destined to become dated in 10 years), nor the adult innuendo that every other modern family movie seems contractually obligated to provide.  It's just Hamilton worthy musical and dance production numbers, and Emily Blunt perfectly capturing the prim and proper, vain, stern nanny whose sly, subtly flirtatious, smile gives a glimpse of how much fun she is mischievously having.  The Banks grown- up son makes it clear that his Downtown Abbey class hierarchy assures that The Help, magically gifted or not, are subservient to their master class.  Dick Van Dyke has a scene stealing return as an older Mr. Dawes, while Angela Landsbury does a charming rendition of a role that most certainly originally was written for an older Julie Andrews.

The original Mary Poppins was one of my favorite movies when I was a kid and it kind of still is. Thus I was indeed a bit worried when I sat down to watch this one with the kids yesterday. After all there is really so many ways a incompetent writer could have screwed this one up. Especially one with an agenda.

Luckily this was not the case and I have to say that I quite liked this movie. Disney actually managed to keep the ambiance of the original movie and it actually felt like a Disney movie from the good old days. The days before every easily offended (censored by RT) tried to make every movie into a preaching mouth piece for their personal crusade.

I think I liked the first half of the movie best. It was an explosion of song, magic and, for me, nostalgia. Apart from the hugely improved technology this movie had available to make the magic bits it actually felt like it could have been made back to back with the original. They really managed to capture the atmosphere from back then.

If I had to compare the two directly I would still go with the original as the best one. It was more imaginative and it just felt a bit better two me.

The story is a bit of a rehash of the original. They could have come up with something more original. Also, the second movie seemed to fizzle out a bit compared to the first half. I would have liked to see some more Mary Poppins coolness and magic, like we saw in the first half of the movie, instead of, mostly, conventional stuff. Also the take down of the bad guy was a bit underwhelming.

Apart from that I think sequel was not bad at all.

The nostalgia in this movie is legit. Emily Blunt somehow managed to perfectly capture the mystique of the enigmatic Mrs Mary Poppins, she ain't no Julie Andrews, but she came damn close and did Julie justice. Her singing voice is pretty good, though I'd be lying if I said I wasn't missing Julie Andrews' higher octaves. Mary Poppins knows how to make an entrance, and Emily's version made quite a spectacular one. Keeping in tradition with the original film, this film wonderfully blends CGI, live-action and 2D animation in one seamless go, proving that Disney's still got the chops to do a proper 2D animation, it was their bread and butter after all. The story is refreshing yet familiar enough for fans of the original to spot the similarities, though it's more of a nostalgia trip. The music was wonderful, though it doesn't come close the original songs, some of which were name-dropped in the movie, but that doesn't detract from the entertainment value of the film. Dick Van Dyke's cameo was hilarious and Angela Lansbury (Mrs Potts from Beauty and the Beast) was a wonderful sight to see at 93. Not that the film really needed  a cameo by Julie Andrews herself, but that was the one thing the movie was sorely missing. It's difficult to sum up the movie in just one word, but there is one particular word that sums it up practically perfect in every way. As Mary Poppins said herself, it's a word you say when you don't know what to say: It's Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.

Awful movie. Mary Poppins returns could have been a brilliant movie, but shot for shot it is a budget copy of the original. Songs are not memorable, Emily blunt voice throughout the movie is too stern all the way through, no melody in her voice like Julie Andrews .

My favorite song was probably Turning Turtle by Meryl Streep. Top notch movie. You should definitely see it.

Derivative from its predecessor and having the misfortune of being the sequel to one of the most beloved Disney movies of all time, Mary Poppins Returns is still a fun sequel thanks to some catchy new songs, good performances with Emily Blunt being a suitable replacement, for lack of a better word, for Julie Andrews as she inherits the personality traits of her counterpart but still has enough changes for Blunt Poppins to have her own identity, amazing production design and dance choreography - "Trip a Little Light Fantastic" is no "Step in Time" but make do with what you have" and sweet nostalgic tone. Mary Poppins Returns may not be supercalifragilisticexpialidocious but it still serves as a lovely return to the world for those who grew up with the first film whilst successfully managing to introduce the character to a younger generation.
Very cute Emily blunt is brilliant in this movie.  Carries the same vibe as the original

Mary Poppins Returns film seems to be a kind of a musical film. So, it's a little difficult for me to review because I'm not that much fan of those kinds of films.

First of all, Emily Blunt as Mary Poppins surprised me. Although I've saw just on film which she was in (film name is The Girl On the Train), I didn't think that she could fit the role. But amazingly, she could. She did a great job, especially the dancing scenes which I don't like that much but those scenes are amazing.

The makeup is so good. Emily Blunt is so beautiful, like I could fall in love with her. (Just kidding. I was just saying how beautiful she was in the movie.)

The costume is also cool too. I bet the costume designer put a lot of effort to it. I love that they chose the old times rather than the current era. (You know what I mean. I love the English's old times because the costumes are so cool.) I totally love their outfits.

The acting is also good, especially, Ben Whishaw. I couldn't even recognise him because of his moustache. When he started to talk, I could recognise him. At that time, I was like oh, it's Ben Whishaw. LOL.

Everything is perfect in the film. The location, the settings and all, but there are two things I don't like. One is maybe because I'm not that much into original score, I don't like the songs. Those songs they sang made me annoyed. Every time they started to sing, I wished those scenes needed to over soon, so that I could continue to watch.

The other thing I don't like is the film is full of dancing scenes. It's like an Indian film where a lot of people are coming out of where the audiences don't know where they are coming out, out of the blue. I kind of don't like those kinds of films.

To summarise, the story is so simple but maybe the director is good, it didn't make me bored. I watched this last night before going to bed. At that time, I had semi-heavy eyes, but I didn't feel sleepy or fall asleep. I could watch it from beginning to end. Some scenes are funny and some scenes are sad, plus some songs made sad more and more. You will feel some emotions and at the same time, it will make you feel warm to see how Mary Poppins take care of children. So, it's a film that is good to enjoy with family. It's totally worth spending time with.

Wanted to see this for Emily Blunt. The cast is spectacular. Unfortunately, this is an unnecessary sequel. The Cover is Not The Book is a great tune, but there aren't any songs like Feed The Birds. It is a fun, enjoyable film.

PROS: It was a fun family movie. A family overcomes the loss of a wife/mother and the impending loss of their childhood home with the help of Mary Poppins and some Lamp Lighters. The movie presents moral, inancial, social and parenting situations that are resolved through diligence, wisdom and sincerity. The bowl was a nice tough. CONS: Mary Poppins comes across as condescending, insulting and arrogant. Most of the songs were complex, fast and not memorable. We had no Supercalifragilisticexpialadocious (sp?) or A Spoon Full Of Sugar hits. They abused the penguins some. Mary Poppins abases herself by lifting her knickers and singing about Birthday Suits.

(Mauro Lanari)

This sequel didn't have anything to say, but I am completely fine with it (excellently) reiterating the original's central message: that we've forgotten what it likes to be a child again. Marshall, in my opinion, has actually done a pretty good job with the direction in ensuring that it felt very much familiar, yet was still different. And of course this is coupled by amazingly catchy songs from Marc Shaiman and Scott Whitman (I mean how could people be saying the songs are not memorable when there's "Can You Imagine That?" For crying out loud people you've forgotten your inner child!) and a stunning Emily Blunt (who I personally preferred over Julie Andrews) with a joyful Lin-Manuel Miranda, being, well himself (I'm not complaining). Even the kids are great too, leaving a movie that is in fact comparable to the original's magical spell. I cried during the "Place Where The Lost Things Go" and "Nowhere To Go But Up" scenes, and finding that kind of emotional connection is exactly why we watch films like this in the first place.

The new Mary Poppins is nothing like the old one. The old one was always polite and proper but very loving to the kids. She would not  encourage the kids to go in the adventures. The kids would beg and she would give in. 
The new Mary Poppins kind of sounds like her, but that is were the similarly ends. This Marry is not proper in the way she speaks and uses slang. The old Marry would always speak proper and would correct improper speech. The new one uses slang and does not hold the same standards. She does not show the children love and affection. She throws the kids into the situations. The movie in a hole is missing a lot of elements that the old one had. The beautiful worlds are no longer there the feeling is not the same. They added  characters that make no sense. The songs are lacking. The old Mary would look at the children when speaking to them with a smile. You could tell that she loved them. This one looks down at them and seems stuck up. Jack tries to hard to sound like the other loveable chimney sweep that we have all come to love. The people in this movie give off a vibe that they want to be famous or that they think they will be after this movie. The other one they were just so happy they were in it.

I wasn't a fan of the original, but I could see why people were.  This one was strange and pointless.  It was much darker and didn't seem to be ultimately going anywhere.  There were several subplots which not only had no point, they had no conclusion.  One such subplot involved a bowl which had belonged to the deceased mother, which seemed to exist for the sole purpose of introducing a role for Meryl Streep to play (who was brilliant, as usual) and disappeared completely once she did her bit without conclusion.  The children from the original were now grown up with kids, yet the chimney sweep, who now lights and extinguishes street lamps, is the same age.  It must be 20 years later at least, but he hasn't aged a day.  The original was about teaching the parents a lesson about valuing time with their kids and all the sub plots were ancillary, but to that point.  In this one the overall plot seemed to be about not losing the house.  It was painfully obvious when the boy found the paper they needed and stuck it in his pocket and there was literally no connection whatsoever to any of the subplots.  This movie was very typical of the current Hollywood trend to rehash old ideas and try to make them new, but without actually adding anything.  The writing was lazy, nothing more than taking anything and everything from the original that people loved and sticking it together.  The entire purpose of the plot seemed to be nothing more than to glue together all the things people loved about the original without actually adding anything.

I am a fan of the original PL Travers books, and also a fan of the original Disney movie (not the same character really)  In the books, Mary Poppins is a rather plain, strict, rather cruel nanny, who introduces the children to all kinds of strange people and events, then refuses to acknowledge they happened at all or that the people were in the least strange.  I have always suspected Travers was trying to warn kids that hella things are going to happen to them in life, things for which there are no good explanations or reasons, and that they better learn how to deal with that now.  (As her life was filled with such events as distant and suicidal mothers, alcoholic and tubercular fathers and early parent death)  The Disney movie softened Mary Poppins and prettied her up, while still giving her the magical abilities and a sort of loving but totally English and no nonsense nanny.

So my idea of Mary Poppins has always been somewhere between these two idealizations of her.  When she returns in this new Disney movie, I almost started crying.  I was surprised at how much I guess I had needed her to return.  So I was ready to love this movie.


Only, I didn't.  The original Disney version had real in depth characters, whose actions were motivated by the needs and desires OF those characters.  The father, Mr Banks, wants to provide a stable and disciplined household to his family, full of British patriarchy of the era.  His idea of a what a proper British home should be informs his actions AND his songs.  The rest of the characters are the same, from Bert to the children, all only sing or say what you can actually see their characters singing or saying,  There are no superfluous songs or dialogue in the original, and the story line is one flowing arc from beginning to end.

In this new version, however, characters are just thrown in for good measure.  They are not necessary for the plot, and are pale imitation copies of the original.  Jack the lamplighter is just a pale imitation of Bert the chimney sweep, Ellen the maid has no backstory or real need to be in the story, etc. etc. And the adventures Poppins takes the new children on (they are the children of the original Michael Banks) have no real fit into the story line.  It is a disjointed mess.

In the original books, the places Poppins takes the kids, always have some fit into what is going on in their lives and they play out fully in the stories.  Same with the original movie.  But in this new telling, Poppins takes the children on several adventures that just seem to be a chance for a bit of song and dance.  The "let's take a bath" scene is like this.  I think about 3 of these scenes could have been cut from the movie without loss of story at all.

The movie is lovely to look at, but most of the songs are truly forgettable.  The one exception I think will be "The place where the lost things go".  This is a lovely, grief filled lullaby, and those with a bit of age on them will certainly be moved to tears with the thoughts of those lost to them over the years, and the idea of seeing them in dreams and memory.

The movie is chock full of talent, and everyone does their best here.  Meryl Streep is truly delightful as Poppins cousin, and it is great to see Dick Van Dyke dance again.  

However, the movie just rehashes basically the same story line from the first movie (father is too preoccupied and doesn't pay enough attention to his own children, Poppins comes to help set things right by turning everything upside down, the kids get lost, Bert, er, Jack helps them find their way home, evil bankers want to take things from this family and the father finally sees the light and everybody goes to fly a kite, er balloons.

C'mon Disney.  You have lost what Walt knew.  The source material is better than this, you don't need to remake the first one to have a good movie or a hit, and characters still matter in good storytelling.  You can't just wow us with a bunch of disjointed songs and expect us to be sold or pleased.

So I merely just "liked" this movie okay or so-so.  And I feel that next time I see Poppins fly back into my life, I probably won't cry ...I will be bracing myself that the movie is any good.  Shame on you Disney for doing that.

Talk about a bad return. Not sure where to start. First I just felt like it was a pale imitation of the original. Talking about the actors. The kids were really good. The actress who played Jane I liked as well I could see traits of child Jane in her at times but Michael was ridiculous. They kept nothing from the child he was and the way they just made him look (visually and in character) like an updated version of his father was just a shame. Now to the two mains. First Jack. Again can't remember the name of the actor. Way too posh and smart for the role he was playing. As a lamplighter he would have been poor. We know he's been working since he's a kid so probably hardly went to school at all so the way he spoke was totally out of character. Plus he was clean all the time. That just wasn't realistic. What made Bert so fantastic was that he was so "one of the lads" he fit in to his environment. This guy sticks out. As for MP/Blunt she has some good moments but most, specially when she is talking are just overplayed. Julie Andrews was naturally poised and somewhat well spoken and sophisticated. Her MP was natural, easy. It was just her with a bit of acting. With blunt you could feel that this was not natural for her. I did watch until the end but I found it quite hard. Mary Poppins Returns (3 out of 5 stars). Mary Poppins Returns with a lot more magical musical performances that will try to bring out the children in all of us. Trying to make the audience go on a journey of what it feels like to be young again. Emily Blunt was brilliant as Mary Poppins and was the perfect choice for the character. The plot follows Michael Banks (Ben Whishaw) who is a struggling widowed father of three kids. He is about to lose his childhood home to the bank. And when he is struggling to find the share certificate for the house. And afraid he cannot handle every responsibility. Mary Poppins (Emily Blunt) shows up to help and take care of his kids. With Jack (Lin-Manuel Miranda) a lamplighter who accompanies Mary Poppins. They will take the kids into a magical journey to help find the share certificate and to help their father Michael save their home. The film does have several fun magical musical sequences with the original music making an appearance. Although, I did feel like a few of the musical sequences were quite forgettable. With the musical songs being similar to the other. There was nothing new or a fresh energy but being repetitive. There are some musical scenes that travel into an animated world which is fun and interesting to see. But the film does struggle in bringing something fresh throughout. Lin-Manuel Miranda was good. Ben Whishaw was good as well but spent most of his on screen performance worried and in a hurry. Emily Mortimer was okay but underused. Julie Walters makes a fun appearance. Dick Van Dyke returns as well and was good. Colin Firth playing the villain role of a banker who wants Mr. Banks house desperately. And does not care that he is a struggling father. Meryl Streep was good too but her role was brief for only one musical sequence. Overall, Mary Poppins Returns is a fair fantasy musical film. The plot is cute and charming about Mary Poppins and the kids trying to help the father save the house. But for its long running time and several repetitive musical sequences. It did not have that fresh progression with the music.

The big dance with the lamp lighters was in no way as intense as the chimney sweeps "steppin time".  Manuel is very talented but in no way is he as talented as Dick Van Dyke.  The back ground dancers had a hard time keeping up with Dick but Manuel had a hard time keeping up with the background dancers.  In that little cameo at the end Van Dyke out dances Manuel at 97. I didn't feel Emily Blunt has the same love for Mary Poppins that Julie Andrews did.  I felt like Emily was just baby sitting while Julie taught the kids lessons in life. I felt we were proded by forced songs and forced pulled heart strings through out the movie.  The biggest joke was the forced ending trying to recreate the feeling of "Let's go fly a kite" with ballons with Angela Lansbury as the singing magical balloon lady in the 
park.  That was the worse. I guess she was suppose to be the old pigeon lady and now she gives out balloons.  
I remember as a kid after seeing Mary Poppins for the first time coming out singing the songs.  As an adult I came out of Poppins Returns and I can't remember one song. It was nice to see the animation I just wish the script and the love for Poppins was in the film.

the more i think about this awful movie, the angrier i become. This incredibly boring movie comes off like a vegas tribute to mary poppins, but without the rights to to the original music. i was excited to see emily blunt in this, but her take on mary was completely wrong. i haven't read the books, and i don't care how accurate it might be. julie andrews worked because of her hilarious, wonderful characterization of a stern but deeply loving nanny. blunt has no humor; in fact, she acts vain, haughty, pissy, and a bit too much above the other characters and situations. the one tender song about love and loss is thrown away with no set up whatsoever; no word of the children missing their mom, and therefore no payoff. the lampwick guy simply has no character at all; just a smiley dull accomplice. but hardly that, as mary poppins winds up doing everything for everyone, after she pretends she can't. the songs are an insult to the sherman brothers, shoving their melodies into a blender and spitting out soulless soundalikes we hear in every meta-musical on broadway today. no wonder julie andrews refused to take part, the script is a dog and it would have sullied her wonderful memory. a chase scene? really? with an unmotivated kidnapping? almost every scene has a direct analog to the original, yet reworked with so little imagination as to make you certain it was done by committee. so much talent, so much effort, so much money involved in this load of tripe, it's a shame. but hey, that's hollywood.

I don't remember much about the original Mary Poppins from the 60s, aside from a few of the legendary songs and Julies Andrew's stellar performance as the quirky nanny. The sequel, produced 54 years later, does so little to distinguish itself from the original that I don't know why they didn't just set out to do a straight-up remake. Emily Blunt is as great as ever, but the acting by the children is poor, and Lin-Manuel Miranda, an actor I haven't seen a lot of, seems to be saddled with the role of 'Character who pops up now and then solely to extend the runtime.' I really wanted to enjoy the songs and the dance numbers, but they always felt like they were going on forever. The scene with the street light dancing in the park feels especially pointless. Also, I found the logic of the movie to be fatally flawed and inconsistent. Mary Poppins can turn a bathtub into an elaborate underwater world and fly down from the sky but not fix a cracked bowl. Also, in the first movie Poppins came to help the children because they were somewhat mischevious, but here she appears to take care of kids who are reasonably well behaved, and the issue here is that their house is going to be repossessed. The film then proceeds to gloss over this issue rather than addressing it, and takes every chance to demonise the father for being stressed about their impending homelessness. I got annoyed at how the film constantly treated the Dad like the bad guy, and how Mary Poppins never seemed to use her powers to truly help him. I'm not even sure if her inclusion in the film affected the final outcome. I don't know if I just misread the message, but I had a hard time properly getting into the story. To me it was certainly bright and glossy, but there seemed to be a striking lack of heart lurking beneath the surface.

There's nothing wrong with the story it may not be that original but few things are these days.. We really liked Mary Poppins Returns and would recommend it.

Disney's 60s beloved classic - stolen from its dumbstruck creator, who was then vilified by the thief - gets an update for a new generation. "Magic is real" it suggests ("we NEVER said that," wink, wink "pish posh!"), just as the first one did, with plenty of Brit music hall style numbers stomping throughout, and hidden bits of sneaky mementos liberally sprinkled for the Boomers who saw it the first time around to secretly find. Only this time, given modern times, Poppins curiously spends a great deal of time in the mirror. The tradition continues then if traditions are simply that which we do more than once, setting the stage, as it were, for more to come. Rousing.

I've known all those first Mary Poppins songs by heart for decades. You you want me to break into song?  Well, maybe not right now.I didn't expect to be charmed, intrigued, and awestruck by various elements of this newest incarnation.  

For one thing, who can take the place of Julie Andrews? No one, but Emily Blunt occupied her own space with dignity, whimsy, and a magical capacity to befriend fantasy.   A different Mary, but one Ms.Travers could probably relate to.  

How is it I didn't know Lin Manuel-Miranda was in the movie? Even without his beard, it took me a quarter hour to due the necessary mental surgery to separate him from Hamilton. But like Hamilton, he immersed himself in the role, thankfully with less of an American cockney brogue than Dick Van Dyke spouted back in the day. Lin's accent had a lovely softened but still Londonish lilt. 

So, this new film made bows to the original, with Meryl Streep standing in hilariously for Uncle Albert. He laughed and floated while her house turned topsy turvy.  The leeries rode bikes, lit and doused lamps, and generally illuminated their environment, even as the chimney sweeps had cleaned soot so people could warm themselves in safety.  All of these were welcome, somewhat familiar encores, though with a different tune. 

And speaking of tunes, I am wondering if I've become too old to learn all the songs by heart, particularly the one about loss and the other about books. As a teacher, I may adopt that last as an anthem.

Silliness! Silliness! Silliness!
Pure comedy! Disney classic gold!
Loved the musical numbers, especially the song and dance performances of Trip A Little Light Fantastic and also The Cover Is Not The Book. I also enjoyed the soft echos of old Mary Poppins tunes, playing throughout the film, at just the right times. This Mary Poppins was a little different, but she actually had me laughing much more than the original nanny did.
From the moment Mary Poppins scolded the kids: "Sit up straight. You're not flour bags!"  I knew this nanny could not be taken seriously. The twins were trying not to topple off a ladder straddled over the back of a bicycle. What made me laugh even harder was when John tried to follow her instruction; on the back of a wobbly bicycle, tries his best to sit up straight enough for her, as if there is a pole running through his back.

The bike will fall, and take John with it, but at least his posture was perfect.

And I could swear that Michael's missing stock certificate floated right across Mary's line of sight, right before she reminded the children that "cleaning is not a spectator sport", and then distracted them with chores; (and not fun chores, like snapping fingers and dancing while the room cleans itself).

Perhaps I'd see this all differently if I stood on my head.
All I need is a different perspective.

But from the upright position of my theater seat, this is what I noticed:
1) In the first scene, grown Michael is visited by a pair of wolves who inform him that he is about to lose his house. Grown Jane helps Michael search for his stock certificate, so he can pay off the house loan.

2) Michael and Jane were minutes away from finding the lost stock certificate when they were interrupted by wild tales from the children about their bath-time adventures, courtesy of Magical Mary. Somehow, the stock certificate makes it's way into a trash box.
Who put it there?
The Practically Perfect Mary Poppins did.
Then it's on it's way out the door with Georgie.
Who told him to throw it out?
Practically Perfect Mary Poppins.

But Georgie is sentimentally attached to the drawing from his father which includes his mother. So he keeps it, instead. However, he also chops it to bits to use the stock certificate to patch up his kite.
Who instructs him to do this?
The Practically Perfect Mary Poppins.

3) The kids break their mother's "priceless" bowl by fighting over it.
Who was supposed to watch them?
Practically Perfect Mary Poppins.

4) Georgie gets kidnapped when the wolf swipes his stuffed toy "Gilly" away from him.
Who told Georgie to even bring that toy along?
None other than Practically Perfect Mary Poppins. (So she IS friends with the wolf!)

5) The kids then lose their mother's priceless bowl to Mary's cousin: Topsy Turvy.
But not to worry: Topsy has assured the children that the bowl is worthless. Mary also forewarned the children that this bowl might just wander off to meet their deceased mother, who is hidden "Where the Lost Things Go".

6) Grown Michael comes racing down the stairs at home, late for work, his briefcase in his hands.
Who takes the briefcase away from him?
The Practically Perfect Mary Poppins did.

Mary hands off the briefcase to the maid, and then gives Michael a hat and umbrella; 2 things he really does not need, and opens the door for him, saying; "Out you go." Only after Michael is gone does the maid suddenly realize she is still holding his briefcase, to which Mary offers to stop by the bank to deliver it to Michael.

7) When the kids come tearing down the stairs at the bank, later, their father, Michael, yells at them.
He demands that Mary "Take them straight home at once!"
And Mary replies; "Yes, sir. Right away."
However, Mary does NOT do this.

Instead, Mary trails along behind the wandering kids, who are worrying aloud over how much trouble they are in. When they get lost, Mary decides to brighten up the night and entertain the kids, which makes the kids forget the awful things they learned about at the bank. By the time Mary is "speaking leery", the kids have completely forgotten about the wolf at the bank. The kids relay all their troubles, to the leeries, except the most pressing problem.

The rhyming, singing, dancing, playing with fire, lasts a long time, into the night, and it keeps the kids up way past their bedtime. They arrive REALLY late to get home, all drunk on "stuff and nonsense", which only causes their father to doubt their bank observations further.
----------
Mary does not continue this frustrating behavior throughout the whole movie, however.
She actually DOES pop into action, to help, at literally the 11th hour OF the 11th hour.
Nearly a split second before the big clock (Big Ben) strikes midnight, she flies on up and changes the time. However, she first had to wait and watch Jack nearly fall to his death, as that would have been entertaining for the kids. But when Jack did not fall, Mary decides to save the day, anyway.

Mary saves the day, but if she had never arrived at all, the Banks children, (all 5 of them), might have been just as well off without her, (only minus a few fun adventures).

In the original they went up to the ceiling due to laughter, in the remake the room turned upside down due to the day of the week.  There are multilple more.
