The cover was NOT the book folks. There is a reason I always see a movie more than once, before giving it a review. And I admit: that habit almost always raises it's final score, from me.
Mary Poppins is back! She has returned. Why?
Because nobody is hiring nannies anymore: she has no other place to go, and the Banks children are still sweet and trusting and naive but they are also both still just children. After all these years.
Jane is sweet but her job is that she is a volunteer labor organizer. She is not married, so no husband is picking up the pieces. No problem though: her father was a banker, so she'll be okay.
Michael is sweet but his job is as a part-time bank teller. His youngest son thought he was "a painter". Hardly enough to pay the bills for his 3 children and their old, senile live-in maid and cook. The kids must grow up faster than their father, and also they must rely on responsible practices taught to them by their deceased mother, such as buying day-old bread for a discount, in order to keep food on the table. Michael must stay in the home he grew up in, just to keep a roof over his children's heads.

My one gripe originally with this movie, and I almost downgraded severely for it, was the inclusion of Meryl Streep singing that godawful "Turtle" song. I could tolerate all other songs EXCEPT that one, and Streep really does not deserve a spot in a Disney film, at all. Plenty of better actresses out there, who would be thrilled with Disney. However, if they are going to include her, the role of some kind of gypsie huckster could not have been more fitting: Relieving the children of their mother's prized Royal Dalton china bowl, leaving young John with a concerned look on his face when Mary observes: "Oh good. It looks like things are starting to turn around for my cousin" just as the kids are leaving. Things are "turning around" bc they left their financially attuned mother's "priceless" bowl in her possession.

Mary may have arrived with the plan to wrestle the bowl away from the kids: She already knows their live-in maid on a first-name basis, she instructs John to help their maid when the maid has broken a look-alike bowl and then the maid mentions the items IN the house as all being "worth more" than anything she owns. It is that comment that inspires John to sell their mother's priceless bowl, which then gets broken by his siblings, who argue to keep it in it's place in the nursery. The movie ends, and that bowl never got returned to them; the last to have it was Topsy-Turvy - Mary Poppins's (Russian? Romani?) cousin.

So Mary is back! And Mary is a swindler?
Well, not so fast. She is still a "good guy". Because 1) Nobody is hiring nannies anymore, so she has nowhere else to go. 2) The Banks children are still children. If Mary had not arrived, Michael Banks would have lost his home through irresponsibility (he draws on everything, even stock certificates. Then he throws them out like scrap paper, which his youngest son swipes from the trash pile to patch up a kite. Even Jane does not see anything wrong with pulling glue-covered patches off a kite and trying to exchange it for the shares of money their father purchased for them.) Mary turns back the clock so that late-running Michael can save his house.
Mary even whispers a dishonesty into the ear of Mr. Dawes Junior: claiming not only that Michael Banks invested tuppence into his bank, as a boy, but that those tuppence have garnered enough interest to somehow be worth more today than 16 bucks. (I read another article that estimated that would be the total worth, with inflation included).
I might be remembering the original movie incorrectly, but I thought Michael just fed the birds with his money. However, if he DID invest 2 whole tuppence, then again, it does not speak well for Michael's salary if 16 dollars is "more than I make in a year!" This was his claim, when confronted about his bank loan. He needs to pay back about 16 dollars, to keep the house. And that would be if 50 years had passed, which the movie cast would indicate it was more like only 30 years from the original tuppence investment. Bank villain, William Wilkins, is correct: Mr. Dawes Junior IS "loony". He is far too old and senile to run the bank. Dawes does not remember what Michael did with his money, OR he does not know how much or how little such a tiny amount could grow in just a few decades.

However, Mary Poppins did as she promised: She looked after the Banks children, Jane and Michael. With Mary's help, Mary's organization, and with a little bit of Mary's dishonesty, the house was saved. The least the Banks family could do is pay her by handing over their "priceless" Royal Dalton china bowl, as her payment for a nanny job well-done.
Mary's self perception may be rose-colored, as she declares her reflection from her rosy balloon to be "practically perfect", but what she did for the Banks family, this second time, was even more perfect than the first time, despite the 1 tiny crack in the bowl. The only imperfection, from Mary, in the whole movie.

Let's talk about "Mary Poppins Returns." No spoilers, I promise. I went to see this movie again yesterday. Consider that I live and work in Death Valley National Park and that the closest theater to me is in Las Vegas, Nevada  --  2 hours and 15 minutes away. Also consider that the last time I saw a movie twice in a theater was in 2011 with "The Three Musketeers," and the time before that was in 2001 to see "Moulin Rouge."  (Ok, so about once every ten years I do this.) Also consider that I watch about 5 movies a week and I rarely, rarely see on more than once.

I was very motivated to see "Mary Poppins Returns" again and I'm glad I did, as it was just as magical and fantastic the second time around. The movie throws nod after nod at the original, but never imitates it. It follows the original nearly beat for beat, but always in a new and glorious way. This is a movie that kids, parents, and grandparents could all see together and enjoy equally. It is super clean, filled with short snippets of wisdom, and relentlessly joyful. And Emily Blunt plays the part of Mary Poppins perfectly!

I went in just hoping the movie would be okay, but for it to have been this good! It just blew me away! Reviews have been mixed, which I really can't understand. I'm even putting this above "Singin' in the Rain" as my favorite musical of all time! It's practically perfect in every way! Go see this in the theater! Support good, wholesome entertainment! Buy this movie when it comes out on DVD! It's the best feel-good movie I've seen in a long time.

I love the original, and I was not disappointed with this sequel. Emily Blount is fantastic as Mary Poppins-- just as good as Julie Andrews, and the children are better than the original children actors. While Lin Manuel Miranda is a fantastic writer, his Bert-replacement character was completely forgettable.

Mary Poppins Returns could have been better paced, the villain is overly cartoony, Lin-Manuel Miranda's Jack is more annoying than endearing and the soundtrack is ultimately much weaker than the original one, but still some songs are pretty good with the standout one being deservedly Oscar-nominated, beautiful The Place Where Lost Things Go. The costumes are superb as are the sets plus the hand-drawn animation brought a big smile to my face. It also has a plethora of very funny one-liners and a big heart. It's a flawed, but irresistible movie which felt like a 60s musical in style and I adored most of its scenes. And Emily Blunt as Mary Poppins is a revelation and a proof that she simply owned the year of 2018.
Pleasantly surprised. Wasnt a remake Thank god. Rather it was a continuation with a modern spin. Miss the Julie Andrews voice. However, great life lessons and superb acting.
Not perfect, but practically passable. Pretty much a beat for beat homage to the original.
Average.  Hard to life up to the original.

I did enjoy this one, the production design was great, the film was uplifting, I think I'm obessed with Emily Blunt, but I like the original better, and I never even grew up with the original.

Fabulous movie which has it's own character and is emotionally charged! It is not a copy of the original, but it carrots itself beautifully and is full of gorgeous pathos, laughter, joy and a whole new collection of songs. If you go along with the expectation of Julie Andrews as Mary Poppins, you will be disappointed, however Emily Blunt has her own special way of being Mary!
Definitely worth seeing in the cinema. You may find yourself spontaneously starting to applaud, too!

Having seen a lot of films new and old, across all genres, English-speaking and not, I like to consider myself a bit of a film buff, but here's one of my glaring (and shameful) oversights: I've never seen Mary Poppins. I know the basics of the plot and seen/heard enough clips over the years to understand most of the references in this belated sequel, but it doesn't actually matter. Filmmaker Rob Marshall has created a supercalifragilisticexpialidocious movie that stands on its own two feet. Backed by a decent budget, Marshall - a veteran of the big screen musical with Chicago, Nine and Into the Woods already on his CV - dishes up a plethora of splendid song and dance numbers that are catchy enough for kids and clever enough for adults. A deep-sea bathtub journey ("Can You Imagine That") and a foot-stomping side alley jaunt ("Trip a Little Light Fantastic") are delightful sequences, whilst the more sombre tune "The Place Where Lost Things Go" has unsurprisingly been nominated for an Oscar. It seems utterly redundant to even say this, but Emily Blunt is amazing as the enchantingly mischievous nanny. Her eyes twinkle as she throws out life lessons, often in the form of witty barbs, and her ability to hold a tune is impressive. Not everything is a home run: Lin-Manuel Miranda (playing the adult version of chimneysweep Jack from the original) isn't as charismatic as you would hope for the second-billed performer, a climactic cameo is admirable but strange, and the final song is a bit underwhelming. All in all though, Mary Poppins Returns is a joyous family experience that shines bright with the toe-tapping wonder of old-Hollywood musicals.
Slow, boring, too much singing. Lame songs. Depressing. We walked out  a third of the way through.
everything you could do wrong in a sequel, lifeless money grab.

I know this might be an unpopular opinion, but I really disliked this movie. While it does have its moments and a few of the new characters are charming, that's not enough to save it. Feeling an itch for nostalgia and being taken back to your childhood? Well, then this might be your cup of tea. Emily Blunt is the perfect person to revive Mary Poppins as she has the same sweet, partly authoritarian, smile of Julie Andrews. The director geniusly copied the style of the original movie of 1964 and some scenes could actually have been a part of the first flick. Once again one is taken into a child's fantasy world and even as an adult one can dip into this joy of falling into a world of carefree images. For me the part which is emerged into a cartoon world is by far the best and I wished there would have been more. Thus said one has to mention that the movie, with its 130 minutes, is way too long for children, and for adults, while enjoyable for some time to be reminded of one's own youth, becomes a bit too stretched after, in clear Disney tradition, way too many songs. 90 minutes should have been enough. 6/10 points.

Pretty much a re-run of the original film, but Emily Blunt is a poor substitute for Julie Andrews. Ben Whishaw is good as the harassed Mr Banks jnr and the dance sequences are ok, though the songs are very forgettable.

Hats off to Emily Blunt. To pull such a genuine, heartfelt performance out of that shell of a character in that mess of a movie takes a truly brilliant actress. Another shout out is to whomever cast the kids. There's such a wonderful authenticity about them. These are among the film's few redeeming qualities. Disney appears to have no imagination for drama in kids movies beyond "let's kill off the mother". We literally just saw it in The Nutcracker. Threat of losing the house is another cliche. Both are exploited and trivialized in the worst possible way. What little there is in terms of a story could be told in 10 minutes. Or less. The rest of the film is shamelessly padded by stretched out musical numbers some with little relevance to the "story". Parts of the scene in the bowl offered a glimpse of the whimsical quality that could have made the film work for me - what's a dream, what's really, what's magic, what's ingenuity. But no, the movie decided, magic is real, except when they needed some suspense and all of a sudden someone had to risk his life, only to have the problem solved by magic anyway. The only musical number that worked for me was the one with Meril Strip. It was funny, smart, relevant, and original. Hopefully all those big stars at least had fun making this film. Though Dick Van Dyke scene made me cringe. And poor Colin Firth was saddled with a thankless role of a boring, barely two dimensional (forget three) villain. Really, every character is barely two dimensional. So, I guess ultra talented Lin Manuel Miranda cannot be blamed for his one note performance. I hate to say it though, but his singing also sounded kind of one note to me.

It's an enjoyable movie, but nothing to write home about.

The only major flaw that I can find is a distinct lack of original ideas, but otherwise, I genuinely love this movie. There are very few movies that I see in theaters now that just make me indescribably happy, and December of 2018 delivered three in the forms of Spider-Verse, Bumblebee, and this one. The performances are all spectacular, especially Blunt and Miranda. Ben Whishaw also tugged at my heart stings with his melancholy solo number. The music can compete with the best of this decade's live action musicals, and the musical numbers are shot in a lot of creative ways, with the best choreography this side of Newsies. Yeah, this movie doesn't have a ton of original ideas, but that doesn't really matter to me. It just made me happy.

Mary poppins returns is the long awaited sequel to mary poppins. Most of the acting is good but there are a few characters whos acting is very much just okay. If I had to say who the weakest actors were Id say the children because a lot of the time they try to act like adults but ultimately fail. She trys to be the original but she doesnt come across as fun and likeable as the original. Good cinematography with some cool shots. Story bland and predictable. The comedy fails even thou theres not too many jokes. Good set design and practical props. Bad CGI that looks ugly and very fake. Bad green screen that doesn)t even take you into the world there trying to show you except the 2D scene which wasnt to bad and probably the best scene in the film. A few blunders here and there. Okay songs but a lot of the time the singers will try to hit a note but fail, and some of the lyrics are out of place or just trying to make the song longer, but the film was quite enjoyable and the younger audience will probably like it a lot more. Aspects of this film were entertaining and allowed me to suspend disbelief. And aspects failed at that. One of the biggest problems of ultra high-resolution film is that is makes suspending disbelief 10x harder. The effects and dancing have to be better then ever. And they just were not. The choreography of dance scenes was utterly pathetic compared to the old days of 2 angles and the best dancers on earth accomplishing breathtaking feats in 1 take. Now its a massive montage of camera angles changing so fast there is literally nothing great being accomplished to astonish your senses. It's like our only hope for skilled movement portrayal is in Chinese cinema these days. That and the amount pitch correction  in certain lead roles is utterly pathetic. Some of them were clearly good singers. Clearly identifiable by detectable pitch correction or lack thereof. That's my 2 cents. See it at home when its on Amazon. You might be able to suspend disbelief more easily. All that being said, if your kid is under 7, def go to the movie, they will probably love it.

Apart from this, itï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)s just a disjointed storyline, with dragging scenes that added zero to moving the story forward. A movie that no one was asking for has the impossible task of following a true classic. Disney doesn't totally blow it, but ultimately it doesn't do enough to stand on it's own or add to the original.

WHAT I LIKED:

- Visually beautiful. The Mary Poppins story told with 2018 special effects adds the perfect touch to make the fantasy scenes truly spectacular.
- The animated scene in the bowl was particularly well done using a great vintage animation-style you don't see often any more. I especially liked the hand-drawn style of the wardrobe in that scene.
- Emily Blunt is superb with impossible shoes to fill. But she is the perfect balance of serious and playful.
- The costumes and set design over-all were very well done. The movie was a visual treat the entire time.

WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE:

- These characters are all VERY quick to just accept Mary Poppins is here for apparently no reason. No one was trying to hire a nanny. The kids seem to have been very independent for quite some time. It's all rather random.
- Meryl Streep's scene was a complete waste-of-time, except to give her an excuse to be cartoonishly over-the-top.
- I didn't care about ANY of the songs! The best part of the original was the catchy songs burned in our brains. I couldn't name one song from the new one as I left the theater. Nothing to sing along to, no "Step In Time" or "Spoonful of Sugar." All I picture in my head is endless singing aboutâ¦ whatever. Just didn't stick. This is perhaps the biggest failure of the movie. Looked great but I just didn't connect with any of the songs. It's a musical following one of the most beloved family musicals of all time, and they made forgettable songs no one will remember. It is no surprise that none of the songs in this movie got nominated for any awards.
- The forced integration was a little blatant. I agree movie casts need to be more diverse. But this really felt like shoehorning in people of color in to 1930s England just to fill some kind of quota.
- Obsession with the bank and money was the opposite of the original. What happened to enjoy life? Now it's be smarter about your finances? And Mary Poppins didn't solve anything. She merely distracted the children from bothering their father from searching for a stock note. In the end, money falls from nowhere and we're done. Huh?
- The father, Michael, claimed to be an artist but they showed no interest in art or pursuing that as a career. How did he survive that long with three kids? Where is his art? Why does HE need to be reminded to enjoy life? He's already is living creatively according to him, but has to work in the bank part time. He doesn't quit his job in the end or become a better artist. Their problems just go away and all is well. Pointless.

Sequels to movies from 50 years ago are a dicey proposition that even the most cynical of studios balk at. Not so, for the House of Mouse, apparently. Of course, they have a better track record than most for "sticking the landing" with all their infinite resources and competent producers. While we certainly didn't need it and no one asked for it, Mary Poppins Returns does just that. We are treated to an airy and colorful excursion that contains a moral center and a message that is sorely missing from children's cinema these days. This follow-up takes place a couple of decades after the original classic. The Banks children are grown up and broke in the middle of the Great Depression and are about to lose their childhood home. Michael himself now has children and has need of a nanny (and moral guidance). Guess who shows up?

This sequel would live or die based upon the performance and casting of its recognizable character. Emily Blunt proves to be an excellent fit for the magical caregiver, albeit a tad bit more vain and prickly than the Julie Andrews version. Supposedly this was because Blunt opted to take it in direction more akin to the novel version originated by P.L. Travers. This is one of those broad PR statements that's hard to prove one way or another, and I suspect this defense was created in hindsight. Either way she kills it with the charm and sharp wit one would expect. (Btw Emily Blunt is actually REALLY good in the few action movies she's been in. I don't know why Hollywood has not made her action star.) The interplay she has with the children is quaint and you feel some of that old Disney magic in many of their fantastic interludes. It was nice to see hand-drawn animation for one of the more memorable sequences, though some of the CGI used in others was a bit...umm terrible. The musical numbers themselves are...decent but not exceptional or ones that you'll be singing years later. The famous songs from the original were scored and written by the Sherman Brothers, who were masters of their craft. There's simply no comparison between the two.

There are numerous supporting characters and a lot of cameos to be had. Lin Manuel-Miranda really shines and he fills in nicely for Dick Van Dyke. Emily Mortimer is quite lively and charming, while Ben Whishaw carries a lot of the dramatic work of the film. Meanwhile Colin Firth is a little TOO good as a slimy villain. Overall, Mary Poppins Returns is a fine family outing and has the right magic to pull off the impossible. That being said, WE DON'T NEED ANYMORE. This was FINE. In Russian Roulette you can get two clicks and survive. It doesn't mean you get THREE. And yeah that analogy was pretty dark for a review of a Disney movie. Don't lie. That's why you read my reviews.

I was flabbergasted to find this movie had such high reviews on rotten tomatoes. I'd heard from a friend that they basically just redid the scenes from the original movie. (And boy was she right). However, it's called "Mary Poppins Returns" so I was expecting them to use more original material from one of P.L. Traverse's many other Mary Poppins sequels.

There were so many good ones to choose from!

Mary Poppins Comes Back
Mary Poppins Opens the Door
Mary Poppins in the Park
The Gingerbread Shop
Mr. Wigg's Birthday Party
Mary Poppins From A-Z
Mary Poppins in the Kitchen
Mary Poppins in Cherry Tree Lane
Mary Poppins and the House Next Door
I've read the the first 4 books in the series and all of them are unique and special. The imagination is what sets The Mary Poppins series apart from other books. While Mary Poppins herself sees little character development, you get to see a different side of her in each story. I felt like this movie just rehashed all the qualities we already know about her...but not as well as the original!

Nevertheless I loved the original for what it was. You can't beat Julie Andrews as Mary Poppins. Then you have Dick Van Dyke. So much great musical talent packed into one movie. The movie doesn't capture the wistfulness of the books entirely, but they at least it captures the creativity and imagination of the original Mary Poppins book.

Then you have this movie. Which barely tries to be original or do anything new! Instead they take each scene from the movie and basically create a mediocre version of it.

There was no energy in this movie! Musicals require lots of paunch and pizazz and ENERGY. Where the heck was the enthusiasm? I felt like it just dragged on and on. The most energy in the entire movie was when 91-year-old Dick Van Dyke entered and busted out the snazziest little number of the entire film. Unfortunately, that magic lasted about 3 minutes then it was back to the lackluster performances of the rest of the cast.

It was like they tried to recreate the original movie which has that often cheesy/over-the-top Broadway quality to it. However, they failed to bring it over-the-top. There was no charisma to this movie. Musicals need charisma, energy, and expressiveness to pull off the sorts of cheesy lines they contain.

Also, WHY are Jane and Michael the adults in this one? They tried to fit them into the mother and father roles of the previous move and it didn't fit. The lines were awkward and were delivered awkwardly. The only one who did a decent job was the actress who played Mary Poppins. Everyone else was...wooden in their portrayals. I think this is mainly due to the fact that there's little conflict driving this movie. They try to mimic the old story, but they do it poorly. In my opinion, the creators should have scrapped trying to mimic the original movie and gone in a completely new direction.

All their attempts at recreating the magical, spectacularly colorful dance scenes fell flat. The music was a poor shadow of the original songs, and so unmemorable I literally can't remember any of them.

Then you have Linuel Miranda, he's a Broadway star, right? The only place he shone was in a scene where he was rap/singing a song. Otherwise, he just did not cut it as Bert's replacement.

Then you have these "lamplighters" or something whose job is to light streetlamps. I don't understand why the city needed so many of them. It's not like it's that tedious or difficult to turn a light on and off. Those chimney sweeps though, that was a hard job. Replacing them with these lamplighters seemed a little pathetic to me.

I simply don't know when was the last time I saw something so boring. What am I missing? What did everyone else see in this that I couldn't? THEY BUTCHERED MARY POPPINS for crying out loud. This is a crime against humanity. Honestly.

Disney needs to stop creating sequels. It just keeps getting worse, and goodness knows when it will end. What happened to think up something new? That's what Disney was known for. He took fairytales and turned them into something unique and new. Where is that creative spirit?
Fun and snappy! Exactly what I expected!! It doesn't have the same impact as the original (obviously) but still hit some heart strings as the movie went along! Go see it for yourself people!!

Anyone who knows me knows that I love the original Mary Poppins movie from 58 years ago. As this is the case, anyone can guess how excited I was to see this sequel for the first, which I totally was. It started off with an original music number, which made me super excited for the rest of the film. Unfortunately, however, as the film progressed, the more disappointed I became. The special effects were exactly what I expected for a Mary Poppins movie with roughly 60 years of improved technology: nothing short of amazing. There were two scenes that were the pinnacle of the disappointment. The main offense was the âcover is not the bookâ? scene. The song was not what I expected from a Mary Poppins film (although the Hamilton-style Lin Manuel Miranda solo was awesome) and it felt like they were making fun of the animated penguins (which were one of my favorite things about the original). On the other hand, I enjoyed the old-school-style animation of that scene. The other misfire was the Topsy number. It felt out of place and you canâ(TM)t ruin any character, let alone Mary Poppins, by telling everyone that that character has such a creepo for a cousin. That being said, the bank taking property is, in my opinion, an overused conflict, however I liked how the banker was actually evil, along with the Dick Van Dyke cameo. This brings me to my next point: Lin-Manuel Miranda, though I love his Hamilton and In the Heights productions, was no Bert-substitute. And the Michael actor didnâ(TM)t look like the kid in the original, but besides that, the casting was well done. Though Mary Poppins Returns was a bit underwhelming, it was still an enjoyable experienceâ"at the times that didnâ(TM)t fall flat.

About what I expected. Don't get me wrong this wasn't a bad movie, but it was lacking in a few places and I found the run time to be horrendous. This is a direct sequel to Mary Poppins (1964) and is set roughly 25 years after the events of the first film. Michael (Ben Whishaw) and Jane Banks (Emily Mortimor) are now grown up. Michael has three children Anabel (Pixie Davis), John (Nathanael Saleh) and Georgie (Joel Dawson). Michael lives with his three kids and Ellen (Julie Waters) their maid (who was also in the first film, but of course played by a different actress). Michael's wife passed away and since then he's turned away from making art and is now working as a teller. Jane is working toward bettering low income workers (much like her mother was helping out all the time in the first film). One day the bank comes by and tells Michael he's missed out on three months worth of payment for their house, so unless he can get the entire loan paid off in 5 days, or find proof of them owning shares of the bank...they will lose their house! Distraught from all of this in comes Mary Poppins (Emily Blunt). Mary arrives just in time to get the Banks children old and new back into shape and to help them realize whats most important. The children have grown up too quick and need a reminder on how to have fun and some other important life lessons. Along for the ride as well is a lamplighter worker named Jack (Lin-Manuel Miranda) who has a connection in a ways to the family. First the good. There are some very catchy songs to this one and even now I am humming them a bit. Are they as catchy or legendary as "Let's Fly a Kite" from the first film? No not really, but I overall enjoyed them. I really enjoyed Emily Blunt's performance. She jumped into the source material more and supposedly her version of Mary Poppins is much closer to the version that the books entail. She has a charm to her and really fits the roll well. I had no issue with her taking over from the great performance that Julie Andrews did in the original film. I still have two big gripes here. First off the movie runs much too long. I know its a musical, but man clocking in at 2 hours and 10 minutes is a bit of a stretch here for me (especially when it has a pretty simple plot). I found a lot of the scenes were rehashes from the original film (there's an animated section, a section where the lamplighters sing, a section where Mary's teaching a good manner or cleaning song, etc). There were 3 scenes in particular I thought could have been cut completely from the film and would have helped the pacing of the film (visiting Mary's cousin, the lamplighters songs and the balloon song at the end) all three of these went on way too long and don't even add much to the story (outside of the balloon song). I enjoy musicals and director Rob Marshall has made some really solid one's that I like including Chicago (2002) & Into The Woods (2014), but for this one I think he stretched it out a bit too far. I would have loved to see more background on Mary, but I get it that she's suppose to be mysterious and all. My only other gripe is the plot here is incredibly predictable and I just found myself kind of wondering when the movie would end about an hour in (much to my surprise I wasn't even half way done). It's very by the book and for the most part it just doesn't capture the charm of the former. It's close don't get me wrong, but this one would be a stretch for me to watch again because of the length of it and the fact that overall I didn't have as much fun with it as I thought I would have. If you're a mega fan of the original I would say check it out if you aren't I would say wait to rent it!

Unlike the original film which my daughter and I love to watch over and over again and will do in the future, I do not foresee watching this movie again, once was enough for me and here is why: 
Although the intention was to have a nice tribute sequel it was NO match to the original magic and message of the original film. The characters in 1964 film were much more believable in their emotions and expressions that one can relate to. The pace of this film however was much faster, louder, and a bit too smiley dramatic /exaggerated for my taste. The only characters that showed a little bit more authenticity was Jacks character and sister Jane. Nice to see Van Dyck, Angela Landsbury and the first and last songs were nice to watch, my daughter liked the ballon song out of all of them. Otherwise, the songs were un-memorable, we still would rather sing "Lets go Fly a Kite" "Stepping Time" and "Votes for Women". For this film, they should have taken a much more critical eye in toning down the Broadway feel that came across both forced and too sensational. The kids I really could not stand and made me think of Dick and Jane books for some reason. Cutting out a song number or two may have helped for starters. One element that really did not help the film and distracted viewers from the story line was the villainous animated characters or scene, it was an unnecessary twist hat did not go with the movies message or theme. This did not happen in the original film and any scary points in the original were more believable like when Jane and Michael encounter strangers and a dog when they are lost. I found the kidnapping animated scene to be a waste of time and just bad taste. If Walt was here I think there would be plenty of edits and better casting choices. I give some credit in the colorful costumes and animation and the way Mary Poppins entered with audiences to magical scenes like the bathtub and porcelain bowl were well executed. I wish Blunt had been a bit more approachable (as Mary Poppins Julie Andrews was) Blunt seemed  more sour in personality and should have aimed for the warmth that Andrews mastered together with the confidence and sassiness/ smarts that the Poppins character embodies.  For the villan of the movie, his balloon doesn't go up (I found that this could have been better thought out...yes he deserved it...but even the "mean bankers" of the original film, had a redemptive quality about them and in the end, event they enjoyed a kite flying experience. I hope Disney can be smarter to bring more authenticity and less showy or forced smiles or scenes in future films like this. I agree with the New York Times review on this and give it a 2 1/2 star.  In the end, thanks for the remake attempt but you could do a lot better story wise.

Reviewed 1.9.19  Emily Blunt does her best to fill Julie Andrew's very large shoes and succeeds by creating her own version of the beloved umbrella wielding genie.  But as the original excelled with the introduction of each beautifully crafted song, the sequel hits a flat note in the same regard.  

The magic is indeed back on Cherry Tree Lane, from the whimsical set pieces to the hand drawn animation (welcome back penguins!), yet with the exception of 'The Place Where Lost Things Go,' none of the new tunes rank alongside the eponymous canon.  And like the original, it runs too long.  

Yet I imagine that no adult that loved the original as a child is capable of providing a truly unbiased review.  It's simply too iconic.  But I imagine countless children will hold this new Mary equally close to their hearts.  As expressed in the closing scene, none of the jaded adults will remember her magic tomorrow anyway, but the open minds of the children will continue to believe.

As much as I loved Julie Andrews' Mary Poppins, Emily Blunt is the charm of this movie. She does a fantastic job as Mary. From the musical perspective to the acting. She's great in this movie. From the first time we see her as this character to the very last moment, she was excellent and made the movie better. She was her own Mary Poppins.

The directing is also good. The musical sequences are very well done and very well-choreographed. No surprise there coming from an Academy Award nominee. The cinematography is also beautiful. The movie has some beautiful shots.

The animation is outstanding. It really is. Words can't express how good it actually is. And the blending between live action and animation is really 'really' well made. It was my favorite aspect of the movie.

The best thing I can say about the movie is that Mary Poppins Returns is its own movie. It's not trying to throw nods to the original, nor you needed to see the original to understand this one. It's a sequel that stands on its own. And although, there are some few nods, but it doesn't rely on them and feed you of nostalgia. 
The "villain" was meh. He didn't have that much screen time, and from the first moment I saw his character introduced I had a feeling he wasn't to trust, and well, he wasn't. 
Most of the characters I thought were necessary for the film because they had a purpose in it. There's a character named Anabel, which I thought had no purpose in the film. She's the sister of Michael. And her scenes had no impact on the story.

Overall, A movie that can speak to everyone who grew up with the original but also mark the lives of this generation that will grow up with this movie.

Mary Poppins Returns is a charming musical filled to the brim with imagination and whimsy. It is quite entertaining and Emily Blunt is very good as the magical, manners-focused nanny.

The storyline follows the title character as she returns to the Banksï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) family home, decades later. Siblings Michael and Jane Banks are grown up. Michael, with kids of his own and mourning the loss of his wife, is about to lose the home that they have lived in since they were children. Poppins descends from the London sky, ready to help the Banksï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) family with their plight and teach Michaelï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s kids to use their imaginations and improve their manners. The bank has given Michael a few days to pay off his house, setting off a countdown for Poppins, the Banks and a lamplighter named Jack to save the home.

The story is interesting. Michael Banks has hit rock bottom. His wife has tragically passed away and heï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s about to lose the home he has lived in since childhood. The only thing that brings him joy is the comfort and company of his family. Itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s a sad place to start, but it's a great scenario for Mary Poppins to come to work her magic. The idea of losing your home is pretty realistic and the contrast with such a fantastical protagonist and situation, provides an aspect that I quite enjoyed. 

Emily Blunt is very good as Mary Poppins. She puts her own twist on the character, yet you can still trace it back to the earlier onscreen depiction of Poppins. Blunt gives the character a sharper, comedic edge. Her Poppins is much more witty and sarcastic, but still gives a sense of compassion and care for those around her. Blunt really dives into the role and cements her portrayal in a charismatic way. She steals the show in nearly every scene.

I recommend Mary Poppins Returns for ages 5 to 18, due to some dark themes. Adults and fans of the original Mary Poppins will enjoy this film. I give it 3.5 out of 5 stars. The film has lots of charm and itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s great to see Poppins sail back onto the screen once again.

Mary Poppins Returns carries a fairly simple message about perspective. You're never too old to rediscover the innocence of childhood and the optimism that brings. There's nowhere to go but up. Some 25 years after Mary Poppins appears to help the Banks children she returns as Michael and Jane struggle to keep their old family home from being repossessed. Michael's three children come under Mary Poppins' care and she begins to weave her (very real) magic in their lives. Emily Blunt is excellent as Mary Poppins, she owns the role, but I thought she was upstaged by leerie Jack (Lin-Manuel Miranda) who has such charisma on screen. Speaking of upstaged, Meryl Streep has a scene stealer and there are a couple of nice cameos. The film mixes animation and live action very well, in the style of the original. I did think it was a bit too long and while the songs are largely good, some better than others, they aren't memorable like those in the original. Overall it's pretty good wholesome fun.

Enter with reasonable expectations. Although a sequel, this would be fruitless trying to compare it to the beloved 1964 classic. Be that as it may, it stands as a perfectly enchanting fantasy on its own right. Pays homage to the original while managing to spin enough magic with this cast and narrative. Emily Blunt offers a take on Mary that differs from the warmth and charm of Andrews, but that is hardly a distraction as it hews closer to the character as presented in the original novels (which is supposedly the launching pad for this film). Magnificent visuals and solid direction make this Rob Marshall's finest work to date. The most frequent and most superfluous of the criticisms seems to be that the songs were forgettable and couldn't hold a candle to the original tunes. What these experts don't realize is that music is highly complex of patterns where familiarity breeds likability. The original Sherman score has had 54 years to burrow itself into the ear of pop culture - obviously, songs you just heard can't hold a candle to that simply by virtue of longevity. Time will be the judge on these new tunes. And, these geniuses who claim there's "too much singing" or songs that don't add to the story clearly shouldn't be critiquing musicals. Bit parts from Meryl Streep, the legendary Dick Van Dyke, and the charming Angela Lansbury make this a delightful entry in Disney's live-action cannon with enough heart and poignant sentiment to please age 8 through 80.

Acclaimed musical director Rob Marshall employs his "Into The Woods" collaborator Emily Blunt to revisit a classic. Somehow the resulting product, "Mary Poppins Returns," ends up simultaneously being one of the most unnecessary and uninspired sequels I've ever seen, yet still a watchable one. A film where its circumstances and central conceits are ultimately more dire than its predecessor's, there's almost nothing about its musical aspects that's worthy of screentime. The musical numbers only serve to distract the main characters from the central conflict of the film. Mary Poppins as a character is borderline inconsequential to the course of events and the songs themselves are almost entirely unremarkable. Still, as someone who's not necessarily a "Poppins" purist, it doesn't bother me all that much. It's just a harmless, silly, disposable junk food film. Don't expect much more than that.

Also, the world of Mary Poppins seems to belong to an age of the past (with the manual street lighting and all that), yet racism was not a problem for anyone, not even the evil bank director, who had hired a black lawyer to visit white people's homes with eviction notices. Good thing the black dude was  the only decent human being among the evil team, too. Oh, and one of the main characters was a social activist for workers rights aganst evil capitalism. Maybe it was just me, but I found all this distracting and spoon-feed. It is not that in a Mary Poppins kind film I am expecting to see a portrayal of racism, but shoehorning social justic in a film isnt either my cup of tea. Also, I found Mary Poppins to be unlikeable, unlike the original one.  The film seems fond of having the characters struggling against situations, only to reveal their struggles are for naught, because the end result would have been the same anyway. So Mary Poppins manipulates the Big Ben and there was no need to climb  it and finding the certificate was useless, because the old director would have step in all the same to save the day. Talk about pointless.

So many movies these days are unoriginal and uninspiring.  In fact it is often the case that Hollywood seems to prefer a movie be produced that is part of a formula.  Well this time they put down the recent formulas and decided to try one that used to work decades ago, the musical.  There have been many good musicals in history, it seems that many think only animated ones will sell, these days.  No so, as Mary Poppins Returns proves.  The sets are simple and in fact reminiscent of from the original movie.  And because of this simplicity, it would be easy to adopt this to the theater as well.  I will admit the songs aren't as "catchy" as many of the originals, but that may be because of how many times I've seen the original.  The singing was wonderful as was the choreography.  The scene where the lamplighters were dancing with their ladders and bicycles was great.

I applaud Disney for not remaking Mary Poppins, but rather making a sequel.  I think I might have resented a reboot.  As this movie deals with the children of the children from the first movie, it allows it to tie in nicely, yet not be ruined by our nostalgia filter from the original.  

When Mary first arrives, Jane Banks asks, "What brings you here after all this time?"  To which, Mary Poppins replies, "The same thing that brought me the first time, I've come to look after the the Bank's children."  Annabel asks, "Us?"  Mary states,  "Oh yes, you too."  Yes, once again, Mary Poppins is here to save a family from the father, Michael Banks, the original bank's son down to his children all of whom have lost wife, mother, and in general their way.

This movie is a must see for children and for anyone who loves musicals in general.  It's a return to cinematic innocence that should not remain lost.  It pushes no agenda or political messages either.  Well done, Disney.
Emily Blunt shines in an enjoyable and faithful return to the Banks family, but forgettable characters and songs accompanied by poor pacing makes for a mediocre film.

Mary Poppins returns hits all the right notes. Beautifully cast and acted. It pulls new story elements right from the source material by PL Travers. It immerses us back in a carefully constructed familiar world. It is orchestrated beautifully drawing from the original movie's famous melodies as incredible underscoring at all the right moments, reminding us of the story we fell in love with and endearing us to this new adventure.  So thankful for this experience.

It was a really well done, very magical and really entertaining Disney live-action/animated family musical fantasy movie. It had really incredible special effects, really well done traditional animation, really great cinematography, really fantastic music, really great characters, really enjoyable cast, really good humor, really fun adventure, really cool magic, really well done costumes and a great story. It was a really good continuation of the original movie. I really recommend this movie to both kids and adults.

Don't watch this movie if you have recently lost a parent/mother or wife as you will be left in tears several times throughout the movie starting nearly as soon as the movie starts. I say this speaking from personal experience as I recently lost my mother in the same time frame as the movie and each reference and song on the topic left both myself and my father in tears. 
Also the actor who plays Jack the gas lamp lighter has the worst fake cockney accent and thus everytime he sings or talks it starts to get on ones nerves. Also this movie is disappointing and a lot of the things that are referenced from the original movie are lost on those who haven't seen the original movie and therefore are unable to understand what each reference means such as when Mary Poppins refers to the sayings next to the heights of herself and the 2 children in the original movie and repeats them in the new movie it leaves one confused if you haven't watched the original movie. In addition little jokes based on her previous movie fall flat without the context or having watched the original movie. This movie did and still has a lot of work needed to be anywhere as good as the original movie, but it does have some fun songs and characters and is thus not a complete failure and the kids will probably have fun watching it but might not understand some of the outdated things like gas lamps that need turning off and on manually each day and night. I could go on further, but I think what I've said should be sufficient for one to understand why this movie could have been better.

When we went to see the original, we all came out of the cinema singing "Let's go Fly a Kite" or "Chim Chim Cheroo" or "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious". When we came out of the cinema after seeing the return, we all came out of the cinema singing "Let's go Fly a Kite" or "Chim Chim Cheroo" or "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious". It may be etched familiarity, but I can't help feeling despite the excellent performances of the cast, that the new songs were simply not catchy o'r memorable enough. Throwing in one or two of the classics might just have helped lift this that little bit further. Maybe they needed to watch the original one more time before making the final cut?

Also, since when does Mary Poppins snap into line with a "Yes Sir"?

Great Movie. Possibly the best Disneg has made since the 60s.  The cast, the music, the songs are all wonderful.  Emily Blunt is a worthy successor to Julie Andrew's and Lin Manuel Miranda was made for musicals. He never once loses his look of pure joy.  More movies like this please.

I'd call this more of a solid "Mary Poppins-flavored" movie. The original happens to be one of my favorite Disney movies of all time, so I am biased when I say that nothing could surpass the original. 

Cons: going with the above thesis, Emily Blunt doesn't have quite the sweet charm as Dame Julie had, showing more of an edge to her mischievous nature. Yet, she is not as tightly wound, it seems, as the original. If you want to call it a "con," this movie basically takes the plot structure of the original movie and plugs in different situations and re-adjusted scenes (compared to the original). But plug-and-play, to me, is not necessarily a bad thing.

Pros: I like Mary Poppins, plain and simple. This movie satisfied that appetite for such a movie. It doesn't have the same level of charm as the original, but it is charming in its own right. The music has Richard Sherman's fingerprints all over it - and I find it all the strongest suit of the movie. Marc Shaiman said he didn't want to ape the style of the original. He didn't, but he (and Sherman) captured enough of the tone and style of the old songs - with more of a PG-level sensibility to a couple of them (like my favorite of the movie "A Cover is not the Book.") And with that said, I can't say enough of how much I really like watching Lin-Manuel Miranda. He did a workable job as Jack, bad accent and all. And my favorite song even had a bit of Vaudeville-patter-meets-a-touch-of-Hamilton in the middle of it. Some may not enjoy that, but I found it a pleasant surprise. 

Not the best movie, certainly not the worst. Given what it is, it's practically perfect in almost every way. I'll definitely be owning this and adding it to my Blu-Ray of the original. I would like to see it again before it leaves the AMC, and I may end up raising the rating on it.

Making a sequel to a beloved film is never an easy task. Especially when you decide that it’s the right time after a staggering 54 years. Mary Poppins is a timeless classic, and it was a very brave move by Disney to do a sequel and they’ve somehow managed to pull it off, well, just about. Emily Blunt is delivers a fine performance as the magical nanny and it must have been a horrendously daunting task to try and fill the shoes of Julie Andrews. Ultimately though she’s doesn’t have that warmth and wonderment that Andrews projected in every scene, and that’s not a fault of Blunt, it’s just the fact that Julie Andrews has that “something else” that magical indescribable quality which made millions of people fall in love with her. The plot sees Mary Poppins again coming to the aid of the Banks children, the story ties nicely to the original and there are some well choreographed sequences, which include a great Big Ben set climax. Productions values are exemplary and everything looks wonderful and magically. However the major issue I had with it is that 90% of the songs are completely forgettable right from the first song. Intact I’d go as far as to say there’s only 1 decent song in it and that’s right at the end, which is staggering considering that this is a Disney musical. With better songs I think people would have warned to this even more. By the end of it I just wanted to watch the original and I think that’ll be the case for most people.

I went to see this with my wife to make her happy thinking I would be a bit bored but it completely exceeded my expectations on every level. Disney is just ridiculously on fire and has been on fire for a long time. I can’t remember any entity maintaining this level of genius for this long. Casting was perfect. Emily Blunt nailed it. It truly made you feel like a kid again at times and absolutely had that Disney Magic. Great acting, great music, amazing sets, cinematography, cameos, great life messages, beautiful art direction and on and on. Another Home Run by the wizards at Disney.

There was much to enjoy and reminisce in the film.  I felt like I left the theater a little let down.   So much of the sequel was a reminder of the original, but it dd not stand out much in it's own right.  I thought Emily Blunt was fine, with a little less charm than Andrews, but a lack of strong songs (in a musical) failed to develop the other characters or the story.  It was just okay and a nice try but I don't think it was be remembered much except to be shared with children after seeing the original
This movie is just fine. If you're into this genre you'll like it a lot, if you're not, you'll hate it.

For the musical fans.  Many years have passed since Mary Poppins first visited.  The children she once nurtured are now adults with children of their own.  They've stumbled upon some hard times, and much like the Room of Requirement, she reappears because she is needed.  Now I don't have all that much attachment for the original, only the foggiest of recollections of having watched it when I was a very small child, but I still thought that the trailers to this looked terrific, so this made my list of most hotly anticipated movies for year end.  When Christmas finally rolled around and this got released, I had to go check it out at my earliest opportunity.  I did not leave the theater a disappointed man.  Now the most noteworthy thing I have to say about this movie is that it stirred nostalgia within me that I didn't even know existed.  To be perfectly frank, I don't have any memory of the original other than the lyrics and pitter-patter of the most iconic musical numbers, so I loved the fact that this made me realize I was actually missing this character.  Emily Blunt is absolutely the standout in this movie, and she is fantastic.  You can tell that she wanted to be in this role with a passion, and whenever she is onscreen, she commands your attention, and rightfully so.  It is undoubtedly her movie, as her name is in the title, but I do wish she was in it just a bit more.  Her presence is felt for the first two thirds of the film, but she has far less to do when all of the plot threads are being tied up.  This is a musical that is special because it leaves you believing that anything is possible.  It does capture that wonder and spectacle, which is why so many of us go to the movies.  I can't really recall any specific lyrics to songs, which is really the telltale sign between type A and type B of musicals, but I do distinctly remember number with a balloons, or the number with the street lamps, or the number in the bathtub.  To really push it over to that next level, this would need to have something that you walk away singing, or at the very least humming.  Still, if musicals are your thing, I think that you should check this out in a theater, as it will do nothing but brighten your day.
An entertaining movie, but I greatly preferred the original.  This was like Disney on steroids, very frenzied - maybe to appeal more to modern day young viewers.

Mary Poppins Returns is a great example of a modern retelling. While it does not have that great a legacy and number of preceding films to be compared against, it still followed all the exact same story beats and elements as the original film. However Mary Poppins Returns does it better and being much more enjoyable. The hand drawn animation is always welcomed in today's world of CG. Some of the musical numbers are really top notch. And Emily Blunt's new take on Mary Poppins shows she is a very capable actress for the role. I say this film remains faithful and true to the spirit of that classic original Mary Poppins.

I was apprehensive when they said they would make a new Companion movie for the class Julie Andrews film. Choosing Emily Blunt put my mind at ease but I still was worried that it might be too difficult to be faithful to the brilliance of the 1964 epic.

The opening song from Lin-Manuel had beautiful lyrics and the score hinted at 'The Life I Lead' and every song after that had a sneaky dalliance at a melody line from one of the older songs. A wonderful performance by Angela Lansbury was reminiscent of 'Fly a Kite'. 

although some moments seems random, such as the appearance that Meryl Streep gave which slightly detracted from the story as her character had no impact on the storyline other than she was going to possibly fix a royal doulton bowl.

That aside, Meryl's song was comedic and linked back to the scene in the Julie Andrews version where they kept laughing so much that they were flying around the house of a randon jolly man ('I love to laugh').

Emily can sing, act and hold an audience's interest with ease. Her charisma is similar but not the same as Julie Andrews. Julie was more about the singing whereas Emily's is about the harshness of the nanny, as told in the P L Travers books that inspired Walt's imagination when he read them with his daughter Diane. Emily holds this role well and has cheeky moments which show her chatacter's real personality.

Lin-Manuel Miranda is amazing and does a much better accent than Dick Van Dyke ever had. It is lovely to see Julie Walters as the housekeeper and the grown up Jane and Michael Banks are very credible played by Ben Wishaw and Emily Mortimer. As a fan of the P.L. Travers Mary Poppins books, I was anxious to see this sequel. Knowing that Travers intensely disliked the first movie and the "pop" score, I wondered how director Rob Marshall would approach the movie.  Marshall is a brilliant Broadway director and his filmed version of Chicago reflected his theater aesthetic.  You could feel his expert touch in every aspect of Mary Poppins. First of all, the cast is perfection.  Emily Blunt was an inspired choice -- she is perfect as Poppins.  I have seen Miranda in both his roles on Broadway and he is excellent here in an entirely new dimension for his repertoire.  Ok, maybe the Cockney accent is not his forte but his performance was pure and emotional and his musical numbers were nothing short of amazing. The score was lush and beautifully complex.  And the songs were the same -- complex with utterly clever lyrics.  As in the best of Broadway, the songs emerged from plot and character.  The team resisted the urge to throw in the catchy pop songs that Travers resented.  ;And they were far more moving than the beautiful little trifles that we can all sing from the original.  For the most part, they land in your heart.  They may not all  be "sing a long" songs for children but that is also true in the best Broadway shows.  Listening to the album, I was struck again by the music in this film -- they are literally uplifting even the ballad.  There is a reason two of these songs have been short listed for the Oscars.  Overall you leave this movie with your spirit uplifted  There seems to be the DNA of joy incorporated in most every scene. 
I saw this movie with my husband and we loved it so much we went back so we could take some children and we loved it even more seeing it through their eyes.

A truly sweet homage to the original film, Emily Blunt embues Mary with both the same smart confidence and wit, but also a little touch of sadness that wasn't apparent in the original Andrews version. The children are sweet, the cell animated scenes are a true delight, and the villainous turn from Colin Firth was a strange change of pace. Overall it will leave you smiling (especially scenes like A Cover is Not the Book and Trip a Little Light Fantastic). The cameo from Streep was fun, but would have been just as enjoyable from a less famous face, but the real standout cameo comes from the balloon lady at the end. A fun romp for kids and parents alike, with some great nods to the original.

Mary Poppins Returns is a overstuffed musical romp, that tries to emulate the originals magic touch, but falls far short by providing a bunch of cringe-worthy set-pieces that never feel like any fun for the viewer, especially for children. Uninspiring and malice, which even the brilliant Emily Blunt will not be able to make up for, even though she tries hard to.

Expected to hate it, rather enjoyed it, and will be humming for days.
New Cast, Familiar Characters, and a  New Adventure, definitely worth a watch for a family or child at heart.

The best part about Mary Poppins was the casting of Emily Blunt. She embodied the spirit of Mary Poppins in every line, song, and dance. Although I did not feel the movie itself lived up to all the hype. Was it a good movie for a family or children to go see? Sure. Was it as good or better than the original? No. I don't remember a single song or line from this movie and to me that is a sign of it being just 'ok'.

Those who have criticized this movie have not read or do not remember P.L. Travers’ books. I was delighted to find three of my favorite chapters, “Bad Wednesday,” “Topsy Turvey,” and “Balloons and Balloons” adapted in this charming movie. There were numerous other references to the books throughout the movie, not the least of which were the children’s names and appearances, the latter of which are taken from the books’ illustrations of Jane and Michael. And while I believe that both Julie Andrews and Emily Blunt are both “practically perfect in every way,” the latter actress’ Mary Poppins is actually closer to Travers’ heroine. I remember thinking as a child that Mary Poppins was a lot meaner than Andrews’ portrayal! My hope is that other families get as much enjoyment from both these magical movies that I did, and that “Mary Poppins Returns” inspires children to read Travers’ wonderful books!
Loved this movie, made me smile the whole time. Brought back memories of watching the original and the magic that is Mary Poppins.

Spoilers: The moral of the story, money fixes everything. It's an entire reboot. I'd have hoped they'd give some small nod to the original mother and father in imagery, yet that didn't happen. The mother of the new children passed away and we don't know exactly when or why, but the story isn't about that or healing that loss. It's about them being in a predicament caused by the father wanting to be an artist and running out of money so he mortgages the house. In doing so he puts their place of living in danger and the movie is all worry with Mary being a pacifier, but not offering to be a fix, to the children as we forget about the lost mother and focus on how to find a stock certificate that would pay to fix the problem. The villain being a banker that for "reasons" tore out the page with the recored of the stock and tossed it in his fire place throws me, as they could have easily said his family had a beef with the Banks or that the bank needed every house it could get as the depression was putting a squeeze on money... but no... they just decided he was going to rip out a page and toss it in the fire, no motivation given, villain created. In the end, the moral is the diametrically apposed opposite of the original movie, and michael learns that love is not the answer, feeding birds with your tuppens is stupid when you need every cent you've got to hold on to your home. Had they lost the house and shown the family happy in a smaller apartment perhaps, that would have been a heartwarming classic Disney Scenario. In this, it was the house has to be saved so they can all be happy. And it was. Moral of the story: Money fixes everything

From start to finish, there is no Disney "magic" in this film. I was expecting that wonderful, emotional, roller coaster ride that takes one on a fantastic journey for a few hours, and instead it was more like a catastrophic train wreck. The theater was jam-packed, but throughout the movie, the audience was noticably quiet. No "ooh's or ahh's", laughter, not even a giggle.    
The character of Mary Poppins was not "spot on"', which is critical to the believability of her return as herself.  The original Mary Poppins was a firm nanny, but she was also witty, charming, and lovable. When she returns, she is not the happy, imaginative, fun-loving Mary we are expecting. Mary (Emily Blunt) is unlikeable, arrogant, snotty, conceited, and appears to be annoyed all the  time. This is the biggest flaw in the movie. When Mary returns, if the timeline we're correct, it would be in the late 1930's or early 40's, but they are still wearing clothing from the 1900's, except for Jane, who wears trousers in some scenes. Go figure! Even more confusing, were the "adventures" of Mary and the three children.  It was like a bad, hallucinogenic trip through a "mish mash" of old Disney movies, from Alice in Wonderland to Peter Pan! The music was forgettable; although I can vaguely recall one song because it was so out of place. It had a psuedo rap beat, and Mary even used the word "boombastic", (perhaps she saying "bombastic", but it sure sounded like "boombastic") The real Mary Poppins would have put her in the naughty chair! 
For me, this movie was not entertaining or enjoyable, and if you're looking for a "feel-good", fun, family movie, don't waste your money on this one.
Rough to watch. Lin's British accent is forced and annoying. Blunt's version of Poppins is off-putting and annoying. Not an enjoyable movie. Not recommended.

I was genuinely looking forward to this film,  with directing by Rob Marshall, and starring Emily Blunt and Lin-Manuel Miranda ; I was excited to see this. Mary Poppins is a film that I grew up on, like a lot of people grew up with this film, with the whimsical songs and the strong message about family and to never take things for granted. I had hopes that its sequel was going to leave a lasting impression. 

However, where I was hoping that its sequel would charm me, it left me rather bored. I left the theater and couldn't recall the name of a single song. The magic of the first film is sorely lacking from this one.  Emily Blunt; while a good actress in the right role, was simply miscast; I think anyone who isn't Julie Andrews would be miscast. Most of the other actors, especially the children, were humdrum at best. You can definitely see that they are trying and putting l lot of effort, but mostly it fell flat; even Meryl Streep felt out of place and I wished for her scene to quickly end.  It was lovely, however, to see Dick Van Dyke and Angela Lansbury on screen, two giants of cinema were truly the only scenes I enjoyed out of this entire film.

But it is beautifully filmed and makes you feel good as you leave the theatre! 12/31/2018

When I was first found out that Mary Poppins was getting a sequel, I was not alone in feeling skeptical. After all, recreating the magic of the first film, including brilliant performances from such legends as Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke, seems like an impossible feat. Still, I was eager to see what Rob Marshall and Disney would do with the sequel to the beloved first movie. Add in the fact that Lin-Manuel Miranda, one of my favorite humans ever, played a prominent role in the movie, and I was really pumped to see it. I can now say, without a doubt, that I was not disappointed in the slightest. The music was spectacular, the set designs were stunning, and the performances by Emily Blunt and Lin Manuel-Miranda did not disappoint. While it is fair to say that Blunt did not quite match Julie Andrews' stellar performance, I have to ask: who could? Blunt was spectacular in her own way and fully captured the magic one expects from a Mary Poppins movie. The songs in the movie were also great, my personal favorite being "A Cover is Not the Book" with singing by both Blunt and Miranda. Musical films hold a special place in my heart, with movies such as "The Greatest Showman" and "La La Land" frequenting on my Spotify playlist. After seeing Mary Poppins Returns, I have no doubt that it too will make an appearance on my playlist at some point. Overall, Mary Poppins Returns is fun, creative, and brings the magic from the first film into the film world of the 21st century, while maintaining its family-friendly nature.
A slightly darker Mary Poppins than Julie Andrews and music isn’t as memorable, but still an enjoyable film.
Best movie musical i've ever seen. Outstanding, Oscar-worthy performances. My new personal favorite movie. Go see it!
A lot better the first...
It felt what a Disney should be, giving the magic and the possibility of fun. Brings back my childhood.

Loved it. Emily Blunt is a joy to watch, and clearly had fun with the role. Wonderful visuals and musical direction, and a much more coherent plot that the original! Only gripe - the songs/melodies aren't quite as 'ear worm' y as the in the original, but maybe time will tell...
A rip roaring success in my eyes. 100% absolute must see. Incredible.
Started this family movie excursion skeptical, but by the time it was over I found that I very very much enjoyed the movie. Kids loved it and I just felt good after watching.

Although I thought the movie was enjoyable, it certainly doesn't live up to the original classic. Emily Blunt is no Julie Andrews and much of the musical routines seemed to be trying to hard to mimic ones from the original movie. It was a joy to see Dick Van Dyke's song and dance number towards the end though and that may have been worth the price of admission all on its own.

I felt is was entertaining, fun and of high quality.  The characters and acting was solid.  There where hints and nods to the 1964 version but not so much that it took away from the modern story.  I didn't feel you had to watch the original to get this version.

Phenomenal new movie musical by Disney.
From beginning to end I was hooked and had tears welling in my eyes throughout. I will say I have a soft spot for Mary Poppins and Saving Mr Banks. I love both movies dearly and need to go back and see Mary Poppins Returns a second time. 

It feels just like the orginal and I'll explain why in a second. First let me get a few critiscims I've seen out of the way.

1. The music is still good and has not changed from a theory or compostion stand point.
2.  Meryl Streep waa awful. Easily the only part lf the movie I would have skipped. Just like i dont like the nanny song in the original. 
3. Manuel won't have a good english accent becuase he ain't bloody english mate! Dick Van Dyke isn't a Brit either. His accent is just as bad. Only  Brits will have a true accent and tone.

Okay so logistically you're seeing the same movie as the first but this time she's there to save Michael and his family instead of the late Mr. Banks. 

There is a silly song, a cartoon segment, a lullaby,  a sad song or two, a moving piece a  big swing number, etc. It's all there. It follows similar arc and then the big finish with the happy go lucky tune.

Besides Meryl Streep song and attrocious Russian accent it's a perfect musical in every way. Emily Blunt may be the only person who could nail this role. She deserves best actress in a lead role here.

Music for this was writtent by a composer who knows musicals and boy does it pay off. He even had the old Richard Sherman on as a consultant from the orginal music that he wrote. So all those saying it's all trash are just full of it. And okay Manuel has a spoken word poem in one song. He wrote Hamilton everyone. He's going to have wrap a song in anything he does so get over it. Plus many of the songs follow similar thematic patterns and even hint at the originals with certain chord changes, meter and plain direct notes from the melodies. All together very tasteful and memorable. Not every song has to be memorable but I loved Can You Imagine That which is a reworking and homage to Spoon Full of Sugar. I also loved the Leary's song Trip little Light Fantastic and the main theme, the lovely London Sky. The ending song and Lullaby in the middle were also catching and great.

Angela Lansbury and Dick Van Dyke had great cameos that added to the wonderment,  not saved it.  Believe me the movie would still be moving without them but they defintiely helped ice the cake.

Go see it and go enjoy it!  Have fun  with it!  Don't analyze every last detail. Remember when alls done, there's no where to go but up!
Timing is everything. Actors were good. Filmography was good. But the timing and tempo turned it into a test of endurance - and I like musicals! This movie was just self indulgent and long.
Great film. So much fun to watch!!!

Mary Poppins Returns Due Out December 25

Initial Reaction: Returns from what?

Main Cast
	Mary Poppins: The magical woman with the suitcase.  Sheâ(TM)s played by Emily Blunt.
	
Plot Summary
	The Baker family is having trouble with their finances.  Theyâ(TM)ve fallen behind in their payments and are about to lose their house.
	This distresses their three kids a lot â" but help is on the way via Mary Poppins.  She shows up and agrees to be the nanny for the kids.
	But theyâ(TM)ve got to hurry.  If they donâ(TM)t find a way to pay off their debt by the end of the day Friday, then theyâ(TM)ll lose their house.

SCORING
Main Characters
	Mary Poppins is a lot like she was in the last two movies sheâ(TM)s been in, but I donâ(TM)t mind.  She really bring out the best in everybody.
	But sometimes I think she works on luck more than skill.  SCORE:  8

Supporting Cast
	The rest of the cast is fine.  I like the kids because theyâ(TM)re more behaved than the kids in the other films.
	But the main bad guy just feels â" overused.  When he appears on screen, most people will know who he is â" and why he does what he does.  SCORE: 7

Plot
	This movie is a musical, not a drama or adventure tale.  And as a musical, I think it works because the songs are fun to listen to and the dancing sequences are inventive.

Violence Factor

Mary's return is super cute and very different than the original. In a lot of ways, it is the same, the mix between animation and real life, with the addition of new and updated songs. The cameo by Dick Van Dyke brought applause when he appears on screen. Angela Lansbury can still bring the vocals, if you close your eyes when she sings you can see Mrs. Potts from Beauty and The Beast. Many reviews appear to be centered on the idea that Mary Poppins Returns is a reboot, rather than a continuation based on the other books in the Mary Poppins series by author P. L. Travers. However, this is most certainly not a rewrite or retake of the original Mary Poppins flick, which was itself a mismatch of more than one of the books by Travers.

The issues with the movie are down to a lack of coherency in the direction rather than the script or the musical performances. Mary Poppins was created as a musical, and Mary Poppins Returns is no different. The main difference in the quality of the two when compared with each other, is the direction. In the first Mary Poppins film, it was directed in the manner of a Hollywood movie. Mary Poppins Returns appears to be directed as if it is a stage show, with classic Hollywood production value.

The production quality of Mary Poppins Returns makes it a visual tour-de-force. The lighting, color palate, and costumery are woven into a stunning presentation second to none in the current holiday box office run. 

Emily Blunt simply shines as the Practically Perfect Poppins, and clearly did not seek to imitate Julie Andrews portrayal, while Lin-Manuel Miranda also shone in his role of Jack. The two had good chemistry throughout and their voices could not have complimented each other any better. The only change I would have liked to see as far as their performances are concerned, would be that the character Jack should have overly-accentuated the bad cockney accent as Dick Van Doik had done in the first Mary Poppins movie. 

Speaking of Dick Van Dyke, it was an absolute pleasure to see him reprise his role from the first film. He has said that when he was on set he very much felt the spirit of the first film, so the myriad of professional critics claiming that their childhood has been somehow sullied by the "reboot" that's actually simply a sequel, should remove their fingers from their keyboards and log-off since the most qualified person in the room, Van Dyke himself, closed that door.

There have been concerns made regarding the "Trip a Little Light Fantastic" and LSD/Timothy Leary connection, which  is pure fiction. Tripping the light fantastic was a turn-of-last-century phrase referring to dancing on stage, and as early as 1908 it was already considered passe'. In addition to this, "leerie" was a word of Scots origin in the 1800's and meant the pole used to light a gas lamp; something many a reviewer failed to discover. Leeries was a term subsequently used for those who's job entailed lighting and snuffing gas street lights while also performing their duty as watchmen.

Mary Poppins Returns is entertaining, the main characters of Poppins and Jack entertaining, the hand-drawn animation sequences lucious and vibrant, and the attention to production second to none.

The only criticism should be levied toward the direction. What could have been a thoroughly seamless film, was hampered by a poor Director. Even with this being said, the flaws are not fatal, but they do hamper Mary Poppins Returns from achieving the same greatness as the first. Sequels are notoriously likely to never as good as the first, but there was a real possibility here that was squandered by the Director.

Emily Blunt delivers a sensational performance in "Mary Poppins Returns", a marvelous musical that demands to be seen. Rob Marshall's latest film is a nostalgic, old-fashioned musical that pays homage to the 1964 original. Packed with plenty of colorful characters, unforgettable musical numbers and terrific performances from a talented cast, it is one of those musicals that works on nearly every level. The entire cast is at the top of its game, but the film belongs to Emily Blunt. Charming, charismatic and utterly unforgettable, she manages to do justice to the iconic role. Although undeniably well-made, "Mary Poppins Returns" suffers from a lengthy running time. At over two hours, it is slightly long and drags towards the end. Nevertheless, fans of musicals will definitely enjoy it and so will movie-goers seeking fun entertainment this holiday season. They don't make musicals like this anymore, but on those rare occasions that they do its a cause for celebration.
