A little disappointed and I don't quite know why.  I love the original Mary Poppins pretty much in its entirety.  Emily Blunt was delightful at Mary Poppins.  Emily Mortimer brought her sweet energy as grown-up Jane, Lin Manuel Miranda was fun as Jack (definitely a nod to Burt but nobody tops Dick VanDyke). Perhaps it was just darker in general than the the original.  Certainly a mother's death is harder subject matter than the threatened loss of a job which was actually a wake up call in the original.  I actually liked the story line of Mary Poppins Returns better but the musical numbers were just not as engaging.  I think the music was darker, instead of a laughing uncle as in the original, MPR features a very strange cousin.  The leary number was darker and less engaging than the chimney sweep number, even the animated world singing number was darker.  The casting was brilliant, the music was performed well but the only standout number to me was "The Place Where Lost Things Go".  The rest of the music felt pretty forgettable.  If this hadn't recalled the original, I don't know that I would have enjoyed it nearly as much.

I was initially both skeptical and disinterested in seeing this, thinking it would never live up to the original. I went to see it as a spur of the moment sort of thing, and I have to say I was delightfully mistaken.

The film lived up perfectly to the original, not surpassing nor dragging behind. It has the same magic and enchanting immersion, and is a feel-good ride with some welcome tension in between. The plot doesn't feel pointless and has some meaning that connects it to the original. 

The characters really sell it, each actor performing their parts perfectly. Mary Poppins is as magical and mysterious as always. Jack does a wonderful job as a sort of successor to Bert the chimney sweep. The new Banks children are amazing, feeling both mature enough to connect to older audiences while simultaneously being innocent enough to connect with a younger audience as well as everything in between. The old Banks kids, all grown up, feel perfectly placed in this world and are a convincing next step from the originals. There are a few surprise returning characters, but I'd rather just say go watch it to find out who those are.

The music is absolutely fantastic as well. The musical scenes are just as wonderful as the original film, if not more so. The choreography is simply magical and a downright treat.

TL;DR: Overall, I am surprised by the amazing performance, and for once I am glad I was so horribly wrong to doubt this film. I highly recommend it, to both those who saw and loved the original and those who have never experienced it before. You won't regret it.

In Mary Poppins returns we see a grown Jane and Michael banks working to save their childhood home. The plot is similar to the first, flushed out with new characters and endearing songs that nod to those of the first movie. The best way I could put it is instead of Kites there are Balloons, instead of chimney sweeps there are Lamp Lighters. And yet, while a practically perfect copy in every way, it falls short of its predecessor all because of the ending. Through Mary Poppins adventures with the children we are given some opportunities for continuity, an important note torn up in the fire, a broken vase that takes up a considerable amount of time. Some of the songs explore deeper problems, âA Cover Is Not the Book being an excellent example! However while the first movie explored real world problems like poverty, addiction, classism, no such depth is ever attained. Meanwhile Jane and Michael are working to secure access to their fathers bank trust, the central plot of the entire story. As the climax approaches one wonders how all these little clues will work together untilâ¦ it happens. The characters are not successful in fulfilling the plot. To save the day a charming cameo of Dick Van Dyke introduces Deus Ex Machina that in less than 30 seconds of screen time rips all of the previous movie to shreds. What we are left with is the realization that none of the tension up to that point was legitimate. I took personal disappointment that said Deus Ex Machina took the form of Michaels saved toppins, so much for âFeeding the Birdsâ?. However, an extremely critical flaw that cannot be overlooked, Mary Poppins effectively has no effect on the plot. Her character might as well be cut out of the story and it would do nothing. What happened to the vase? The letter? Why was she here at all? If the ending could be recut I fully believe this would be a fantastic movie, it truly is a lesson in the power of a single point of failure.

Many people believe movies from years ago don't seem to age well, but I've never bought into that notion. Personally, if it doesn't hold up in terms of today's standards, then it simply deserves to be called a product of its time. Mary Poppins has become that for me. I love watching the original film, but even I have to admit that being released over 50 years ago is a bit of a stretch when you hope something holds up. In the early days of visual effects, it truly shot for the stars, and for its time, there is no denying that. I had high hopes for this 2018 sequel in Mary Poppins Returns, due to the fact that movies have endless possibilities in terms of visual effects nowadays. In short, this is a movie well-worth making, but I don't quite think it will be among everyone's favourites of the year or anything like that.

Picking up many years after the original, Mary Poppins Returns sees the return of the classic (titular) character as she once again arrives to serve the Banks children. Now fully grown with children of their own, Michael has been taking care of his kids with his sister Jane after the passing of his wife. Arriving just on time to relieve some stress from Michael, Mary Poppins becomes the new nanny to these children, taking them on fantastically fun adventures. Filled with great musical numbers and cameos that would brighten anyone's day, this is a late sequel that definitely deserved the spotlight. That being said, this movie isn't perfect in my eyes.

Disney films have begun forming this new formula that seems to string across many of their franchises lately. I'm not saying I dislike this, but the similarities are a little too familiar, to me at least. The original cast has grown up and the film is passing the baton to the newer generation. That's definitely one way of continuing your franchise, but that can't be done again decades from now, because it'll probably just feel tired. I could be wrong about that (which I have been many times), but that's just how I see it. Where this movie undeniably steals everyone's hearts is in its cast and overall atmosphere. With a few casting changes, this movie could've been a disaster, but not this time.

To start, I've always been a fan of Emily Blunt as an actress. I think she has tremendous talent and I was ready to call her one of the best of 2018 when I watched A Quiet Place at the beginning of the year, but that opinion has slightly altered. Mary Poppins Returns is the film that she's been destined to be cast in. Many people said that nobody could touch Julie Andrews, and while I wouldn't say her performance is better, it seems as though Julie Andrews came back through time and performed this character again. Emily Blunt is a true wonder on-screen here. From the incredible sequences involving Lin-Manuel Miranda to emotional moments involving Ben Whishaw and Emily Mortimer, everything about this film was impeccably cast. For that reason alone, I enjoyed this movie from start to finish.

In the end, Marry Poppins Returns may not feature as many memorable songs and some may even seem like slight rehashes of the previous ones, but it's great for all ages to experience. From life lessons involving death in the family to just pure silliness in the land of cartoons, this movie provides everything that kids should be experiencing, all at once. If you're a fan of the original film or simply want to smile at the theatre, I definitely recommend checking out Mary Poppins Returns. This very late sequel was worth the wait. I don't believe it will be remembered as a classic in 20 years from now, but that shouldn't deter you for a second.

In the interest of full disclosure, I was skeptical about this one and wasn't particularly looking forward to seeing it. I must admit, however, that I enjoyed it more than I was expecting, especially since remaking classics or creating sequels to them is very risky business (and something that often makes me cringe). This offering does justice to the original by not ruining its legacy, thanks to the excellent production values, fine performances and an enjoyable soundtrack that, unlike so many contemporary musicals, isn't totally forgettable. Emily Blunt pays perfect homage to the legendary character and is worthy of whatever acclaim that comes her way, and kudos are definitely due a fine cast of supporting players. The film is, unfortunately, somewhat episodic, using the narrative between musical numbers mostly as a bridge to link the songs to one another. Otherwise, though, this is a capably made and surprisingly delightful release.

This movie had a lot to live up with it being a sequel to a beloved classic. While I've seen the original movie on repeat as a child - it never had that massive impact on me like everyone else, but with each re-watch I found more enjoyment and appreciation for everything that went into it.

So this being a sequel made me curious and wary; I went into this expecting nothing to avoid any disappointment. I sat down, arms crossed and waited patiently for the trailers to be over. When it started, the first 10 or 20 minutes was fine, but I was still critical. After the first musical number "Can You Imagine That?", I started to warm up a bit and relax more.

However, halfway through the movie I noticed something about myself - there was tears streaming down my cheeks, and for a rare moment, I breathed a sigh of relief and enjoyed the ride. This is the first time in awhile I would call my experience escapism.

Emily Blunt was an absolute delight as Mary Poppins. Blunt never imitations Julie Andrews portrayal and makes the role her own. I honestly couldn't think of anyone else to fill in the shoes of the character than Blunt. Her sassy and deadpan wit makes this super nanny pure magic.

The other cast members were also solid: Lin-Manuel Miranda delivers a theatrical performance that elevates the films charm and brought a smile to my face. Ben Whishaw, on the other hand, was so heartbreaking as the grieving Michael Banks. You can feel the pain and stress in his voice. Emily Mortimer is good as Jane Banks , but felt under-use and didn't offer anything to the story.

Also Dick Van Dyke dance scene, while short, was unbelievable. He's got more energy than any wanna be dancer, and he's 93 years old.

Rob Marshall gives the movie a Broadway-like touch similar to his previous work. The musical sequences with songs like "Nowhere to Go But Up" and "Can You Imagine That?" being colorful and a blast to watch, which adds to the escapism. The production design and choreography - mwah. He also tackles the more serious elements where the emotions from the characters are expressed through songs and the performances.

For issues: The songs themselves while fun, yet not super memorable and doesn't hold a candle to the 1965 film. After the movie was over, the songs didn't stick with me as I hoped. This might change over time.

The main villain played by Colin Firth is so cliched and cartoonist. I started to question why a movie like this needs a bad-guy - although I guess the climax needed to be more intense. He's even got a twirling mustache. When the character first appears on screen, I knew straight away there was something unpleasant about him and the foreshadowing involving an animated sequence was so painfully obvious. His character could have be great if it was written better.

Meryl Streep short appearance is so pointless and could've easily been cut out from the final daft. I wasn't sure what accent she was going for.

Overall rating: It's not flawless, yet it wasn't an abomination like some expected it to be. I would go as far to call it a satisfying sequel.

Nostalgia is thick as London fog in this sequel 54 years later, though only 20 odd years have passed on-screen, with the grown up Banks children in the 1930s and, in the case of recently widowed Michael, struggling financially and emotionally with three children of his own. Good thing his youngest's kite caught on a magical nanny and brought Mary Poppins back just in time. Comparison to the unbeatable and iconic original is inevitable, though the advantage of brand recognition also means that there is a substantial locked in and critic-proof audience for this sequel. Blurring the line between remake and sequel, director and co-writer, Rob Marshall, who's very familiar with the genre, follows the original's formula and replicate it in fastidious detail. Everything from set design to casting is immaculately and calculatingly executed. The new tunes, as catchy and hummable as they are, all contain DNA traceable back to those beloved songs from 1964. And even the narrative follow the original's beat by beat, with the same animated fantasy detours (in a similar 2D Disney manner), and for every Uncle Albert before, there is a Cousin Topsy now. So while they all look spit-spot and shiny, they do lean towards the derivative (except for one innovative bathtime sequence which hints at what a more daring approach can produce). Emily Blunt has the biggest baggage to carry but despite a slightly frosty and smirky portrayal, her Poppins proves to be one we can all rally behind. In the end, these films have always been episodic adventures set to musical numbers hanging on the slimmest of narrative structures, and ultimately, nostalgia wins the day and it will take a stern hard-hearted cynic not to be grinning and humming like an enchanted infant after experiencing such a joyous film. Now, can you imagine that?

"Mary Poppins Returns," as a show, is less than the sum of its parts.  But some of those parts are magnificent.  First, there is the respectful homage to actors of a prior generation.  Dick Van Dyke, who played Bert the Chimney Sweep in the original "Mary Poppins" (1964), returns in this film, even singing and dancing in a final scene, no small accomplishment at age 93.  Karen Dotrice, the original Jane, has a brief cameo.  Angela Lansbury, also 93, who had no association with the original film, is amazingly spry in her brief appearance as a strong-voiced Balloon Lady.

Emily Blunt, who showed off her musical theater chops as the Baker's Wife in "Into the Woods" (2014), is luminous as Mary - the perfect blend of regal bearing, mischievousness and warmth.  When Mary Poppins is in charge, this film is on strong footing.  On the other hand, when Lin Manuel-Miranda (Jack the Lamplighter) is on the screen, the audience does not "look around at how lucky we are to be alive right now."  His efforts need considerably more work, work.

Director Rob Marshall previously has been quite effective in bringing Broadway musicals to the screen.  "Chicago" won six Academy Awards in 2003, including Best Picture, the first musical since 1968 to win the top award.  His versions of "Nine" (2009) and 2014's "Into the Woods" also are worthy of note.

Here, Marshall receives another credit as one of three story writers.  One wonders why, since the plot is almost incidental.  Widower Michael Banks (Ben Whishaw, so excellent in Amazon Prime's "A Very English Scandal" this year) has fallen on hard times.  He and his family are about to be evicted from their ancestral home.  If only the family can find their Certificate of Shares in the bank that holds their mortgage, all will be saved.  Six-year-olds across the world have a clear sense of how this will all end.  The show lurches happily along from one song opportunity to the next, sometimes with no plot development.  One interesting quirk:  this may be the only Disney film in history where the animated sequences are by far the least effective elements of the film.

The score by Marc Shaiman, with lyrics by Shaiman and Scott Wittman, the team behind the excellent "Hairspray" (2007), is entirely serviceable.  However, it suffers in comparison to the score of the original film.  The original "Mary Poppins" offered a series of songs known by generations - "A Spoonful of Sugar," "Chim Chim Cheree" and "Let's Go Fly a Kite." In this film, the score is super-cali-fragil-never-mind.  There are no soaring ballads here that you simply can't get out of your head.  In fact, given the non-existent plot, many seem entirely interchangeable.

If you need a diversion to minimize the time you have to spend during the holidays talking with family members you've avoided all year, this may be the show for you.  Medical warning:  do not take a spoonful of you-know-what before viewing.  It would just be redundant.

My advice: give the movie a chance. Pay attention to the talent, the story, and the fun. I'm sure it will make you smile.

I wanted to love this movie. When compared to the original this one comes up so short. The soundtrack doesn’t have a single song that you will remember or or care to hear again. It’s Emily Blunt trying to pretend to be her. The story was also lacking. They could have done so much more. The cameos and special effects are great however.

Mary Poppins Returns Review: For this review I thought I’d do a something special and have a combined review with a musical genius, aspiring actor, and my best friend, Landen. Throughout his review I will put breaks through his paragraph and put some of my comments and add-ons in. Mary Poppins Returns was the standout movie musical of the year of the past couple years. I definitely agree, though La La Land is the best musical of recent and my favorite. Every year around this time there is always a musical and I’m always excited to see what it is. Last years was The Greatest Showman, which though it worked as a musical failed as a story for me. Disney hasn’t had a real musical since the underrated Into the Woods. It sounds odd, but for being a sequel to a classic Disney film, it’s originality shined through. Yes. I was expecting there to be many similarities and just repeating the original but it brought a new magic to it. As we can all imagine it can be tough to live up to such a performer as Julie Andrews, but I believe Emily Blunt did it justice. Bringing the same sassy attitude and whimsical charm as Julie Andrews did, Emily Blunt managed to be Mary Poppins but bring her own twists and choices. They couldn’t have picked a better choice for Mary Poppins. Blunt did such a great job and did honor to Julie Andrews Oscar winning performance. I’m sure Julie Andrews agrees. Though nothing can beat Andrews, Emily Blunt did such a great performance landing a Golden Globe nomination (it’s between her and Olivia Coleman for The Favourite, I think Coleman will win however) and possibly an Oscar nomination. Lin Manuel Miranda did a good job of being the character as well. His acting was spotty as well as his singing but I think he did an okay job of keeping up with the other performers. Lin was fine. I personally don’t like his singing that much or his acting. He didn’t do horrible though. He got a Golden Globe nomination in the Comedy/Musical section, which seems to be easy to get into (Amy Schumer was nominated in that category for Trainwreck, definitely not an Oscar worthy performance) The other characters, such as The Banks Family, were great. Emily Mortimer and Ben Whishaw as Jane and Michael did a nice job of not straying from the characters while also portraying the grown up versions. I loved both of them. Emily Mortimer does the best performance that I’ve seen from her. She’s also just a great voice actress (she was Sophie in the amazing Japanese film Howl’s Moving Castle). I absolutely loved Ben Whishaw as Michael. There was so much emotion and depth put into the character. Other than Emily Blunt he was the best part. Both of them were amazing. The kids were great, as most Disney kids are. I liked the children, not as much as I thought I would but I still liked them. I wanted to feel for them just a little but more. The appearances of bigger household name stars were great as well. Julie Walters, funny, Meryl Streep, crazy and entertaining, Colin Firth, evil and good at it. Meryl Streep was just amazing again for how little she was in the movie. Julie Walters is just hilarious all the time and she had some of the best lines in the movie. I really liked Colin Firth’s characters. Lastly, the original songs by Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman are really what made this movie shine! They created new songs that were fun and entertaining, yet sad and sentimental. They were amazing original songs but they also went back to the original we know and love, with hidden tunes in the underscore. There’s no doubt that Marc Shaiman will win both the Golden Globe and Oscar for Best Original Score. It was so colorful and beautiful. He brought back some of the original tunes we love and know and it just put a smile on my face. His songs were really good. Surprisingly none were nominated for Golden Globes. If any are nominated for the Oscars it’ll probably either be The Place Where Lost Things Go (beautiful song) or Trip a Little Light Fantastic (the showstopper but not my favorite song). He deserves the awards. Overall, a great film for the entire family, all ages! I’m going to add a few things more now. The choreography was really good, especially for Trip a Little Light Fantastic. My only problem was that they kept focusing on Lin Manuel Miranda and not really anyone else. I understand he’s one of the leads but we only saw one other guy other than him. Speaking of cameras, the cinematography was good. It was colorful at the magical parts and captured the dull and dreary gray of London. As you’ve seen from the trailer and images, they incorporate the old animation in the movie. That was one of my favorite sequences in a movie of recent. I just had a smile the whole time. People have forgotten about that animation since they stopped making animated movies like that recently. The CGI wasn’t the greatest but I felt like it was supposed to be like that because it’s not supposed to feel really real. It might get a nomination for Best Visual Effects but won’t win. I loved this movie and the nostalgia it brought. The sequence for Nowhere to Go But Up (my favorite song) was the best part. It was so nostalgic and beautiful I just wanted to cry. The film was good with the tones from joyful to melancholy. My only complaints for the movie are Lin Manuel Miranda, the emotional attachment to the children could’ve been a little better, and also it was a bit long (2 hrs 10 min) but it’s worth every second. I thoroughly enjoyed this film and it’s one of my favorite of the year! Landen’s Grade: A My Grade: A

I have to say that I am dumbfounded with so many of the negative comments. I’m sure you have your reasons, but from what I see many of them have absolutely no bearing on the reality of what I saw the other day. This show is absolutely stunning. I’m not sure who could possibly experience the sweet story, those amazing lyrics, melodies and absolutely wonderful orchestrations and poo poo all of it. The story although seemingly very basic, has all of the intricate qualities that allow a musical to speak on many levels to many, young and old. It is smartly written, and brilliantly performed. Emily Blunt blew it out of the water with an amazing performance! And all of the supporting actors were spot on. The wide open slot for Julie Andrews was a huge missed opportunity. I think she may realize that if she hasn’t already. It would’ve been a wonderful way to cement and solidify both of those motion pictures together. And quite frankly, she has allowed herself to be used in movies that don’t rise to the heels of this movie. It could’ve been a wonderful legacy piece and a wonderful memorial for the older crowd, and an invitation to the younger crowd to experience what they haven’t seen. Time will tell, but I feel that this is a giant miss for the critics and the crowd that have panned it so quickly and quite frankly, so ravenously. One day, your kids and grandkids will be singing these tunes. My 12-year-old daughter already hasReally all of it memorized including the amazing light rap portion of “the cover is not the book”. I believe that one day it will be known as one of the great musicals our time.

An unnecessary, but yet well executed sequel to the beloved classic. In a time where Disney remakes reign supreme, Mary Poppins Returns is a breath of fresh air that quickly turns stale, as this “sequel” is a remake with a flashy coat of paint. The plot follows the same sequence of events as the original. The film begins showing Jack (this films Burt) singing a song about London. A disliked activity is made fun to introduce Mary’s magic to the children. Mary takes Jack and the kids into an animated world, where hi jinx, a musical number, and a race (chase) ensue. Mary then takes the gang to a magical relative who’s affliction has placed them on the ceiling. Mary then takes the kids to the bank, where their actions put their fathers job in jeopardy. On their way home, they all run into Jack and his gang of chimney sweeps, sorry, lamp lighters, where they all do a musical number using their tools of trade. The children’s father has a change of heart in the end, everything turns out alright and the family celebrates by flying balloons. Mary flies off into the sunset and the movie ends. This isn’t to say that the movie doesn’t bring anything new to the table. The film has a climax unlike the original, where the entire cast attempts to save the Banks’ house. And of course, we can’t ignore all the new music, which is enjoyable and upholds the tone of the original. And all the new scenes are enjoyable, if predictable once you realize it’s following the plot of the original.

I'm really in awe with this musical. It was a spectacle like no other. It felt as a movie of the good, old, romantic times, where cinema was more like art. It was creative and very imaginative. "Mary Poppins Returns" feels like the original, is the perfect sequel to a great film. It may contain songs that don't carry the magic of the original, but still the whole joy and excitement they cause is the same. Emily Blunt is the perfect Mary Poppins. By no means does she try to mimic Julie Andrews playing Mary Poppins. She just got the character so well, she really became Poppins. Jack is no Bert, but Lin-Manuel Miranda does a fantastic job in shaping this new character. Ben Wishaw is acting the hell out of Michael Banks, he is phenomenal. It such a sweet, beautiful movie, a really fun musical and although it is its own thing it feels so nostalgic. It doesn't necessarily rely on nostalgia to succeed, but when it hits you with those feels,it really does. Very wonderful little cameos have broken my heart. "Mary Poppins Returns" is pure fun!

Mary Poppins Returns
2018
U
directed by: Rob Marshall
starring:Emily Blunt,Lin Manuel Miranda,Meryl streep,Colin Firth,Dick Van Dyke,Emily Mortimer and Ben Whishaw etc

overall rating 81/100

Lets dive in to what makes Mary poppins returns a truly amazing in most ways sequel and another strong edition to the disney brand.

Lets start off with the incredible cast. Despite everyone having there excellent qualities i am particularly highlighting Julie Walters and Lin Manuel Miranda. Firstly Julie Walters is a fantastic actress and always does well in these types of roles as seen in Harry Potter and Paddington. She brought some humour to the film which helped the scenes with her in feel more humorous and warm. And secondly to Lin Manuel Miranda who did a fantastic job at technically playing Bert 2.0. He had the charm,the accent and great musical numbers to his character. You couldnâ(TM)t help but smile whenever he appeared on screen i think having a career in the west end has helped him tremendously for this type of role.

Next i do have to congratulate the director for getting the perfect actress for the role of Mary poppins. Emily Blunt was a fantastic Mary poppins. she has the charm the wittiness and the warmth that Julie Andrews bought. And even added a flavour of sass to the iconic character so she was on par and in some elements better then Julie Andrews.

The only slightly negative thing to do with the cast was the part of Meryl Streep. Her character just felt very out of place in the film and the whole scene with her in could of been cut from the film but it was fine for what it was.

Next I would like to add that the plot had so many nods to the original it was very nice to see after such a long wait for the sequel. Having key phrases and objects and the 2D animation world really will satisfy any fans of the original. And extending on the 2D animation world i thought that this whole scene was actually executed better then the original with the penguins and everything recognisable in the scene. It was just so nice to see this still added and done in the same way as the original but it will obviously look better due to higher budget.The director really did a creative and visually good job with making this as charming to watch as the original. 

Next i would like to add the excellent musical numbers in this film. Yes perhaps there arenâ(TM)t as many iconic songs in this film as the original. But all the numbers were still very pleasant to watch and really took you to another place when listening. And all the cast could sing very well which also made the scenes even better.

The final nice positive that i think that Disney has really been executing well recently is the emotional depth to the narrative. having the Banks children recently losing there mum and to see how badly there father Michael Banks ( Ben Whishaw) was coping and that he didnâ(TM)t know how to cope with looking after the children really added some heartwarming scenes into the film and to see them all gradually get closer was very sweet indeed.

Just ending on 2 only little things negative to say. Firstly i did question a couple of times whether the director was perhaps being to reliant on the original in certain scenes. Which i think they were in places but that i think was the directors creative choice so it was still very nostalgic to see and there was just enough new elements to the film to balance it out. And finally The actual plot of the Banks home was fairly dull just in places but not so dull as to make the film that much worse but i do think if there was more focus on this type of plot my rating would of been a bit lower.

Overall Mary poppins returns is a fantastic film which is on the same level as the original and is another very strong addition to the Disney cannon.

Iï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)m no fan of musicals or childrenï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s movies, but of course I have seen the original Mary Poppins and of course it holds a special significance to any serious appreciator of movie making. I was initially unimpressed by the idea of retreading such an iconic classic, but after hearing Emily Blunt on Fresh Air and reading the New Yorker review, I found myself actually excited to see it.

Why in the world is this movie getting such lukewarm praise?!
It is a sure-footed, beautifully wrought visit back to the era when childrenï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s entertainment wasnï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t trying to be ï¿ 1/2 1/2edgyï¿ 1/2 1/2ï¿ 1/2?, wasnï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t concerned with feeling topical or making meta-references to popular culture, and when the studio understood that if you make something truly marvelous on its own terms, it will entertain the audience at all ages.

The songs are absolutely first-rate, and criticisms of the music or the beats of the film as being somehow derivative are nonsense. If this had been made in some significantly different style, audiences (and presumably the haughty critics) would have cried foul. Mary Poppins Returns is the perfect example of a movie that has to be ï¿ 1/2 1/2just the same, but differentï¿ 1/2 1/2ï¿ 1/2?. Where a movie like ï¿ 1/2 1/2The Force Awakensï¿ 1/2 1/2ï¿ 1/2? made me feel hollowed out inside, reminded that I will never be 8 years old again, ï¿ 1/2 1/2Mary Poppins Returnsï¿ 1/2 1/2ï¿ 1/2? made me feel like something had been restored within me. How sad that so many others have apparently gone into this movie prepared to dismiss it, and therefore well armored against the intrusion of a feeling. Apparently, guileless enjoyment is terminally out of fashion for some people; they are the poorer for it.

ALTHOUGH i FOUND THIS FILM A LITTLE TEDIOUS, EVERYONE i WENT WITH LIKED IT.  tHE MOST i CAN SAY FOR IT IS THAT IT IS GENERALLY PLEASANT.  bUT THERE'S NOTHING TO REALLY INVEST IN HERE EMOTIONALLY, AND THE BIGGEST SURPRISE TO ME IS THAT THIS FILM SEEMS TO CONTRADICT, UTTERLY, THE MESSAGE OF THE FIRST FILM.  THE HEART AND SOUL OF THAT FIRST FILM LAY IN THE WISTFUL BEAUTY OF THE ST PAUL'S 'FEED THE BIRDS' SEQUENCE AND THE WRENCHING INSISTENCE THAT A SMALL BOY COULD NOT SHOW HIS KINDNESS IN GIVING HIS TUPPENCE TO THE BIRD LADY AND THE BIRDS OF ST PAULS.  iNSTEAD, HE WAS FORCED TO INVEST HIS TUPPENCE IN THE BANK.  aT THE END OF THAT FIRST FILM WE ALL FELT THE RELIEF OF SEEING THAT  MR BANKS HIMSELF REALISED THAT LIFE WAS SO MUCH MORE THAN MONEY AND THAT HE WAS ALLOWING HIS CHILDREN'S LIVES TO PASS HIM BY.  BUT IN THIS SEQUENCE IT TURNS OUT (I DON'T WANT TO SPOIL THINGS TOO MUCH HERE) THAT WHAT WE SHOULD ALL DO RIGHT THIS MOMENT IS LEAVE THE THEATRE AND INVEST TUPPENCE IN THE BANK!  a VERY STRANGE THIS TO DO IN A SEQUEL, AND IT FEELS AS IF THIS STRANGE CONCLUSION MAKES VERY CLEAR WHAT WE'RE WATCHING: A SOMETIMES CHARMING BUT VERY CALCULATED INVESTMENT BY THE DISNEY FOLK.

A bad sign watching a movie is thinking mostly negative thoughts and after an hour I was thinking: 1) This really isn't a movie for kids as it is too dark and somber  2) This really isn't a movie for adults as it doesn't capture what made the first film memorable 3) Emily Blunt has talent but she isn't a Julie Andrews or a Mary Poppins  4) Emily Mortimer has that certain smile and would make a better Mary Poppins 5) Will this film get any better? and 6) The songs are pretty lame.

There was one positive thought and that was Lin-Manual Miranda was continuing his place on the top of the hill after "In The Heights", "Hamilton", his score for "Moana", being honored on The Kennedy Center Honors this week, plus winning an Emmy Award, A Tony Award, Grammy Awards, the Pulitzer Prize, about to reprise his role as Hamilton opening the show in Puerto Rico and now doing a good job as Jack, the man who lights and shuts off the street lamps in the streets of London during  the Great Slump of the 1930s. Up to the hour and a half point--no pun intended--he is the only bright light.

Julie Walker, as the housekeeper, is almost an afterthought while Colin Firth should have been given a mustache to twirl as the villain to do something with the role. As the Banks children Pixie Davies, Nathanael Saleh and Joel Dawson they are given little more than they are expected to while Emily Mortimer, as their aunt, lights up the screen here and there and Ben Whishaw, as their father, really is wooden up to and in the last half hour of the film when he really comes through in a moving scene. Oh, yes, the less said about Meryl Streep, her song and her time on the screen the better.

The last half hour in no way makes up for the first 90-95 minutes but the screen does come alive with a song and dance by 93 year-old Dick Van Dyke up on a desk, with movie magic or not, reprising "Tripping The Light Fantastic" done earlier in the film by Miranda, along with 93 year-old Angela Lansbury as the Balloon Lady singing one of the better songs from the movie, "Nowhere To Go but Up" starting a full cast number.

Lin-Manuel Miranda always talks about watching the old song and dance movies and in "Mary Poppins Returns" he has two numbers, the first being "Tripping The Light Fantastic" and the second, "Race To Big Ben", that fulfill any dreams he might have had and brings back the magic of "Mary Poppins".

A lively, colourful homage to the original movie, which doesn't at all sully the memory of its predecessor. The song and dance numbers look and sound fine, with orchestrations shimmering and glittering. If the melodies and lyrics are nowhere near as accomplished and memorable as those of the Sherman Brothers, well, you can't expect miracles. (Bizarrely, my wife and I still came out humming numbers from the original!) More seriously damaging is the portrayal of Poppins. Emily Blunt cannot balance strictness with kindness in her characterisation. Her performance seemed to me calculating and cold, and at times painful to watch. I was left wondering how much better Emily Mortimer might have played the lead instead. (She really shines as Jane.) This is a shame, as so much of the production does work beautifully, including the entire rest of the casting. Miranda is superb. Whishaw and Firth are as reliable as you'd expect, and the three children are also excellent. The animated sequences are pretty well done (a decent homage to former glories), and the overall story arc works well. The final 15 minutes are a particular delight, mainly for the show-stopping cameos by Dick Van Dyke and Angela Lansbury. (Van Dyke particularly had me reaching for my hanky.) But I have to deduct 1  1/2  stars for Blunt, and  1/2  star for the overly fussy, contrived lyrics. My wife, it's true, loved the movie unconditionally, whilst still acknowledging Blunt's miscasting, and so did our 6 year old daughter (whose favourite scene was bathtime.)  All in all, a fair and respectful sequel to an all-time classic, one which has made us all want to watch the original movie again.

A delightfully earnest movie with excellent performances from Emily Blunt and Lin-Manuel Miranda. But it's a completely worthwhile moviegoing experience.

I walked into the theater with every intention of hating Mary Poppins Returns. As the movie started I began thinking of each little flaw I could nitpick. That sounds mean-spirited and harsh, but as an avid fan who grew up watching the original Mary Poppins, it felt disrespectful and ridiculous that someone thought they could create a legitimate sequel to such an iconic film 54 years later. Then, as I was sitting there gritting my teeth and ready to write the most scathing review I could muster, I heard someone humming along to the music. Wait, was that me?!? I realized I was grinning from ear to ear despite myself. There is a magic in Mary Poppins Returns that hooked me against my better judgement. It is a charming film that has a style that harkens back to the original, to the point that I almost have to admit this is a legitimate sequel. With each new scene I was more engrossed and feeling like a kid again. My brain shut off its critical nagging, and I was having a great time, waiting for the movie to end so I could buy the soundtrack right away. Now there’s a reason that Mary Poppins Returns feels so reminiscent of the original, and that is the fact that it is almost a remake. The plot has most of the same beats, and every single song can be directly linked to the one it is emulating from the original. It’s a great formula, so that’s not necessarily a bad thing, and perhaps the fact that it kept reminding me of something I love played into my enjoyment. It’s very similar, but rest assured it is inferior in every way when you compare the two. Emily Blunt is fine, but she’s no Julie Andrews. The songs are playful and fun, but they’re not as strong as the Sherman Brothers’ masterpiece. The plot here is weak, and threatens to become boring, but it never quite got there for me. If you like the original Mary Poppins, and you’re able to watch Returns without comparing them directly with one another, you should find something to enjoy in this sequel. It was well-made by people who clearly had some reverence for what Walt Disney and his team did half a century ago.
If you enjoy the world of Mary Poppins, this is a great addition to the Banks family story. A great family film.

Having seen mixed reviews and had experienced many other dreadful remakes I was prepared for the worse but was pleasantly surprised. It is a really good film. It is charming, happy - delightful. For children of all ages. It is not a remake of the 1965 classic. It is Variations on a Theme of Mary Poppins. For once I do not hate CGI. I now see it can be used for Good as well as for Evil. And toward the fairytale happy ending I was lazily under its spell but I shot upright in my seat with (especially), its first Surprise. (There is a second one). At the first one I thought - is it? No, it can't be, can it? Am I imagining it? But it was!  My rule is never to give a film 5 stars. So I don't give it 5 stars. I have to give it - on this one and only occasion - six stars! Some of the recent Disney's efforts have been poor. They got this one right!

This movie was faced with the impossible task of following up a timeless classic. It did an amazing job of channeling the original, but never directly relying on it. It only uses hints of the original songs and exercises great restraint. Blunt never felt like she was trying to be Andrews playing Poppins. This movie takes inspiration from the books and handles some harder lessons like how to cope with loss. Disney has carved a niche for itself with legacy and loss as themes in recent movies like Black Panther, Infinity War, Cars 3, Coco, Thor Ragnarok, and so on. The songs are very catchy and I feel will age well and are only being attacked because they are being compared to some of the best songs in Disney’s history. This movie shines because it is a combination of classic Disney sensibilities and their modern ones.

Disney has outdone themselves. I loved Mary Poppins as a kid, and have continued to into adulthood. One of the problems with sequels this far apart is that they often lose the heart and soul of the original movie franchise. Not so in this case. Disney stays true to Travers' tale as well as true to the style of the original and somehow far beyond his grave a hint of Walt is contained within. Emily Blunt is not just a good Mary Poppins, she IS Mary Poppins in every sense. From her accent to her singing, to her clever wit and quick quips, the performance is spot on to the point of Oscar worthiness. Disney reminisces all the wonder and imagination of the original with new spins on live action mixed with animation, managing to include both new and old into a solid 2 hours of fun, singing, dancing, laughing, emotion, and pure entertainment. Do the kid in you a favor. GO SEE THIS MOVIE!

5) Angela Lansbury was obviously supposed to be Julie Andrews. So it didn't work.
6) There's something very cold about the whole film. It's no Paddington.

My wife and I took our four-year-old daughter to see this despite her having seemingly no interest in the trailers or TV spots that have been on heavy rotation-especially over the past week or so. Admittedly, this was partly for the reason both of us wanted to see this fifty-four-year-later sequel to Mary Poppins and didn't want to have to go through the hassle of finding a babysitter the weekend before Christmas, but it was mostly due to the fact that despite the lack of interest in the promotional materials that sometimes you just have to trust your parents know better than you and, lucky for us, our little four-year-old girl decided to indulge us on this particular matter (the slush and popcorn might have factored in, but I digress). The point being, that once director Rob Marshall's (Chicago, Into the Woods) Mary Poppins Returns began and Emily Blunt's incarnation of the practically perfect nanny showed up and began teaching the new generation of Banks children (as well as reminding their parents) that while imagination may not always be approved of, that it's more than necessary to make life fun and largely bearable, the little one was more than hooked by the magic of the titular character. And so, while Mary Poppins Returns is admittedly more of a re-hash or re-imagining of that first, 1964 film than I would have either thought or hoped it to be it is also a reminder of how powerful and delightful the imagination can truly be. Though my personal experience with the film may not be as heartening as those who take their teenagers to the theater and see their faces revert to a state of child-like wonder; to experience the kind of magic and possibilities Mary Poppins brings to the table and exerts with pure enthusiasm strike our daughter in such a clear and distinct way-especially during the numerous musical numbers-was quite something. The Julie Andrews picture was one of those movies that was always on whenever I needed it to be growing up and taking on the burden of crafting a follow-up to that respected classic (the only live-action film Disney saw garner a Best Picture nod in his day) is worth a degree of built-in respect for even attempting as much and while Mary Poppins Returns could have certainly done a little more to stand on its own it is so excessively charming, appropriately cute, and full of original songs and creative executions that it's hard to argue the film is anything but perfectly pleasant in every way.

Only reason I would not give this movie 5 stars is that it had too much emphasis on the mother’s death, for a movie that should be drawing a large audience of children.

Went to the theater last night to see this with my family as I am a fan of the original Disney movie, it was my Christmas gift. I have read the books and loved Blunt as Mary Poppins in her bit more stern yet dynamic portrayal of the magical nanny. I also love Miranda in his role and thought Jack a fitting homage to Bert. His opening number "Underneath the lovely London sky" was just beautiful and set the tone even if his accent was rubbish cockney like Van Dyke's original. I just thought that was another wink and a nod. Many of the musical numbers are fantastic and me and the children really liked the bawdy vaudeville number, " the cover is not the book" and "trip a little light fantastic", and Michael's "conversation". I didnt really like "turning turtle". Although there is a lot of magic, the plot seemed very contrived ( or conjured?) in places such as with Big Ben and the final scene at the bank, although Van Dyke always puts a smile on my face. We left the theater feeling cheery and yet a bit confuddled. Anyway, will still recommend to my friends.

Fun for the family.  First half was very good, but second half slowed down/boring.  The movie did capture the "Mary Poppins" theme and characters very well, but there didn't seem to be a good reason to make it, other than to make Disney more money.  The kids will love this movie, but the original is better.  Blunt was great as Poppins, but Miranda's dance scenes were not even close to what Van Dyke did in the original.  Disney should've hired someone that can dance for Jack's part.  The "bowl" scene was probably the best part of the movie, but we didn't need the Meryl Streep scene. It looked like it was forced, and didn't belong in the film.  If it was deleted, then we'd have had a better movie.

Performances (actors and dancers) in this film were well done, especially the choreographic numbers.  I give this film  only 3 stars because the writing was subpar.  Itâ(TM)s very difficult to not to compare this film to the original âMary Poppinsâ?, which holds the bar very high.
My family really enjoyed this spectacle. The music, the story, the acting. All wonderful, and Blunt was perfectly perfect.

Fun family movie. Long and Slow buildup that finds its stride halfway through with a uplifting message/story that is overall kid friendly and bearable for adults.  Listening to the sound track before the movie might have helped me feel engaged sooner and more fully.
Ask for your money back

My entire family really enjoyed the film. It pays homage to the original but creates itâ(TM)s own magic. The acting and direction are very strong. Emily Blunt is terrific as is Ben Whishaw. A wonderful holiday treat for all of us.

Since Disney is incompetent of coming up with new ideas, and must resort to using older stories they did years ago, they certainly better live up to what theyï¿ 1/2(TM)re doing. This does not happen with Mary Poppins Returns. The film is terribly cast, Lin Manuel Miranda isnï¿ 1/2(TM)t anywhere near good enough or remotely right in type for the role he was given, and Emily Blunt is just practically average in every way. Disney will only use movie stars now instead of giving anyone new a chance, a grim shadow considering Julie Andrews was a newcomer given the role of Mary, and denied by competitor studio Warner Bros. for ï¿ 1/2My Fair Ladyï¿ 1/2Â? because she wasnï¿ 1/2(TM)t a star. Also terrible considering the movie stars in this film were nothing amazing or remotely interesting.
I was really disappointed in this movie. I had really high hopes. While the singing and dancing were fantastic the movie was slow and the songs were not memorable. Emily Blunt was amazing .

It was just a matter of time. Mary Poppins was bound to return. Iconic, beloved, practically perfect in every way, she had to return. And now is the perfect time! Yet after seeing this production, I'm wondering why she bothered coming back at all, for Disney's hasn't made a movie here. They have made well structured, visually compelling digital content suitable for mass market, multi-channel distribution and rich with merchandising opportunities. 

In short, this movie was not made by creative minds at Disney, it was made by Disney's marketing department. From the casting and weakest of plots, to the bmx bike sequence (of course...in 1930's London), the entire experience felt like being fed great tasting, processed food in a test kitchen. I'm full, but nothing is memorable.  

And maybe that was the whole idea. After all, they weren't trying to make a classic, they were trying to make a profit.
Kept in touch with some of the original material! Emily blunt very good but feels like there isn’t enough about Mazza P herself, too much on the banks kids. Beautiful animation!
Terrible movie. I was bored stiff. It felt like an acid trip. Music was awful, nothing memorable. I wanted to walk out of this movie I was so bored.

Excellent movie! You do not need to see the first one to love this one.  Although, what beautiful memories, such delicate connections between the two. Loved every moment!  (And definitively, LOVED LIN MANUEL!)

Very good. Love how Disney incorporated old animation with modern live action. Emily Blunt played Mary Poppins very well. And Dick Van Dyke has got it even at 93 YEARS OLD. IT IS REMARKABLE. Mary Poppins Returns was a great movie and throwback to the original

incredible. The music overwhelmed me into tears.

I've never been a big fan of Mary Poppins, It's always been a whimsical movie, but never my favorite. However, this adaptation made me change my tune quite a bit. Emily Blunt is an extremely talented actress, and now we know she can sing too! We knew Lin-Manuel Miranda could do both, and he did them well. The other characters were very talented as well, and they all contribute to the magical feeling this movies gives off. The graphics and CGI are probably the most amazing part of it all. I knew technology has gone a long way, but the the mixing of different types of animation and reality made the movie feel that much more magical and whimsical. In Mary Poppins, it's clear that each actor or actress was meant to play the role they played. The two hour movie flew by in what felt like minutes. The only reason I gave this movie 4.5 stars and not 5 is because  sometimes it just felt like so much was coming at me at one time, and I got a little lost. But that was only at some points, and the majority of the movie was beautifully done. Mary Poppins has never been a favorite of mine, but this rendition was very well done.
Lots of fun. Lin Manuel Miranda is great!
Truly magical! Great new music; Emily Blunt is outstanding and practically perfect! 6 year old grandson loved it so much!
My 4 year old and 10 year old daughters and I loved it
very good, just don't expect it to be the original and you'll be fine. great to see the cameo by Dick Van Dyke, wish Julie Andrews would have done hers but it's always good to see Angela Lansbury.

Those 3 actors ruin the hard work of every one else. It was still fun to watch, other than the parts where it was cringingly bad. I would say this movie is fun, but it is not good.There are great performances by all but 3 actors.And yes, they do ruin the whole thing. Mary Poppins Returns

Best movie of the year.

Great songs, breathtaking backdrops, and fantastic characters.

Some great lessons:  Children are important and itï¿ 1/2(TM)s worth our time to listen to them.

As grownups we forget.  Forget to live, and laugh, and have fun.  That is why we need children to see through their big hearts what is possible.

Mary Poppins Returns reminds us that though circumstances may bring us down, together "there is nowhere to go but up."

It is a must see movie!

This is a slightly above average children’s film, but in many ways its positives make it an overall disappointment. Good: Emily Blunt is excellent. Some say she lacks a bit of the warmth of Andrews but as a slightly older Poppins that works very well. She makes Mary her own and creates a fun character flaw, her enormous (yet deserved) ego. Lin Manuel was fine as Jack, the Bert replacement, an allegedly young chimney sweep during first film who grew up. The kids were solid particularly Georgie. The special effects made Aquaman laughable in comparison. Bad: Songs were not memorable. Too many cameos. Van Dyke was the best but he should have returned as Bert. Ugly: Story was a mess. Michael Banks was awful. The actor brought no life to the role and his character made no sense. He was an artist who had no art supplies in house and never painted. His only song was the last song. He was a totally wasted character and the heavy death of a mother we never met at all lacks heft in film. We needed to see a glimpse of her at the beginning to feel the loss. This was way too much of a retread of the original and it is an absolute shame because the bewitching Blunt could have accomplished Disney’s mission and turned this into a franchise. The cast needed more diversity and the story of a rich white man who felt he was no longer wealthy enough to pay his bills lacks appeal to many working class families who attend the movies. Bad story. Absolute shame. Sharper screenplay and lyrics could have made this a classic since Blunt clearly brought an A game.
Well acted but a weak storyline, not a single memorable song. Not up to Disney’s name.

This movie had potential to be good. It was about 30 minutes too long and the music was just blah (shoulder shrug). I thought Emily Blunt was pretty good (no Julie Andrews) but she did a good job. And can we please, PLEASE stop making Meryl Streep sing? Or at least put a warning label on the movie so we can brace ourselves for it? This movie is probably worth seeing once.... at a dollar theater, with lots of popcorn and candy. I don’t have any desire to see it again.

I am a huge Mary Poppins fan. I watched it constantly growing up. I was so excited for the movie and was thrilled that Emily Blunt was starring. The film did not disappoint! Emily Blunt fit perfectly into Mary Poppins shoes. I couldn’t keep my eyes off of her. The soundtrack has not completely won me over yet. Maybe after I watch a few more times I will feel differently. It’s kind of unfair when I have been listening to the original songs for over 30 years. I will say that I missed Bert terribly! Dick Van Dyke delivered in the first movie....we got a hint of him in this one but I wanted more. Meryl Streep was a treat!!! And loved the original Jane Banks cameo. Bravo!!! PS I recommend rewatching the original first as a refresher. There are many throwbacks that you could miss the humor if you do not refresh your memory first.

Mary Poppins Returns is a rare treat: an old fashioned movie musical with an old-fashioned message that works perfectly in the modern world. Blunt is the movie's backbone. She is wise, witty and mischievous - with a twinkle in her eye. She is not so much the film's protagonist, as she is the engine who, with a few words or a gesture, directs people to the right path.Mary Poppins Returns serves as a reminder that Disney still has a little magic left up its sleeve.

Mary Poppins Returns

Marshall's version of one of the most beloved Disney character is practically advanced and not your usual overprotective confidant. Unlike the previous version, this one is less focused on glorifying Blunt's stardom by putting all the work in her shoulder and instead works marvelously as a teamwork. It surely is a Disney feature from head to toe. First of all, as usual Marshall's visual galore offers you an overwhelming dose of cinema with its meticulous art designing and jaw dropping production design. From choreography to performance, he squeezes out the best from each frame. The visual effects are a bit dodgy, but the animated musical sequence is a pure packet of delight. Frankly, if considered only the musical acts, it is a perfect ten.

From catchy songs to amazing choreography, the film flows smoothly without overstaying its welcome. Among many many musical bits, the one concerning the lanterns at night with Miranda at the helm is the perfect collaboration of everything; song, performance, choreography and visuals. And as far as the rest of the storytelling is concerned, unlike his few previous projects, Marshall has managed to keep it pragmatic. With fluent vocab and a persistent theme of staging each character as the protagonist of the scene, it is palpable to its happy-go-lucky nature.

The writing is quite balanced, all the actors gets their stand out moments. Whishaw as the victim has an amazing voice and sings expressively with Mortimer who might not have enough to invest but has tightly hold on to her role. The younger cast draws attention from the elder ones in musical sequences especially in the lantern musical act. Streep and Firth are merely their to raise the stakes of the table, their part concerns as an introduction to hold the audience whenever the storyline drops down.

Surprisingly, Miranda has a much bigger part to play, almost walking parallel-y to Blunt as a lead, his performance may be put on stand on drama for questioning but on musical acts, he is put upfront by the makers knowingly that he will impress. Blunt under the sheer pressure of filling in the shoes of Andrews, is confident and equally hilarious. One of the best gags of all is devouring her perfect-ness in the mirror that itself grows as a character. Marshall's maturity can be pointed out in here, where he doesn't unnecessarily offers Blunt a wider range to please the viewers, in her own contract-orial margin, she delivers unflinchingly. There is a sense of Disney-ness that saves this before falling into mediocrity lane.

The culminated sub-plots and tactics projected that hits altogether in the last act, amps up our emotions where Marshall manages to craft a live action sequence that is arguably written for an animated one. This merrily merry place does get way too sweet at times for you to swallow. And for their conflict, the very essence of Mary Poppins is it, and hence with an ironic and sarcastic note carried off effervescently by Blunt, it somehow manages to land safely; so what if with an umbrella. Mary Poppins Returns; she does, and she makes sure it matches the expectations, if not exceeds.

Absolutely Wonderful! True to the spirit of the original. LOVED the music, singing and dancing. Emily Blunt is brilliant! Lin Manuel Miranda ... I wish we lived close, cuz you’d be my BFF. I have no real investment in Mary Poppins as a character or the original 1964 movie, so I was expecting to walk out of Mary Poppins Returns with a shrug, likely finding it middling at worse. I was unprepared for what I endured, and endured is the accurate statement. Mary Poppins Returns is an insane movie and one of the most maddening and painful experiences in a theater I've had all year, and no number of spoonfuls of sugar will help this bad medicine go far enough down.

It's the "Great Slump," a.k.a. Depression, in London and the Banks children have grown up. Michael (Ben Whishaw) has three young children of his own and he's struggling to maintain his job at the bank and be the father they need in the wake of his wife's death. His sister, Jane (Emily Mortimer), has moved into help but it's still not enough. Enter that famous nanny, Mary Poppins (Emily Blunt), who takes it upon herself to watch over the children, help them through the grieving process, and explore the outer reaches of London with some help from some friends, chiefly Jack (Lin Manuel-Miranda). The Banks family is in danger of losing their home to the head of the bank (Colin Firth) unless they can find a specific title of shares that will grant them a wealth denied their adult lives.

This movie felt like it was eight hours long and I had no sense of how much time was passing, mostly because of its misshaped structure and general lack of pacing. Mary Poppins Returns feels like it could have been renamed The Tony Awards: The Movie. It's one unrelated song-and-dance number after another, rarely building from the previous one, and so it feels like an eternal televised awards show that just shuffles from one set piece to the next, never providing a sense of direction or finality. Things just happen in this movie and then different things happen but rarely do they feel consequential. This makes the film feel endless because you have no real concept of progression. It's just another unrelated song into an unrelated magical realm that doesn't really seem like it matters, and then we're off to the next. I think some part of me is still trapped watching Mary Poppins Returns, never allowed to leave.

This would be mitigated if the songs were any good. There are over a dozen and not a single one is memorable. It was mere minutes after leaving the theater that I pressed myself into trying to hum any one of them, and I could not. They instantly vanish from your memory because there are no melodies or interesting production aspects that cause them to stand out. They assault you with their blandness and staid orchestration. They're a careful recreation of an older sounding, 1950s musical, an antiquated sound that doesn't have the same traction today. The only way you can remember one of these songs is if you have a traumatic experience forever linked to one of these mediocre, warbling collection of sounds.

There are two astoundingly peculiar songs. "Trip a Little Light Fantastic" is a big ensemble number involving the lamp lighters lead by Miranda. However, the song reference is clearly evocative of the Timothy Leary "trip the light fantastic" comment about LSD. It's strange to think this is only a coincidence when the lamp lighters are dubbed "learies." It's not a good song to begin with and the performance literally involves men on BMX bicycles flying around and doing tricks. How is any of this happening in a reported Disney family film? The Meryl Streep "Turning Turtle" song may be the most excruciating five minutes I've sat through for all 2018. It's just embarrassing to watch and made me honestly think of the children's movie disaster, The Ooogieloves, where you watch once proud actors debase themselves and their legacies in depressing fashion. That's the level of dread and mourning I had watching Streep slog through a Bela Lugosi accent and dance upside down. It has to be seen to be believed but you shouldn't ever have to see this. I have a new appreciation for the La La Land songs.

The continual removal of stakes robs the movie of feeling like anything onscreen genuinely matters. Mary Poppins is a magical creature without clearly defined rules or limits. At any point she might simply have the solution to a problem that she wasn't sharing. Take for instance the ending (spoilers for the duration of this paragraph, but really, who cares?) where the lamp lighters and the Banks family race to ole Big Ben to literally "turn back time" by adjusting the clock hands. The lamp lighters use their ladders to free climb the face of the clock to the very top, only to be undone by not being able to reach the minute hand at it nears twelve. Then all of a sudden Mary Poppins scoffs to herself and flies up to the clock face to adjust it. If she could do this the whole time why did these very mortal men risk their lives in this exercise? I think Mary Poppins may be a cruel god (more on this later). The concluding dash to ensure the Banks family can keep their home involves not one, not two, but three deus ex machinas, a "Turducken of ex machinas" as my pal Ben Bailey termed it. Ultimately all of their actions do not even matter because the film routinely provides an unknown escape route that invalidates their efforts. It turns out, in the end, they weren't even going to lose their home thanks to (at my best guess) a magical bird head that is best friends with the head of a bank and who never mentioned this before, the same head of the bank who has just been off in what appears to be an adjacent room for whatever reason and that also knows that Michael Banks has accrued a hefty fortune from a childhood investment, and has never mentioned it as well except in this crucial moment. Why, why does Mary Poppins Returns do this? Why does it present stakes or the illusion of stakes only to sabotage them every time?

Is Mary Poppins really a creature of good or does her need to be loved prove her a fickle god who demands adulation, subservience, and obedience? When Mary Poppins travels from world to world, some live action, some animated, all fanciful, every inhabitant seems to know this woman and love her unconditionally despite her prevalent smarm. The bigger question is do these magical worlds exist independent of Mary Poppins? Is there a pocket universe in existence on the side of a chipped porcelain bowl, or did it only come into existence when Mary Poppins decided it would be a lovely vacation spot? If so, that means she is calling into being a throng of adoring creatures that exist to validate her impulsive whims. She is a selfish god that demands an audience of servants and sycophants, not unlike the Javier Bardem character in Darren Aronofsky's polarizing polemic, mother!.

The actors acquit themselves fine for their roles. Blunt (A Quiet Place) and Miranda (Moana) will still be charming performers even when given substandard material. Blunt holds your attention with her prissy, schoolmarm persona, balancing the audience's memories of Julie Andrews without going into parody. Her singing (as also evidenced from 2014's Into the Woods) is above average and can help make some of the songs more tolerable to listen to. Miranda is a talent bursting with charisma and range, which makes it all the more frustrating to squeeze him into the narrow confines of a cockney scamp. He does get a rapping reprise in "A Cover is Not the Book" with a group of cartoon penguins. The stranger element is that it really feels like Miranda's character wants to have sex with Mary Poppins. They slot him as a forced romantic option for Mortimer's underwritten sister, but his eyes are clearly set for the woman who bosses people around and has magic in her fingers. He remembers her when he was a boy chimney sweep and I think he's been fantasizing about her every day since. Plus, she hasn't aged in 30 years.

Mary Poppins Returns is a bizarre artifact of a displaced time, taking great pains to recreate a style but without providing a purpose or sense of feeling beyond emulation. I don't know who this movie is for besides the hardcore fans of the original. There are dancing dolphins, talking dogs, bathtub portals, an upside down house, flying balloons, union protests, Angelina Lansbury or an animatronic lookalike, and there's lots of songs you will be unable to recall and a story that repeatedly removes any stakes or grounding from beneath itself so that the movie never feels firm or purposeful. There were several points where I just wanted to throw up my hands and ask, "What am I watching?" I still don't know. Mary Poppins Returns is a movie musical that is nothing short of super-cali-fragil-awful.

Mary Poppins Returns is the longest sequel ever developed in history.  After 54 years this movie is reincarnated with Emily Blunt playing Poppins.  Blunt was endorsed by Andrews to reprise her character.   The script was enticing and long and sad.  I couldnâ(TM)t hold back my tears praying for the Banks family, having to lose their mother, their house and trying to get by within their means.  The songs from the original were not part of the this movie which was disappointing, but the new songs were not memorable.  The hand drawn animated scenes and characters were amazing, smooth and one of a kind.  Meryl Streepâ(TM)s scene was not necessary, it was side story that would have saved fifteen minutes of screen time off of a movie that ran over two hours long.  Lin-Manuel Miranda added another dimension and he portrayed Dick Van Dykeâ(TM)s leery group to life with great choreography.  It was great seeing Lansbury in a cameo and overall it was a wonderful movie. Definitely add this to your library.

I wish I could give it more stars. This movie was a cinematic masterpiece. The performances by Emily Blunt and Lin-Manuel Miranda were amazing, the songs were very catchy, and the visuals were incredible. In one section of the movie, they add in some of the old school animation from all the movies we watched as kids. Meryl Streep even makes a special appearence that blows you away. Mary Poppins returns, but goes no where. What a horrible movie. To start with, there was no story line.  All the characters are essentially the same at the end of the story as they were when the story started.  I am hard pressed to state what is theme of Mary Poppins Returns.  Is the theme having no money is bad, or is it that bankers are evil.  I am not sure what Mary Poppins Returns was trying to say.  

Also, the cinematography was dizzying.  The cinematography in the first movie was breathtaking, as the camera moved and seemed to dance with the chimney sweeps.  In the new movie, The camera seemed to get in the way of the action.  The dancers seemed to be confined, and the sets would be better on a the stage than the studio.  

The cinematography was bad, but  how Mary Poppins was portrayed was a slap in the face to Pamela Lyndon Travers , the author of Mary Poppins.  .  Mary Poppins in the new movie never smiled.  Never once did seem happy. She seemed all knowing, but why? Mary is happy and charming, not a wizard.  

Most the scenes in the movie didn't add to the plot.  I didn't understand what the bathtub scene had to do with the plot, and the china bowl scene, made very little scene to the story. 

All and all, I left the theater, disappointed and nauseous.  Most of all I just wanted two hours of my life back.

My wife and I took our two girls (3 yr old and 5 yr old) to see this movie last night and everyone was looking forward to it.  I am sad to report that it was not well received and we all left the film feeling a bit cheated and questioning why Disney would greenlight such a mediocre execution and concept?

Disney has managed to make this movie so incredibly unoriginal following the original Mary Poppins almost to a "T" with the only obvious changes being inconsequential (Mom has passed and Dad is an idiotic struggling artist turned bank teller).  The casting is uninspired and as much as we love Emily Blunt, she doesn't make this movie sing.  She's not bad but if Disney is going to do such a vanilla remake then you better get a full cast that can sing their faces off.  Emily does not fit this role.  

Even the amazingly talented Lin Manuel Miranda seems out of place here.  His only capacity in this film is as a performer only and it makes me wonder how much better the movie would have been if he had been allowed to take his brush to this canvas? 

But shame again on Disney for taking the middle-of-the-road approach and releasing a movie that should not have been made.  It runs too long and the true test of a movie like this is my kids who stopped paying attention very early on.  The songs were not good and we just don't really care about the Banks family. Faced with the impossible task of adding to the classic Mary Poppins legacy,  this film makes a beautiful tribute and effort. Mary Poppins Returns, about the titular nanny returning to help the grown up Banks children, was a true experience for me that brings back the feel of the original Mary Poppins and 60's Disney in general. (It even has a nostalgic old-fashioned opening credits).

The entire thing looks and feels fantastic like an old-timey storybook. Includes a new 2-D animated/live-action segment, not something we've seen in a while and a welcome comeback. The story itself has a very old-fashioned and genuinely good-hearted feel to it.

Great cast. Blunt makes and an excellent Mary Poppins, and Lin Manuel Miranda is pretty likable as Jack, Bert's replacement. Ben Wishaw (the voice of Paddinton and the most recent Q from the James Bond films) does a surprisingly sympathetic job as Michael Banks mourning the loss of his wife and just trying to keep things together.

The songs, by Marc Shaiman (Hairspray and parts of the South Park movie and Team America) aren't as catchy or memorable as the first film, but that's not knocking these songs. I did like them all and they again captured an old-school feeling.

There were some weak points. A lot of the scenes set in London, were too darkly shot for their own good. I mean I understand that an intentional style choice as the bleakness of London contrasts with the brightness Mary Poppins brings, but it makes it a pain to watch at some points.

The movie is basically like The Force Awakens as it repeats many elements from the first film. (They even bring back Admiral Boom, now played by David Warner. I mean come on he was no spring chicken in the first film. He should be dead by now.) Also, the whole mother-just-died bit was done by Disney only a month ago for the Nutcracker movie, although this movie handles it a lot better if you ask me.

Lastly, the main antagonist is paper-thin and whose crookedness exceeds practicality. This is especially disappointing as the first film didn't need this sort of villain to drive the plot.

Those criticisms aside, I had so much fun with this movie that I'm still giving it a full rating. 

There is nothing really objectionable in this but be forewarned younger children may be bored by the more talky moments. I saw restlessness in my nephew and other young children while watching this.
Mary Poppins reminds us how we should stay graceful in a dreadful world.

Mary Poppins Returns has a lot to live up to in the shadow of the 1964 classic, and honestly its gonna need some time until it can be told if it's a success.

This winter's musical to bring in the masses in a year without a Star Wars, Mary Poppins Returns is just as comparable to last year's The Greatest Showman as it is the Disney original, but definitely a different level of effective.

This film banks (the pardon the pun) on the nostalgia and classic filmmaking of Mary Poppins for effect. Where we're given the endearing and inaccurate London of the Julie Andrews film once again, full of whimsy and imagination. A lot of the beats are similar and we're given our fare share of references, but none of them are groan-inducing. In fact, it' more sweet and delightful hearing music cues or seeing classic Mary Poppins magic once again. 

Rob Marshall does well to not oversaturate Mary Poppins Returns with modern special effects. They are certainly used here, but there's a feeling of imperfection and of the first film in its practicality. Sequences are imaginative and capture your memories of Mary Poppins, with only a bit of a modern wipe on it.

Make no mistake, Mary Poppins Returns is still bigger and better thanks to budgets and advancements, but it feels good to watch live action and animation come together again without in your face computer animation.

Marshall is no stranger to putting musicals to film, but much like his track record, it's a bit mixed here. For every beautiful sequence full of wonderful choreography there's sequences of poor musical cinematography and editing that lacks that punch. Mary Poppins Returns has its highlights, but there are sequences that could easily be excised and some parts that could have done with a reshoot and a recut.

Mary Poppins Returns is an ambitious love letter, and it's also cursed by its aspirations. It's tough when you try and match a perfect musical soundtrack by some of the greats. Not a slant on the talented Marc Shaiman at all, just highlighting the daunting task of even remotely matching something like  Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.

What it undoubtedly gets right is it's cast. It's tough to call what's the smarter call: Lin-Manuel Miranda as the Jack the lamplighter or Emily Blunt as Mary Poppins. Blunt shines in this, channeling her best into it to recreate the iconic nanny with great respect to the legacy. She's not practically perfect in every way, but she's exactly what you need here. Same for Miranda, it's great whenever you see someone enjoying every second of their job, and Miranda's on top of the moon from his very introduction.

Other casting choices go from great to so odd and potentially problematic. Colin Firth is the perfect villain you need, Ben Whishaw and Emily Mortimer rock being the grown up Banks children, but goddamn, why the hell is Meryl Streep in this movie, I still don't know. 

Mary Poppins Returns is the love letter you didn't know someone wanted to make for Mary Poppins. It's familiar and it's safe and it tries to be a good modern sequel/pastiche. It's fun and it's optimistic and it's bright, which is definitely my shit. For all of its appreciation it suffers for never reaching the highs of Julie Andrews, and that says a lot coming from a returning nanny holding a kite flying over the smog of London.

3/5 Stars.
