When a film leans hard into nostalgia, it can sometimes work but often doesn’t. Star Trek (2009) brought back Leonard Nimoy’s Spock to great effect. Stranger Things uses our love of the 80s to build an effective backdrop for the show. Superman Returns leaned so hard on Richard Donner’s films that they lifted the plot of the first film. Nostalgia can be a tricky thing. I’ve been thinking about this since we took Julianne and a friend to see Mary Poppins Returns. I’ll admit, I really liked it. I found Emily Blunt utterly charming as Mary. She’s a fantastic actress. Lin-Manuel Miranda was well cast as Jack the Lamp-Lighter. The music dazzles (A Cover is Not the Book was my favorite) and the dance numbers are fantastic (Trip a Little Light Fantastic has a wonderful dance number). There are nostalgic moments but you could have zero knowledge of Mary Poppins and be able to follow the story. It can be a little predictable at times if you pay attention. There’s at least one song and dance number I didn’t particularly care for when Meryl Streep’s Topsy shows up. As for the two big nostalgic moments: there are two cameos in the film. Dick Van Dyke shows up to do a little dance. Which for a guy in his 90s is pretty amazing. There’s another cameo that unfortunately is not Julie Andrews. I’m certain the part was offered to her, but she turned it down. Her reasoning was sweet. She didn’t want to distract from Emily Blunt’s performance. However, it’s still a special performance and, from the moment you hear the voice, you’ll know exactly who it is. Overall, Mary Poppins Returns feels like a throwback to the films of yesteryear. The viewer can clearly feel the love and care that went into being Mary back.
Great film! Feel bad for haters. I hope they find some joy in life somehow. It’s an enjoyable film that reminds me of the grand days when studios created a new musical in house. Recommend it highly.

First of all, Emily Blunt's performance as Mary Poppins is excellent. She makes this famous character her own by just embodying her. She seems more like somebody who actually cares about these children. The ending shows this the best. Also in the song "Where the Lost Things Go" they show her caring for the children a way that the original didn't show. I also have to applaud Lin-Manuel Miranda, who played Jack, performance in this film. You could easily tell that he was having fun with his character. I just wished we got to see his character more. I'm glad that they didn't change the special effects in this film and kept it in the style of the 1964 one. They did put a slight modern day look to it but it was still the same style at the end of the day. Now some people say that none of the songs in this aren't catchy and I argue over that. I would say that all but a few songs are catchy. The only non-catchy songs are the ones that are a bit slower and "Turning Turtle." All the other songs are energetic and have great choreography to go with them. Marc Shaiman also composed the original score for this film and it's just as magical. During the opening credits you can hear his score and in it, there are hints to the songs from the first film. The production design on each of the sets looks straight out of the first. I just wished they took a bit more care in making the house look more like the original. There are some obvious details to it that make it not look similar. For one the entryway is entirely different. They had some unique transitions between the scenes of the real world and imagination. The atmosphere in this film was excellent. In each scene, it gave off the correct type of atmosphere that you would feel in that situation. Finally, I think there were a few scenes that could have been cut out and it wouldn't have affected the movie. Mainly because they did nothing with it later on. In the end, Mary Poppins Returns is an excellent film that is just as great as the first one. I give Mary Poppins Returns a 8.5/10.

In my opinion, this is one of the best live action films Disney has made in 50 years! Everything about this movie is heart-warming, personal, and gorgeous: the beautiful painted backdrops, the gorgeous score (including the incidental music), the subtle and nuanced acting, the cameos, the relevant and relatable story line, the stunning and tastefully derivative animation, the  fluid and artful cinematography, the very fitting and immersive set and costumes, the professional vocals and both catchy and clever lyrics, the morals, the subtle political and social statements, the fact that there are opening credits with an actual overture, and the very idea that Disney legends like Richard Sherman were consulted, all of it just provides evidence that Disney set out to make a truly excellent film that makes you cry, picks you back up, and reminds you the joys of being a wide eyes and open hearted kit again! This is truly an instant Disney classic that is enjoyable and impactful for children of all ages! I can see Walt Disney smiling down upon this movie for capturing the very heart, joy, love, and wonder that Dinsey was founded on. Thank you, Disney, and for everyone involved for making this masterpiece and for making me want to go fly a kite again! God bless and Godspeed!

Ignore the bad reviews. Believe in magic again. My grandmother loved live theatre, Broadway in particular. As a youth, I was brought up loving live performances on stage and musicals. I can remember so fondly, she used to bathe my sister and I in the tub, signing songs from “South Pacific,” inserting her own words. (I didn’t realize that it wasn’t actually “dirt” being washed out of my hair but “men,” until I saw the show live on stage for the first time.) She would riff off songs from “Guys and Dolls,” dance to “Sweet Charity” around the kitchen while making us sandwiches. I’ve seen both the movie and stage show for “Mary Poppins” more times than I can count. Suffice to say, I’ve been excited for “Mary Poppins Returns” for some time. I did not take time to sit and watch the Julie Andrews original prior to viewing this new installment. Do yourself the favor and follow my lead. You’re going to compare the classic to the new movie, no matter what you do. It is easier to take them both as separate pieces if the classic isn’t fresh in your mind. The filmmakers do enough with this new plot so as not to lose the viewer. I’m sure there are plenty of Easter Eggs alluding to the original completely lost on me. Oh well. Even if you’ve never seen Mary Poppins before and have no idea the original plot, just the fact that she’s a nanny arrived to help will not be lost on you. Which brings us to my first point. For those of you who may have somehow not seen the original, you must go into this movie knowing that it’s a musical. Hence the reason I’m even talked about Broadway stage shows in the first place. Now, it’s a not a musical in the same vein as the recent “Les Miserables” featuring Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway singing every single, but filmmakers make no remorse that this movie has music at its core. “Mary Poppins Returns” even opens with a number sung by Lin-Manuel Miranda before the opening credits roll. That being said, if you’re not a fan of movie musicals, I must tell you, stay away. In terms of Ms. Poppins, the title character whom Julie Andrews made magic back in 1964, Emily Blunt is (for lack of better description,) practically perfect in every way. Have no fear of airbrushed posters that make Blunt look like Cate Blanchett in smoky black eyeliner. She’s bright, she’s witty, she’s charming, she’s charismatic and she has a great singing voice. She was quite right for the part and takes the reigns artfully from Andrews, which I’m sure was no easy task to do. Who would truly want to be the actor or actress to mess up Mary Poppins? Lin-Manuel Miranda is also great as Jack the Lamplighter, a nod to Dick Van Dyke’s Bert, the jack-of-all trades drifter from the original film. Miranda features the same wry grin, smattering of dirt on his face and cockney accent that Van Dyke made famous. In fact, Jack trained under Bert as a child, probably while Bert was bouncing between jobs, never staying in one place for too long. Jack has known the Banks family since Jane and Michael were little. Jack remembers Mary from her first appearance and knows all too well of her legend. He’s just as comfortable with her magic as Bert was the first time around. In terms of the music itself, I thought the songs were great. I can’t sit here and tell you that there are better songs than “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious,” or “Spoonful of Sugar.” Those songs have had 54 years to grow. I can tell you that there are plenty of songs that sound just like them. “The Royal Doulton Music Hall” is an obvious (and welcome) nod to “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious” (darn you for making me type that twice,) without being an annoying copy. “Trip the Light Fantastic” makes you feel nostalgia for “Chim-Chim Cher-ee.” As a movie goer, you won’t walk out of your theatre claiming that the songs are better than the original. Of course not, but it’s hard for me to actually claim to like a song the very first time I hear it. I enjoyed almost everything offered here. I think perhaps this year’s “Let it Go” might have appeared in “A Star is Born,” but “Mary Poppins Returns” does admirable justice to it’s classic predecessor. The film does fall flat in two places. First, Meryl Streep’s role as Mary’s cousin Topsy. This seemed to have just been a way of getting Meryl Streep into this movie, playing a role Johnny Depp could have been better suited for. The whole time she’s on-screen deviates from the central plot, and was obviously just a way for producers to advertise Meryl Streep being it. I didn’t find she advanced the story at all. She’s fine in her role, don’t get me wrong. She even gets a song. It also could have easily been cut, and we would’ve been none the wiser until deleted scenes on the DVD release. Second, when Mary, Jack and the children are mixing cartoon with live action, the film does turn a tad dark, probably what earns it its PG rating. There’s just a wee bit of child kidnapping and other nonsense. I just didn’t believe that Mary Poppins would be into herself for so long and stop paying attention to what was happening to the children. In the end, “Mary Poppins Returns” is everything I needed right now. It’s fun, it’s sad, it’s imaginative. In a digital age full of CGI action movies, virtual reality, smartphones, tablets and social media, (all my son wants to do is watch shows on his tablet or play Fortnite.) Action figures collect dust on the shelf. White paper stays blank, paint and markers dry up. It’s everything I can do to read books to him first, before he sits down to watch the movie. My failures in parenting aside, I do have fears that if I don’t step in, my kids won’t know how to properly use the spatial qualities of their imagination. One quote struck me from the movie, I don’t see the point of mentioning a “spoiler alert” because I won’t say which part of the film this turns up, and you can hear it during the movie’s preview, “(we’ve all of us) forgotten what it’s like, to be a child.” Mary Poppins couldn’t have returned at a better time. I didn’t realize I missed her so much. I pictured my grandmother sitting next to me in the theatre, just enjoying the movie as much as I did. I could feel her smiling down on me as the credits rolled. I know that this movie would have been dear to her heart. This was the best movie I saw in 2018. I find it difficult to stamp a perfect score on any movie, but this one got darn close.

There will likely be dissenters as with any sequel of this kind - think the kind of criticisms that Star Wars: The Force Awakens suffered from - most evidently that the plot was very similar to that of A New Hope. Indeed, that could be a fair criticism of Mary Poppins Returns, but it doesn茂驴 1/2 1/2(TM)t leave a mess of a film in front of you - in fact, the way the original is tied into this sequel is dealt with in a very emotive way - the subtle themes delivered via the score and key plot points from the original tied into the plot of this film are enough to jerk a tear or two in sentimentalists like me! 
Emily Blunt as Poppins is a grower - initially I wasn茂驴 1/2 1/2(TM)t sold, but by the second third of the film I thought she was practically perfect in every way!
Lin-Manuel Miranda茂驴 1/2 1/2(TM)s Lamp Lighter, Jack, will doubtless draw comparisons to Dick Van Dyke茂驴 1/2 1/2(TM)s Bert from the original, while Julie Waters & David Warner assume the roles of Ellen and Admiral Boom from the original and deliver some lovely comedy moments.
A trio of stunning cameos from Meryl Streep (Cousin Topsy), Dick Van Dyke (Reprising the role of Mr Dawes jnr) and Angela Lansbury (Balloon lady) really add to the film - the latter was simply amazing in her role! 
In a nutshell, I loved every minute of it & will probably struggle to get the three songs mentioned earlier in this review out of my head!

Perfectly done.  It is a reboot (akin to Star Wars reboot) where the plot is in many ways nearly identical, yet a sequel at the same time, even with Dick Van Dyke reprisal.  Quite clever in that regard, but i'll skip the spoiler details.  Blunt is perfect, especially given such a hard act to follow.  The movie is 9 minutes shorter than the original.  The overall character of the movie is very true to form.  The only disappointment is that there is no memorable tune -- the likes of  supercali and spoonful are replaced with formulaic (but decent) songs.

I literally could not stop smiling throughout the entire movie. I loved it. It was entertaining and uplifting-left me happy and inspired. I frankly did not know how it could hold up to the original Mary Poppins but it was its own kind of wonderful while weaving in with first one beautifully. I loved all the songs and the meanings they conveyed-acting and dancing was great.

Like many of the studio's other films during this live-action sequel-remake-reimagining renaissance, 'Mary Poppins Returns' doesn't bring much new to the table, but it offers up more than enough of that classic Disney magic to justify its existence thanks to Emily Blunt's performance and absolutely spectacular musical numbers.

The overall plot was not strong, but the series followed a similar path: just moral lessons and adventures of the Banks children. practically perfect in every way. a really enjoyable sequel that touches on all of the originals' tones. I truly believe that the only person that could play Mary Poppins after Julie Andrews is Emily Blunt and she didn't disappoint in this movie. Further proving her talents from being able to play any genre of movie, she knocks it out of the park as Mary. Maybe this movie is hitting me at the right time in my life, but the mix of the fun escapism of the places the kids go and real life struggles that Mr. Banks is going through are fully realized and hit home. I grew up on the classic Mary Poppins and Rob Marshall made me feel that magic again. I really enjoyed this, you won't get anything you didn't see before but, it's well acted all around from Emily Blunt, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Emily Mortimer (who really fits the grown up Jane), Ben Whishaw, the kids in the movie, and some special cameos, it's a fun time at the cinema this Christmas and worth going to see.

Musically, the movie fails miserably with not one of the songs coming close to those in the original movie. Dick Van Dyke steals the show at the end but cameos by Meryl Streep and Angela Lansbury seemed gratuitous. Technically the show is good but it's a shame to have all that talent and expertise weighed down by a wooden plot and tuneless music.

the movie was different than the orginal in these ways. it was LONG. without previews it's over 2 hours long. for kids in my opinion, it's too long. it's scary and dark in several scenes. I understand it was rated PG, but, unlike the original, it has several truly scary scenes. it also touched on many heavy subjects. death, loss of security, nightmares, lying and deceit. also, there were many scenes where the father was very angry with his children. the orginal Mary Poppins did have a few scenes like this, but, it was more of a snip than a rant. the overall movie aesthetically was dark. as in the lighting, coloring, gray skies, etc. then there were moments of polar opposite brightness, color, cheery songs. however, it was maybe 30% happy and 70% dark or low/sad. there were points where the movie seemed to drag and the storyline would go over a 7 or 8 year olds head. mostly in regards to the songs. the songs were used to guide the characters to dealing with the perils in the storyline and were not straightforward. that's fine for an older viewer but for those that are younger I feel it left the scary parts more prominent. I went with 4 total adults and 6 children. the acting was great. the happy parts were cute, but too few. overall I was disappointed because I thought the movie would be fun and uplifting. we left with many of the children frightened and my daughter fearing she would have nightmares. my daughter is not easily frightened. I feel like Mary Poppins Returns was geared towards those that watched Mary Poppins as a child and are now adults and missed the mark for those that may be children watching for the first time.

When Mary Poppins said the infamous line, “practically perfect in every way,” I felt like she might as well be describing the movie itself. But, Dick Van Dyke practically stole the whole movie in a few short minutes of a cameo near the end. I thought Emily Blunt put in a solid performance as Mary. Mary Poppins is back with an all new cast! Not to worry however, they're not ALL recasts like Emily Blunt. But the tenuous reasons for everyone filling the same roles but looking slightly different has us wishing they were recasts! And why not put a new face on old favorites like Bert and Mary? Having to explain why everyone fits the same mold as the original cast, while not being exactly the same, echoes the stiffness of the entire film. Mary Poppins Returns attempts to create a beat for beat remake of the original film by coming up with slants on our favorite Poppins story beats. The result is the feeling of being back in a musical, magical London that has us wishing for the old songs, cast, and adventures. Had this been a recast and a new Mary Poppins adventure that calls upon the beautiful of Travers books, this could have been a big win in the age of the Live Action Disney Re-hash. Alas, it is all too similar to Disney's Star Wars: The Force Awakens, which regurgitated Star Wars: A New Hope. You can't take an old film and rip off it's script beat for beat and come out with something fresh. Only originality will win back the soul of Hollywood. Mary Poppins had heart, and some great performances, but did not ultimately give us the new adventure it promised. You won't be upset you saw it, but you might just want to watch the original instead.

Since the whole image of Mary Poppins is prim-and-proper the dance scene in the tent I found inappropriate and out of character, not to mention a few other scenes (what a difference 54 years makes as to what is proper).  I think the writer and director focused too much on the fantasy world  with animation and green scene technology that they lost focus of the movie. The scene with the lamplighters (though intended to mimic the scene of the chimmey sweepers in the original Mary Poppins) did not fit into the movie and felt like it was just thrown into the movie to fill space.  The story was cute, but it just lacked the Disney magic of the original Mary Poppins. And lastly it would have been nice to see more of Dick Van Dyke in the movie.

In 1964, Walt Disney released an adaptation of "Mary Poppins" by P. L. Travers, and it became a huge hit. Not only did the film win several Oscars, but many have considered the film to one of the best Disney films ever made. However, Travers made more stories to the Mary Poppins character, and Disney never followed up. Until now. "Mary Poppins Returns" is pretty much exactly what one would get from the title alone. The film does offer a spectacular vision in both sight and sound, but lacks a decent story to tell. While "Mary Poppins Returns" may disappoint fans of the original film, it does offer up some great eye candy that's almost practically perfect in every way.

The story is set during The Great Slump (Britain's answer of the Great Depression). Jane and Michael Banks (Emily Mortimer and Ben Whishaw respectably), are now grown up, and are trying to make a living without their parents. Because of hard times, money is scarce, and Michael is trying to help raise his three children after his wife passed. Then, during a strong wind, Mary Poppins (Emily Blunt) comes in and seeks to help Michael and his children have a lesson in fun and not repeat what his father did in the past. With help from a person named Jack (Lin-Manuel Miranda), Mary Poppins and the children must try and help their father regain their house before something terrible happens.


"Mary Poppins Returns" is something of a mixed bag.

For starters, the film is very impressive on a technical level. The sound design is excellent as it brings forth a lot of unique and interesting situations For instance, there is a scene near the beginning of the film where Mary Poppins and children are in an underwater  world, and the sound design really shows off here.

Next up, the set designs and costumes almost feel like an exact replica of the original film, just with a modern coat of paint. The time period of the 1930s not is a tribute to when the original books were set, but also a good transition of time from the first film. Plus, the costumes look great on each actor, and compliment the movie very well.

Speaking of which, the acting is pretty good here; under the supervision of Rob Marshall, the movie has a wide and varied cast. Blunt really shines as a new and modern Mary Poppins, and she has enough spirit from the first film that she makes the character her own.

One of the big highlights from this film is the special effects. Yes, most of the time, the usage of computers is seen here, but for a brief and very exciting moment, we get a sequence where the main characters are in an animated world, and everything's all done in hand drawn animation. And it looks really good.

Now, onto the main problems with the film.

For instance, the entire songs and music presented in the film just isn't as memorable as the Sherman Brothers main contributions. Plus, there isn't time for the audience to fully take in what just happened and fully catch their breath. This, in turn, can lead to some slow pacing issues, making the film drag; the original was slow, too, but there was a purpose for it as it showed what is happening with the story.

Speaking of which, the story is the biggest issue that the movie presents itself. It almost feels like the audience is watching a different version of the first film, just in a different setting. Plus, this movie has a main villain; Mary Poppins doesn't need a villain, and here, it feels forced and unnecessary.

In conclusion, "Mary Poppins Returns" almost feels unnecessary to do sequel, it does have its moments of creativity, but for intentions and purposes, the film tries very hard to recapture the magic that the original had.

It appears as though Emily Blunt took Benicio del Toro's advice seriously and left law enforcement altogether. Regarding her absence from Sicario: Day of the Soldado, she apparently time warped through the sky to pre-WW II London to teach children about imagination. Her experience in the battlefield of the drug war and not knowing who to trust has hardened her. Beneath her well-tailored demeanor lies the seething chaos of a perspicacious narcissist, hell-bent on bending reality to her whims.

Her singing and dancing are only chameleonesque, peacock-like machinations to dazzle and distract the weak minded from her true intentions - some nihilistic end that we shall probably never fully understand couched within cautionary truisms. One wouldn't expect Disney to be taking this darker edged approach to their long-awaited franchise endeavor in the Mary Poppins IP, but they probably saw the worldwide box office returns for Batman v. Superman and decided to give it a shot. Believe it or not, however, I found myself dealing less with my own latent teenage angst through brutal violence and death and, instead, tearing up constantly from the whimsical joy of kind-heartedness and wonderment displayed in Mary Poppins Returns.

Seriously, I couldn't stop crying. I don't know if there was an experimental, DARPA-made, sonic ray gun pointed directly at me or if sitting in the cinema for an accumulated 8 hours had bludgeoned me into a supple, emotionally compromised meat bag, but some strange frequency I had not felt since Paddington 2 blasted through my chest and left me weeping, a supplicant at the altar of Blunt's shrewd, yet caring Mary Poppins. If you've allowed yourself to become emotionally divorced from the sight and sound machine, I highly encourage you girding yourself at any upcoming screening of Mary Poppins Returns for fear of a melted heart.

Another way to cope with the onslaught of musical merriment, dazzling choreography, sweetly inquisitive children, and family-based morality is to remember that the film is a several decades late sequel, made as a safe holiday season cash cow. And if you can forego the cynical dismissal that it's an unnecessary movie banking on how similar it is to the original (a la The Force Awakens), you will easily be swept up in the joyous song and dance expertly pulled off by Blunt and Lin-Manuel Miranda accompanied by impressive 2D animated implementation and practical camera trickery.

If you want to condemn the soulless Hollywood machine for cranking out another crowd-pleasing entry in one of its multitudinous old stories, be my guest, but then you won't get to see a decrepit Dick van Dyke and Angela Lansbury eek out the last of their life-essence to the Illuminati on screen. As for me, I enjoy a nice lachrymal session in the theater. I may look like some weird dude in a Behemoth shirt weeping during a happy movie about a singing British nanny, but thankfully they keep the lights low enough during the screening that I don't fully give off the appearance of a mental breakdown.

I could not stop smiling throughout the entire movie.  Emily Blunt proves herself to be the practically perfect Mary Poppins to fill the shoes of an equally practically perfect Julie Andrews.  I would even go so far as to say that Ms Blunts Mary Poppins felt a bit more real to me.  She seemed to feel more, to have a sense of longing, a touch of sadness - the spoils of being so wise.  I would chalk this up to the people behind the camera giving room for the actors to find their characters.  

Lin Manuel Miranda looked as though he were having the time of his life.  And that smile I mentioned having throughout the entire movie?  That smile was so huge during the dance number for Trip a Little Light Fantastic.  

I brought my daughter, son-in-law (who by the way has a huge crush on Julie Andrews) and my 8 year old grandson to see the movie.  It was unanimous, we loved it.  All of it.  Everyone in it.  All the songs, the music, the dancing, the story, the call backs.

No practically about it - it was, plain and simple, a perfect, joyful fun magical movie!

Old school Disney Magic. They actually pulled it off. It feels like Mary Poppins. Emily Blunt is the clear choice. Lin Manuel Miranda grins like a child throughout. They have a ridiculously awesome number together halfway through. It was meant for the big screen. 

That said, the music is really great though not as memorable as the original. But that isnâ(TM)t saying much because the music of the original is essentially perfect and is unmatched by even the best of today. No, they donâ(TM)t sing the old songs at all, but there are little call backs to the old cues here and there. 

I want to get back to my âOldschool Disney magicâ? comment for a second. I say that not only because you have big music numbers backed by full orchestras. But also because this movie wasnâ(TM)t afraid to get weird like the old movies. I canâ(TM)t explain it, but they flaunt the weird characters (both real and animated alike!) like they did in the old days of Disney. And this also allowed them to tackle important themes for kids in more mature ways than Iâ(TM)ve seen from Disney in some time. And most importantly, it felt like Poppins. 

I highly recommend you take your kids to this movie. If you donâ(TM)t have kids, then take yourself!

I loved it! I saw Mary Poppins Returns (MR2) today. I took me back when I saw it so long ago on the big screen as a small kid. Watching the trailers, I was afraid Jane Banks would not be in it. I was pleased the character that I thought was Mrs. Michael Banks, was his sister, Jane. Though older, so many of the same characters that lived along Cherry Lane are back. I LOVED all the little references to MR1, that were there for the fans that watched MR1 so many times, but will pass the average movie goer. The music scores had traces of Sherman's score along most of the track. I liked the old woman's clothes from MR1 laying on the steps of St. Paul with all her doves. I would have loved a beautiful song such as "Feed the Birds" (not the exact song, but something memorable) in MR2, but I don't know it could have been placed with the current plot. I did love the scrambling of Dick Van Dyke's letters at the end as it was done in MR1 for him at the end. And what a glorious surprise to see Angela Lansbury in it and Meryl Streep. I did read the Travis books last year and I believe, the story of the "second Wednesday topsy-turvy" was in one of the books. I also was glad to see that the umbrella bird head got more speaking parts this time. In MR1, the parrot said quite a bit in the very beginning while MR was sitting on the cloud. But on all the versions I have found to buy, the parrot only speaks at the end. I have a lot more to say, but I strongly encourage all the fans of MR1 to relieve those moments of watching it the first time and go see MR2. It is supercalifragilisticexpealidocious!

MARY POPPINS RETURNS

I grew up knowing the original story, so there was a lot to live up to. At over 2 hours, this surprise sequel, honestly, did a pretty good job.

Emily Blunt really put her all into bringing Julie Andrews' most famous character back to life, & I think she succeeded. I honestly believed I was seeing the same Mary Poppins I saw years ago, older, more traveled, but still the same. The rest of the cast all did an amazing job, bringing back old characters, & introducing new ones. We even got some cameos & a surprise actor, no spoilers but rest assured, they're worth seeing.

The effects & set design were a treat. I really believed I was in 1930s-ish London, the Banks family home, & Mary Poppins' fantastical world. And while there was some CGI, it felt like most of the effects were done in the classic movies' fashion.

The music was classic Poppins & classic Disney, they went all out, the choreography also fit the film perfectly, like the dancers from the original film time hopped right to this one!

Mary Poppins Returns wasn't a sequel anyone asked for, but I'm glad we got it. It respected the past, while continuing the story in a believable way, & reminding us of things we, sadly, shouldn't have forgotten, but did. 4 stars outta 5, I hereby dub this film respectfully supercalafragalisticexpialadosious.

Mary Poppins Returns is a memorable movie and was enjoyable to watch as an advocate of the original movie. The songs wouldn't become as memorable as the songs written by the Sherman Brothers, but the production crew and music was astonishing. I especially like the revival of the original hand-drawn animation, as we haven't seen that from Disney in a while. Hugely recommended regardless.

However, i found myself wondering why i spent the money to hear little score, lack of passion in every song, and bad child acting. The interaction with CGI was poor and the only song that had me feeling anything was the closing song.

The new songs are hit or miss (which I expected, especially since the original has a jaw dropping number of perfect songs) but the movie is a lot more charming than I expected. Most surprising is that the movie finds a compelling arc for Michael Banks (featuring Ben Winshaw in the best performance in this movie), one that neither mirrors his father's in the first one nor feels forced.

To the movie......Emily Blunt was amazing. The special effects were a lot of fun and very imaginative. For almost all of the movie, I had a smile on my face. Wouldn't we all like to take a bath in Mary Poppin's world. Or who wouldn't have a blast visiting a land on a china bowl? The movie was just a lot of fun. Would have actually rated this lengthy sequel, which often looked more like an updated retelling, much lower if not for the high quality production value and acting.  It appears they set the original plot points and musical numbers down in one column and simply replaced some of the details with contemporary themes and language in the next column, while preserving the original and overly recognizable framework, unfortunately leaving us with a dull and cliche narrative.  I found the music to be unmemorable and uninspiring and doubt any of these songs will gain a tiny fraction of the space multiple numbers in the original Mary Poppins still take up in popular culture today.  The acting was extremely enjoyable all around for me and wish the cast would have been given more of a story I could jump into.  Viewed in Dolby as well which usually only improves my enjoyment and rating.

I find usually sequels a bit dull and this surely doesn't live up to the original Mary Poppins. It might be that this Mary is more authentic in how she is depicted in the books, but she lacks the charm of Julie Andrew's one and becomes a bit too forced/too irritating at times. 
The movie is a inch too long and it tries to mimic the same schema as the first movie with the "trips" into the magical world, meeting some weird relative (the Topsy sequence was though very good), having a bunch of low class workers dancing around,  helping adults to find their inner child again as solution to many issues... 
Some aspects are just touched and seems that there is a vivid intention to put a lot of elements alltogether (even the special interest of the lamp lighter for Jane Banks) without much consequential thought or relevant plan.
Even the soundtrack is blend. And it is natural to compare it with the amazing one of THE Mary Poppins, because I do not remember a single song of this and all of them seemed similar to each other. 
I was not impressed by the acting. All seemed very forced and artificial. 
All of this though in an impeccable setting, full of amazing details, beautiful picture, nice atmosphere and colors. Pity the magic is blurred.

Over 50 years in the making, Mary Poppins makes her grand return to the big screen in this brand new sequel to the 1964 original classic. Emily Blunt plays the practically perfect in every way magical nanny, originally played by Julie Andrews. Blunt does an excellent job bringing a new take on the titular nanny. She leads the film with an intrepid supporting cast including Lin-Manuel Miranda, Meryl Streep, and Angela Lansbury. Much like its predecessor the sequel is a musical that showcase brand new songs that are well crafted and really enjoyable. It not only features incredibly beautiful visual effects, but also a nice throwback with its combination of live action and traditional hand drawn animation. They do also include some nice computer graphic imagery in the film, most notably during the ocean scene in the "Can You Imagine That?" musical sequence. This sequel is a lovely homage to the legacy of its predecessor, while delivering a magical new Mary Poppins story that's familiar yet still an enchanting follow up to the 1964 film. 

Walt Disney's original film is both highly regarded, as well as considered a bit of a relic of its time. Although its appeal has not diminished with the iconic music, and memorable performances of Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke from the original film. Emily Blunt makes the role of Mary Poppins her own marvelously, with a stricter and firm portrayal than from Julie Andrews kinder take on the magical nanny. Blunt gives Mary Poppins a slight edge while maintaining her gentle side. The supporting cast do splendid jobs in their roles. Some honorable mentions include Lin-Manuel Miranda is very charming as Jack, a lamplighter and former apprentice to Bret from the original film. Meryl Streep brings a delightfully quirky performance as Mary Poppins Eastern European cousin, Topsy. Angela Lansbury (who voiced Mrs. Potts in the animated version of Beauty and the Beast) has a very sweet small role during an uplifting musical number towards the end of the film. 

The musical score and songs is helmed by Hairspray songwriters Marc Shaiman, and Scott Wittman. Their songs are not only highly enjoyable but have a surprising amount of depth to them. Although, they lack the irresistible charm and feel more like counterparts to the Sherman Brothers tunes. That's not to say the songs are in anyway as bad as some would have you believe, they're beautifully crafted and feature some wonderful messages for both kids and adults. Some of my standout favorites in the film are "Can you Imagine That?", "A Cover Is Not the Book", and "Trip A Little Light Fantastic". However, the song that is my #1 favorite in the film is the one Angela Lansbury sings called "Nowhere to Go but Up". It's a truly beautiful finale song. Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman do a tremendous job integrating the songs while moving the plot forward at the same time.

The story of this sequel delivers a big dose of nostalgia. It tends to feel as though it almost mirrors that of the 1964 film, but still manages to expand upon its predecessor. Although, it hints at an important part of the plot rather early on in the film. The visual effects and animation are quite possibly even more magical than the original. I'm especially glad Disney stayed true to the originals legacy of using traditional hand drawn animation. Not only that the film also featured some pretty neat computer graphic imagery, particularly during the ocean scene in with the dolphins in the "Can You Imagine That?" musical sequence. 

Overall Mary Poppins Returns is a truly wonderful follow up to its predecessor. Emily Blunt is a fantastic new Mary Poppins for a new generation, with an equally impressive supporting cast. The score and songs are exceptionally beautiful. Even if you don't find yourself humming the tunes when the movies over doesn't mean they are necessarily bad, they just don't quite reach the standards set by the Sherman Brothers. It honors the legacy of the 1964 film with its music, visual effects, and animation. The plot is similar to the original, but suffers from revealing is plot quite early in the film. Yet it still manages to capture much of the magic of the original film quite brilliantly.

Mary Poppins Returns is charming. That really is the best word to describe it. I dare you to watch it without a smile on your face. Delightfully reminiscent of the original, it is a magical and heartwarming story for the whole family.

Emily Blunt makes a wonderful Mary Poppins. She looks the part, for certain, and her voice is perfection. She nails the iconic character's quirks; her briskness, her no-nonsense nanny-ing, her unapologetic self-admiration, her mysteriously knowing smile. Lin-Manuel Miranda plays a lamplighter named Jack, who is an unexpectedly delightful character. With his mischievous smile and easy charm, he wins you over immediately. Ben Whishaw and Emily Mortimer are also lovely as the grown-up Banks children. The newest generation of Banks kids are all delightfully, amusingly precocious. And the rest of the cast, including Colin Firth, Meryl Streep and Julie Walters, are all unsurprisingly fantastic as they portray a wide variety of eccentric characters.

I've read that some people were less than impressed with the soundtrack. Yes, it is true that it does not quite compare to the legendary songs of the first movie, and some of the numbers are disappointingly mediocre. Others, though, are much catchier and memorable, with 'A Cover Is Not the Book' probably being my favorite.

Overall, this is a fun, whimsical and light-hearted film. Yeah, it is a bit cliche and predictable. But with the colorful 2D animation and plenty of other nods to 1964 original, it is a great film to watch if you want to feel a bit warm and fuzzy.

While I did enjoy it, I have to say it's not as good as the original 1964 film. It's not a matter of any bad casting decisions; it just did not have the charm of the original one. The music was not as good, and the movie relied more on heavy special effects to keep the audience captivated. The story was also darker than the original. The original was more fun. This one tried to be fun, but it was a little bit forced. The situation is  more tragic: Michael Banks is now a widower and a father of three children. He's fallen on hard financial times. The very bank that his father worked for, and he now works for, is going to take his house, if he can't pay off a loan he took out, or prove that he owns bank shares. They can't find their certificate for the shares, and the guy who now owns the bank tears the page out of the record book of the Banks family and burns it. Michael spends most of the movie in a funk. In the original film the main conflict was that the father was a workaholic, who left the care of his children completely up to a nanny. Although his wife was a suffragette, when Mr. Banks was  home, she acted very submissive and he was very chauvinistic..The movie shows the humor of the domineering male. If you had not seen the original movie, you might think this was really good, but for those of us who know the original, it pales in comparison.
Mary Poppins Returns is charming, an excellent nostalgia and complete magical in every way.

It's hard to rate because I grew up with the first adaptation. I feel like Emily Blunt occasionally slips during her act, as in, there's an inconsistency to it; I've watched her other performances, and this is so far the only time I feel like there's "she's in-character" and "um, this doesn't feel like the same character". The mannerism and stuff.

That said, I did like quite a few of the songs and I like the animated parts.

I really like this movie. I don’t love it as much as the first, but, I do think it’s a worth follow-up to a practically perfectly aged Disney classic of nearly 55 years. Emily Blunt does Julie Andrews Justice as Mary Poppins. Ben Whishaw also makes a good combination of humor, sadness and vulnerability to the role of an adult Michael Banks. Emily Mortimer does do a good job of taking on the role of Jane, though I do wonder how she’s able to stay happy and positive in a movie where her brother is on the verge of a mental collapse. As for as how Lin-Manuel Miranda did in this movie as Jack, he did pretty good, not Dick Van Dyke-level good (more on him in a little bit), but, I do think for his first feature film role coming off of Broadway productions like “In the Heights” and, the obviously big one, “Hamilton”, this is a good start for his feature film career. Now, as far as the set pieces and visual effects, I really think they were well put together. The one set pieces that stood out to me the most were the underwater sequence (which I think will give Rob Marshall his keys into directing the live-action “Little Mermaid” for Disney, especially if people like how James Wan was able to pull of the underwater settings of “Aquaman”, too) and the sequence where Mary Poppins, Jack and the Banks kids go into a China bowl for the insanely hyped return of 2D cartoon animation mixed with live-action, which I will say is the big colorful highlight of the movie that I hope people really like to get Disney convinced to do more hand drawn animated films in the future and/or more 2D animated/live-action hybrids such as the long in-development “Enchanted” sequel called “DisEnchanted”. Now, as far as the songs, there were only a few that really were memorable to me: “Underneath the Lovely London Sky”, “Can You Imagine That?”, “Trip a Little Light Fantastic” and “Nowhere To Go But Up”. But, I do think the rest of the movie’s music and the orchestra conducted by Marc Shaiman fit perfectly with this movie and felt very grand and classic. And, I will say Dick Van Dyke’s very excellent returning cameo as Mr. Dawes Sr. had to do with one of these songs and I’ll leave you to guess which one it is. Now, if you had asked me which one of Disney’s two live-action franchise continuations/sequels I enjoyed more, “Christopher Robin” or “Mary Poppins Returns”, I would say “Christopher Robin” because I really was hyped to see Winnie the Pooh return to the big screen since as a child, he was the Disney character I related to the most. But, I will say that this movie, as a movie for the whole family, is worth your time and should be seen, in Dolby Cinema format especially, since the color grading feels more clearer. So, overall rating: 8/10 or 4 stars. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

A very uplifting and cheerful musical sequel to the classic and timeless 1964 film, in which decades after her original visit, the magical nanny returns with another incredible adventure to help the Banks siblings and Michael's children through a difficult time in their lives. Even though it does not surpass the original, it provides an exhilarating, but similar plot with a couple of memorable songs such as "The Place Where Lost Things Go" and "Trip a Little Light Fantastic". Emily Blunt demonstrates that she can play any character and she adds a unique touch to the lovable nanny with very clever and hilarious lines and Lin-Manuel Miranda is as passionate and engaged as usual. Excellent sets, music and costumes! Best of lucks at the awards season!
Unfortunately not as magical as the first one, but it's still quite enjoyable.

While its biggest strength is its penchant for nostalgia, ‘Mary Poppins Returns’ does have a bit more to offer. The cast is more than capable of taking up the mantle of the original cast, and Rob Marshall continues to display his knack for directing movie musicals. The songs are certainly derivative, and often drag on for a bit, but the staging and choreography inject a bit more life into them. If you love the original like I do, you will probably find many moments of delight amidst the merely serviceable.

Mary Poppins Returns should have stayed on the page. Though Emily Blunt plays a truer depiction of Mary Poppins than the charming depiction of her predecessor Julie Andrews, and the performance of Broadway star Lin-Manuel Mirandaï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s character is a lovable but a less creative copy of Burt (Dick Van Dyke), the star studded cast can not save the sluggish soundtrack. The songs fell flat and did not have the warm and earworm-worthy melodies but rather served as filler for the unsure plot. The story follows Mary Poppins, who is now looking after Michael Banksï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) children, accompanied by Jack (Lin-Manuel Miranda). The film wishes to relight the childlike wonder of Jane and Michael Banksï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) adventures from the original by mirroring the new adventures of the children but does not deliver on the nostalgia. At best, Mary Poppins Returns is a cash grab family film that felt like a cheap adaptation of a Broadway performance, lacking the overall intrigue of the original. You will leave the theatre wishing you had rewatched the original.

Overall: 3.5/5

Emily Blunt and Lin-Manuel Miranda bring their talents to bear with cameos from some old friends.

Emily Blunt is fantastic as Mary Poppins and a worthy successor to Julie Andrews. While the film displays wonderful choreography and splendid visuals, both animated and live-action,  it sticks too closely to the familiar instead of expanding the universe. Rob Marshall had all the means to create another classic out of P. L. Travers's beloved stories but unfortunately Mary Poppins Returns lacks its own magic.

Walt Disney's proudly-achieved sensational classic "Mary Poppins" soared off the pages of P.L. Travers' book onto the screen, delighting families, then eventually shared to generations, with wonder and whimsicality as well the true definition of a family film. This kind of classic is frequently considered as independent, a one-hit wonder that doesn't need a follow-up to duplicate the magical originality that was brought into the cinema. If there was ever a follow-up announced, there is inner intention of offering a story for the current generation with remembrance and nostalgia under experiencing the replicated magic, while there is also the outer doubt on being up to the original's par. Fifty-four years later, "Mary Poppins Returns" is right at the standardized perfection as [permitted] reassurance.

A few decades since the original visit, the Banks family are struggling against the Great Depression after a devastating tragedy occurred. Then as fate has it like before, the magical nanny Mary Poppins returns to help the now-grown siblings and Michael's children to get through this difficult time, and remind them what they lost touch in.

The premise may seem to follow the "history repeats itself" trope, particularly when transferring roles to the next generation with the exception of the main character being an indirect inspirational source of subtle motivation. Even though I didn't get the time to view the original predecessor prior to the revisiting, the reliance of the structure did felt to be derivatively focused on the original while putting in new ideas that maintains the story's ideals. While it may be frown upon as a criticized flaw, it is actually understandable when continuing the story after a large gap of decades in between the two films.

Director Rob Marshall used his notable theatrical skills to take us back to Cherry Tree Lane with fantastic art direction and honoring Walt Disney's ambition of bringing the titular nanny onto the screen - physically and magically back to the screen in this case. This can be considered Marshall's best work at the most special when he managed to nostalgically bring back the grandness from the original's time, especially the purity of Disney magic that is more direct to the film's own definitive stance. One of the few aspects of the said magic that resurfaced from the original is the new animated sequence in all the missed, forgotten glory as a proposed comeback for the medium's initial form.

The most prominent factor that declared "Mary Poppins" a classic is the music that furthers the whimsical wonders as an extra filling to the heart at delightful levels. Marc Shaiman's composed score rejuvenated the classic grand feels, including the defining of Disney and the expressive return when the spectators are being transported into a magical world whereas dimensionally impossible imagination is realistically possible. The songs follows the sequel structural arrangement for similar tunes at fitting narrative placement with own meanings being carried. Now they may not be at the iconic level of the original's soundtrack, they still carry lovely and excellent tunes at some being quite almost as memorable as the predecessor's while the score itself is just plain great.

Finally, next to the music in the soul is the excellent cast's performances showing such capability of continuing a story's legacy through the main energetic source from the characterization. They all fulfilled their roles to the fullest of the original's heartening content with their own narratively-active part of reaching right up to the previous standard. Lin-Manuel Miranda's performance parallels to the still-talented Dick Van Dyke at that age with the musical charm and the choreography's extravagant center. Then the main star taking on the challenge of filling in Julie Andrews' titular shoes is Emily Blunt with a simple descriptive quote of her performance and the film as the year's most whimsically wonderful picture: "Practically perfect in every way." (A+)

If Walt was still alive at age 117, he would've floated up to the ceiling with tears of joy.
